title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hello everybody welcome to another DIY video we are doing rope shells these shells are so versatile and are an awesome thing to bring into your interior space if you're decorating you need storage or you need a place to display items what's amazing about them is you can make them any height you want you might know that if you're shopping at the stores if you're trying to buy a shelf that's over six feet tall they're hard to find and they're also really pricey but this shelf you can make at any height you want for not a lot of money at all we have these in our style set which you may have seen in a recent style video and they're just too amazing not to show you how to make and then you guys can make them for yourself and save money and how about something else what's that about that nothing I will go through the basic supplies I was saying these are rope shelves so rope this is the natural fiber rope that you can get at any hardware store I personally like this rope because I really like the natural look to it but you could do a more streamlined cotton rope or even metal chain if you were super adventurous you need a piece of wood if you want more than one shelf you will need multiple pieces of wood but that's up to you guys but I'm just going to demonstrate for you guys on this one piece of wood repeat the same process with as many shelves as you need another very important thing is a drill with a nice hefty drill bit one that will give you a big enough hole to fit your rope through some pale pink paint I also have a big ruler here pencil sandpaper a piece of paper which you'll see what I'm going to do with that and some scissors that's all the supplies let's get into the deck a very important part of this DIY is balance now I know that I want the holes to be three inches in from both sides so in order to make sure that I am drilling the holes in the same spot on all the shelves I'm going to make a three inch square out of this paper and this is my template that's going to help me not have to use the ruler every time so I've just placed the square here and I'm just going to mark at the point three inches in on either side repeat the same easy process on all the corners alright I've got my holes marked and now I've got my drill with my nice big drill bit and I'm going to make the holes in my rope now you want to use some sandpaper to smooth out your shelf and you can also take this opportunity to smooth out the size of your shelf as well so before you paint you just want to wipe down your shelf with a cloth to make sure you don't have any dust left over from the sandpaper and now for the painting or the staining part whatever your choice another tip is if you don't want the look of brushstrokes with the paintbrush you could use your rag to kind of smooth in the paint a little bit this creates kind of more of a wash over the wood and with the magic of cinema my shelf is now dry and fully painted but of course you want to repeat this process with as many shelves as you want for your particular shelving unit the next step will be to take all of your painted shelves and actually get them strung up on the rope and hung up forever you're mounting them so I've got my rope and I've got two screw hooks here and this is what I'm going to use to anchor into my wood beams that I'm hanging from got my supplies got my painted shelves let's head to the shelf area yeah like some trail be hey hey we're making shelves sorry I just have this rope and my cowboy tendencies okay Mel you know those public doesn't say you want to err on the side of too much rope because you're going to be threading through the shelves and then knotting underneath each shelf on either side and you're going to be making a loop knock like when you take two threads at the same time and off them together like some so obviously that eats up some rope so you just want to make sure that you have a nice amount that you can trim later have to add so I have the center of this long piece of rope right here and obviously that's creating a loop and this loop I am going to use to hook on to my screw hope that will be screwed into my beam in the feeling and of course I have two of these which will be on either side of the shelves I'm gonna use a piece of tape here to wrap around the fray tip to just kind of seal the fibers make it easier to pull through the holes and I'm also going to make kind of a little like point that extends beyond the edge of the rope that will make it easy to pull through the hole all right so painted shelf here I'm just going to feed them through you want to start with your top shelf and work your way down so since this is my top shelf I'm pulling the rope to get closer to my middle point here is where I will hang from the ceiling and then not underneath so a nice loop not like this underneath which is going to secure the rope from pulling through the show that so this is one side I got to repeat this on the other side and then hang this up on my screw hook great nice and snug and straight so obviously the key when you're tying these knots underneath each shelf is to keep them kind of loose at first so you can finagle and make sure that your shelf looks nice and straight before you make the knot snug keep in mind as well when you put something on top of these shelves that will weight them down and also keep them balanced and sturdy so looking good straight shelves we got the final one to go all right Street yeah oh my gosh okay so this looks so cool they are floating but they're sturdy it's just just eject the position masterpiece if I do say so myself and then for these extra lengths of rope here you can remove the tape and just let them kind of foil on the floor in a cool industrial way which is what I personally like or you could trim them right underneath the knot so that the Shelf looks like is totally floating I like the coil look because it looks a little more industrial especially because we have concrete floors but totally up to you you how amazing are those shelves I'm so thrilled with this product I just I love how versatile it is and use types of shelves looks so good in so many different interior design styles so if you do this project please post pictures and hashtag mr. Kate so I can see because I would love to see your rendition there's obviously so many options you can go to the moon with these shelves that would be cool please subscribe so you don't miss any of our shoot for the moon projects that we will have coming at you very soon always we're working hard and thumbs up if you liked the video and comment too if you have any questions at all I would love to be your accomplice in accomplishing this project and tune in next time we will see you on the morrow friends shelf it no I love you that sounded weird I love you I love you bye mr. geek we are making geometric wall storage pockets they are functional they are sheep what I love about these is they are so cool-looking they're sturdy and they're functional you can use them in so many different areas of your home

content: hey this is adam from smart furniture and this is a quick walkthrough of how to install your floating wall shelf so take your bracket you're going to position about how high you want you're going to find your nearest stud with this stud finder right about there I'm going to take my pencil and now we're going to mark right in the center of my stud come into the center make your tick mark right there now you're going to take your bracket and you're going to draw the top outer hole right there you're going to come you're going to do the other side or top outer hole now I'm going to take your drill with the drill bit is slightly smaller than your hardware drill in about half the length of your hard work all right now we can bring up the bracket we're going to hand tighten this top screw make sure you're up arrow will make it pivot up there that top bracket whole hand tightening now switch to a Phillips head bitch you're going to do this about ninety percent away you don't wanna do all the way because we need some way to go up when we leveled out so I'm going to get this going ninety percent all right now we need to get our level and we're going to pull it up with the same hand I'm going to hold this level in a right in the center and I'm going to mark all my remaining holes to outer the one Center in my other outer now I can drop this back down a little bit I need to make sure which ones are going to land on the stud these are this one is just going to be a drywall so I'm going to need to put an anchor in there after I pre-drill i'm going to pre Joe all the holes to the same bit just bring it back in here three drill these these are going to be straight straight into the stud this one that was going to be a little bigger I'll pull this back control that one as well now I'm going to take the rest of my Hardware get it ready to go but first I got to put in my drama anchor because this is just going to be a drywall anchor so put that in there just press firmly with your thumb there now I got my hardware I'm going to pull this back up I'm going to hand tighten in the top outer one to the hole I just made that's going to be easier than trying to drill and hold the bracket at the same time now you can switch back to your Phillips head bit and you can go ahead and put these in I usually do about 90% until I get all of them in and then I will finish them off so now everything's ready to go in these can go in all the way the center one into the drywall anchor and this last one is going to be straight into the stud I can go ahead and finish these two hours from ninety percent to 100 same here now I'm ready to slide the shelf on make sure your screws screw holes if they're there I'm going to be on the bottom simply slide this on firmly pressed against the wall there's one last step is you're going to screw the bottom screws in to secure it into the bracket not all shows have this but if they do you definitely need to do it and that's it there's your shelf ready to go you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
*Intro music* Hey guys! We're Evan and Katelyn! Today we're making an easy DIY entryway shelf, thingy with hooks you put keys in, and your mail on, and... We're making one of those This project is great for woodworking beginners, cause the steps are real easy to follow you only need two power-tools, and some supplies, which will be linked below This piece is made with a backing, two shelves, one with magnets under it for your keys, and four hooks Also, one shelf has a lip to hold mail But it's really modular. You can make it longer, add more hooks, take away the shelves, etc. For wood, we got select pine from the hardware store It's twice the price of the cheap stuff, but still cheap, and it's easier to work with, and it looks nicer There's a lot of options for hooks, like dowels, knobs, actual hooks But we ended up with these bath towel hooks from Amazon With our circular saw, we cut a 1x8 for the backing, and 1x4s for shelves We have a quick tip for this at the end of the video We also cut a square dowel to make a lip for the smaller shelf to hold mail We did a dry fit to make sure it all looked right, and then gave it a light sanding On the back, we marked where we wanted our long shelf to be, and three points to drill through into it We drilled pilot holes through just the backing first, and then we clamped on our shelf piece and drilled into that We should have used more that one clamp because it shifted, but luckily it was ok Then we did the same thing to screw the dowel to the smaller shelf It was a little misaligned, so we sanded down the ends Yes! Now it's time for magnets The magnets we used have a 3/8 inch diameter and are 1/4 inch long We put a piece of tape on our drill bit to help us drill to the right depth Then we used our favorite CA glue to secure the magnet in Once you do that, panic cause you don't know where your hammer is And grab a 2x4 to hammer it in Hey! Perfect!
That's one way to do it We attached the little shelf with screws, and took the whole thing outside to stain Nice! It makes the end look so much better We did two coats of shellac, which is sooo easy to work with and sanded with 600 grit sandpaper really lightly after each coat Then we applied some Briwax and buffed it out by hand And now, all that's left is hardware We marked and pre-drilled the holes We used our favorite screwdriver to drive these in by hand since they were a little close to the edge Then we added rubber feat so it'd hang straight, and not mark up the wall Next, we attached our hooks Side note: These were awesome cause they were really long, and way cheaper than anything else we found Should we go? Thank you guys for watching! *laugh* If you want to see what we're up to next, you can follow us on Instagram And for detailed plans, we have links below And don't forget to subscribe, if you haven't already Thank you! OK, quick tip time! Lining up your circular saw blade can be tricky, so here's how to make a little jig for accurate cuts First, raise the blade so that it won't cut all the way through the wood Then, clamp a speed square to some scrap wood mark a line along it, and cut a groove using the speed square as a guide Now you have a guide that shows you a line where your speed square should be, and a groove where your blade will cut You could cut all the way through the wood, instead of doing a groove But we like the groove, because it shows the thickness of the cut *beep* *hahahaha!* *beep* Do be do. Do be do be do Do You ready? *beep* Nooooo!!! *beep* The entry shelf... Our entry waaaaay... It's a haunted entryway Entry-waaaaa aaaaayyy!!! *beep*

Also, one shelf has a lip to hold mail
But it's really modular. You can make it longer, add more hooks, take away the shelves, etc.
For wood, we got select pine from the hardware store
It's twice the price of the cheap stuff, but still cheap, and it's easier to work with, and it looks nicer
There's a lot of options for hooks, like dowels, knobs, actual hooks
But we ended up with these bath towel hooks from Amazon
With our circular saw, we cut a 1x8 for the backing, and 1x4s for shelves
We have a quick tip for this at the end of the video
We also cut a square dowel to make a lip for the smaller shelf to hold mail
We did a dry fit to make sure it all looked right, and then gave it a light sanding
On the back, we marked where we wanted our long shelf to be, and three points to drill through into it
We drilled pilot holes through just the backing first, and then we clamped on our shelf piece and drilled into that
We should have used more that one clamp because it shifted, but luckily it was ok
Then we did the same thing to screw the dowel to the smaller shelf
It was a little misaligned, so we sanded down the ends
Yes! Now it's time for magnets
The magnets we used have a 3/8 inch diameter and are 1/4 inch long
We put a piece of tape on our drill bit to help us drill to the right depth
Then we used our favorite CA glue to secure the magnet in
Once you do that, panic cause you don't know where your hammer is
And grab a 2x4 to hammer it in

Hey! Perfect!
That's one way to do it
We attached the little shelf with screws, and took the whole thing outside to stain
Nice!
It makes the end look so much better
We did two coats of shellac, which is sooo easy to work with
and sanded with 600 grit sandpaper really lightly after each coat
Then we applied some Briwax and buffed it out by hand
And now, all that's left is hardware
We marked and pre-drilled the holes
We used our favorite screwdriver to drive these in by hand
since they were a little close to the edge
Then we added rubber feat so it'd hang straight, and not mark up the wall
Next, we attached our hooks
Side note: These were awesome cause they were really long, and way cheaper than anything else we found
Should we go?
Thank you guys for watching!
*laugh*
If you want to see what we're up to next, you can follow us on Instagram
And for detailed plans, we have links below
And don't forget to subscribe, if you haven't already
Thank you!
OK, quick tip time!
Lining up your circular saw blade can be tricky, so here's how to make a little jig for accurate cuts
First, raise the blade so that it won't cut all the way through the wood
Then, clamp a speed square to some scrap wood
mark a line along it, and cut a groove using the speed square as a guide
Now you have a guide that shows you a line where your speed square should be, and a groove where your blade will cut
You could cut all the way through the wood, instead of doing a groove
But we like the groove, because it shows the thickness of the cut
*beep*
*hahahaha!*
*beep*
Do be do. Do be do be do
Do
You ready?
*beep*
Nooooo!!!
*beep*
The entry shelf...
Our entry waaaaay...
It's a haunted entryway
Entry-waaaaa
aaaaayyy!!!
*beep*

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: what's going on everybody I'm Johnny Brook welcome back to another crafted magazine video in this video I'm going to show you how to build these simple live-edge shelves stay tuned the first step in this build was trimming a little width off of the slab and creating a clean straight edge on one side I usually treks off for this but you could also use a circular saw with a straight edge this slab was an off cut from a larger slab I used to build a coffee table previously and there was a little epoxy left over from that build so I removed it with a chisel next I skip playing the slab I didn't need this to be dead flat just roughly flattened and the surface cleaned up a little bit the piece was too wide for my jointer but skip planing got it close enough this involved taking a little bit off of each side of the slab turning it over between passes until it was flat on both sides after planing I took the slab to the jointer and jointed one edge squaring up with the face of the slab next I cut the pieces I needed for the two shelves from the larger slab at the miter saw I squared up each end and then cut my shelves to length which ended up being about 24 inches each I've had this slab for over a year at this point and the bark is still holding on tight and I really liked the look of the slab with the bark on so I decided to leave it there was a small section of loose bark that I decided to reinforce with a little five-minute epoxy I just mixed it up filled the gap between the slab and the bark and clamped it in place I did this on the underside of the shelf so you won't see the epoxy in the final piece next I sanded the shelves working my way through the grits starting at 80 grit then moving to 120 grit after sanding with 120 I rounded over the edges of the shelves with an eighth inch radius round over bit and then finished sanding with 180 grit I like to use my round over bit right before my final sanding as it keeps the round over from being too affected by the sanding and also helps to remove any tool marks from the router for the finish on this project I use Danish oil now I just followed the instructions on the can flooding the surface and keeping the surface wet for the first coat the wood will absorb a ton of finish on the first coat - just make sure to stay close by and keep a flying finish once the wood stops absorbing the oil as quickly I let this first coat dry for about 30 minutes and then come back and do the same thing flooding the surface I let the second coat sit for about ten minutes and then wiped off any excess also make sure to lay your rags out to dry completely and unfold them before doing so if you can't do this outside on maybe your driveway somewhere that's concrete not flammable these folded rags with oil-based finish can actually spontaneously combust and you definitely don't want that to happen in a room full of sawdust and dry wood so I let the finish dry for about three days and lightly buffed out any surface imperfections with a thousand grit sanding pad and this left a really nice smooth matte finish which was exactly what I was looking for next it was time to mount the shelves the first set of brackets I tried were a metal kind of French cleat set that I found at my local Home Center these are designed for hanging picture frames and canvases and unfortunately it turned out that the bracket relied on being able to rest on the back of the piece to provide stability and my shelves just weren't thick enough I really wanted to get that floating look but this hardware just didn't work and I didn't have time to try any other options if you have a recommendation for another kind of floating hardware that would have worked in this project let me know in the comments section i found another set of more traditional brackets in my local home center and use them instead making sure the brackets were level and plumb last i attached the shelves to the brackets with a few one inch screws from below and they were done alright guys thank you so much for watching hopefully you enjoyed this project it was relatively simple but ended up being a little more complex than I initially expected it to be especially the little bit of a hiccup with the shelf brackets I was really hoping those floating brackets would work out if you like this video please give it a thumbs up and leave a comment telling me what you liked about the video it's very helpful for us also if you don't already go ahead and get subscribed we have new project videos every tuesday and new weekly maker roundups every Thursday and last if you want a little bit of a behind-the-scenes look at some of our projects and want to help support us check out our patreon page it's patreon.com slash crafted magazine alright guys I think that's going to do it thanks for watching and until next time happy building

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hi I'm Stephen with Alberta urban gardens CA growing indoors is a fantastic way to spend the winter months the best part of all is it doesn't have to be complicated nor does it have to cost a lot on today's episode I'm going to go through how I built this gross station behind me and the cost of the project if you have access to a self or south west facing window you can use something like a bookshelf that you may already have laying around the house or build a temporary structure like I have over the last few years with that in mind I grow indoors most winters so I finally thought I'd invest in a permanent structure I added the lower shelf in order to double my growing space for this project I've purchased six bell brackets to support the shelves on the wall there are cheaper brackets out there however we decided to go with ones that look a little nicer as the squirrel space is highly visible within my home the next piece is the Shelf itself for that we've picked up two panels of laminated lumber that are just about the length of the window as there are no studs in the center of the window I've also purchased dry wall mounts if you're going to do the same I recommend getting the highest weight rated mounts possible as once you have your plants soil and water on top you don't want them to fail you will also need a measuring tape pencil level stud finder and drill for this build i will be using the length of the window for my growing area as such i will measure and Mark the center of the window and extend the line all the way down the center of the wall using a level to keep it true this will mark the location for the center brackets if you have a stud finder locate the studs under your window it will greatly improve the strength of the Shelf itself if the brackets are secured to the studs I generally mark them using a pencil trace the shelf on the wall this will set your height for the first bracket now that you have traced the shelf line make sure to offset the brackets on each side of the window the same amount this is important as it will evenly distribute the load preventing future failures to install the bracket install the first screw and using a level mark and install the second screw is important that the brackets are level for the remaining two brackets i use the shelf and a level to set their height once all three brackets are installed I mark the center of the shelf and line it up with the center line on the window it is now time to make sure the shelf is level in my case it was level from right to left but not front to back in order to fix this I've installed shims between the bracket and the shelf near the back I find paint mixing sticks are wonderful for this purpose pre-drilling will help prevent cracking once the Shelf is level you can now secure the brackets to the shelf using screws that will not penetrate the surface of the shelf once I had the first shelf up it was simply a matter of repeating the title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: welcome to the will hi product installation video here we will go over the best way to install your new Willa hide product first make sure you have all the necessary tools needed for the job you will need a drill stud finder tape measure level and a pencil to make marks a sheetrock saw will be needed if you are installing the picture frame or mirror here we will be installing the floating shelf first remove all the items in the box ensure you have two screws and drill bit that come with it next use your stud finder to find the studs where you'll be installing the shelf remember the stud should be about 16 inches apart mark each end from there measure the height that you would like the floating shelf to be installed at and mark that now we will remove the inner drawer box carefully slide it out and use both hands to push the black tabs on each side separating the shelf from the inner drawer box then match up the drawer box with the marks you have made ensuring they match up time to start drilling find the drill bit that came with the shelf and place it in your drill you may need help find someone to hold the drawer box while you drill when you start make sure you can see the marks you made so the drill goes in the correct spot you may want to use a level after the first drill to make sure the Shelf is still straight once you are sure go ahead and install the last screw before you place a shelf back on make sure the inner metal slide is brought to the front of the shelf then line up the Shelf with a drawer box and slide it on making sure it locks into place finally place the pan into the lock at the base of the shelf and it should drop right in if the pin is having difficulty dropping into place for example if you are forcing it in then is a simple matter to adjust grab a drill or screwdriver and loosen the metal plate where the lock is located adjusting where it sits until the pin is able to drop in with no issues congratulations you've successfully installed the will hide floating shelf thank you for choosing willa hide

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: I am measuring my wall for feed board I'm going to cover the walls with beadboard and then put some shelves up this is a plywood beadboard purchase from my local lumberyard it's more rigid than the MDF stuff available at home improvement stores I marked my stud location on the countertop and ceiling before I covered the wall so I'd know where to shoot my nails I applied some caulk to the wall in my seam area to help adhere the smaller piece because there wasn't a stud behind it in which to nail I did nail it on the right side into the stud that was available the two ends of the beadboard form a half lap joint and the seam hides really well the beat board came primed so all I had to do was paint I'm using a high-gloss paint in my pantry I also needed to paint my face frames and do some touch-ups inside my cabinet this area looks very blue and I think it's because of the countertop that it's darker back here so hopefully when I put the light in up here it will look better and I'm gonna deal with that I'm just gonna keep moving ahead with what materials that I've currently got and floating shelves is what's on the agenda for today so that's what I'm doing getting these heavy four by eight sheets of plywood up onto my workbench is always quite a chore that requires a little creativity I've built a lot of floating shelves in my past and I've always used two by two as the ribs I'm trying something different this time and using 3/4 inch sanded ply on the vertical I ripped a ton of one and a half inch strips and then decided I needed to plan out exactly how many shelves I thought I wanted to build so I'm having a really hard time dissipating what I'm going to want to store on the shelves in here I don't want to waste space so I think I'm going to do is the first shelf and then work my way up because I want to visualize as I go what I want to do next I may have the shelves be different you know vary in height in between them yeah that's what I want to do I started out using pocket screws because I did not want to screw through the end grain on the one and a half inch strip but after the top rail was on I didn't have room to get the second set of screws driven in so I resorted to glue nails and screws through the face I shot two nails and put one screw into each side of each spine I built this first shelf only eight inches deep and I'm installing it at 20 inches above the finished countertop height once I have this shelf in place I decided I wanted the rest of the shelves to be 12 inches deep so I went down and made three more shelves I skipped the whole step of drilling all the useless pocket holes this time and just used glue nails and screws to secure these ribs together I used two spacer block to give me even spacing throughout the entire thing even though it's just a skeleton so who really cares I've built a total of four long shelf skeletons for the main wall and then four shorter ones that would go to the left of these making corner shelves of all of them it's just a lot of the same glue nail screw flip and repeat once I had all of the skeleton shelves built I took them out to the pantry and started installing them I measured the space in-between and secured each shelf with one screw I wanted to make sure I got the police met right before I worried about leveling I don't know that's not going to be very useful up there looking at this top shelf there's gonna be crown molding so I am a gain going to lower everything I'm gonna end up having some holes to patch but I think this will be better so I decided to undo all of the screws that I had secured and lower all of the shelves the bottom shelf I had actually leveled and secured in to all of the studs so I have a good amount of holes to patch the other shelves only had one screw each so it's not too bad I went ahead and leveled in every which way you can possibly level each shelf and secured them to the wall into every stud that they each hit for the corner shelves I clamped them to the existing shelf leveled them secure them to the wall and to the cabinet sometimes when I'm doing something that's easy I do it too fast and then I don't look at my notes and I made three of the longer shells instead through the short shelves so I just go and cut them down me too bad well I was hoping to be done today and it looks like it's gonna be one more week yeah there's a lot left to do so yeah alright bye guys see you next week

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: a couple weeks ago I finished a project to build some floating so that my cats could access a high perch in the house that they jump up to anyway so I scoured the internet and came up with some plans I changed them a little bit and I'm going to do a walkthrough on how I built these this first video is just going to be laying out how I did it and what makes them up I might do a second video on how to actually build one for anybody that doesn't do much woodworking anybody that's used to doing this should be able to just see what I've done and build it to their own specifications the three shelves I put in one right there one there a top one and then that's the area that they've been accessing so I built a fourth shelf that's going to go right in this area just to make it easier for them to run up the shelves so let's do a walk through on what this is and we'll go from there so this is the shelf before it's mounted here's the front edge here's the back edge it is basically a hollow shelf there's nothing much to these to hang them a lot of floating shelves use a single cleat that they mount off the wall and they put the shelf in - what I did was I made an extended cleat and cats already checking it out this board mounts to the wall I'm mounting it I've pre-drilled it so that it can mount 16 inches on center and I made - or I made a series of 4 protrusions that'll stick into the Shelf to add some extra support and take some of the load I glued these I stapled them and then when everything was dry I drilled them and ran one screw into them I think they're strong enough to support anything that my cats will throw at it there or she's trying to throw stuff at it right now the Shelf dimensions are pretty simple the overall shelf is 21 and a half inches by 8 inches wide weight cat doesn't make this easy inside the shell I used one by two and it runs the entire perimeter of the inside of the shelf so the plywood is quarter-inch I just nailed the plywood nailed and stapled the sari glued and stapled the plywood to the 1 by 2 and then I put a finish board on the outside that I did miter cuts on and then I round my edges a little bit just because of cats jumping around it the carpets the same carpet I just put in my house it's stapled down except for this back edge because I want to put screws in this back edge to hold the shelf to the cleat so I'm going to mount this to the wall and get it attached okay here's the cleat installed on the wall it's ready it's good and solid I do have it four screws in two studs and I'm just going to slide the outer shell on it's on now these holes are not pre-drilled into the cleat yet take a drill bits bent but it'll be enough that hole is going to be a bit of a problem I'm probably hitting a staple underneath so I'll address that that one grabbed really good this one grabbed really good pull this one out and just move the whole over about 3/4 of an inch and that's addressed just pick up these little flakes of sawdust and I just need to grab the stapler attach the back of this carpet and we're done okay I'm ready to do the last bit and staple the back of the carpet done I already have my product tester sitting on it just going to meet with her approval I do have my supervisor sitting right there just watching the goings-on so let's get these final staples in and if the camera mount wobbles it's because cheetah is attacking a camera like come on get out of there okay these staples do ride up a little bit I'm going to push them in with a hammer but the idea is I want just enough that the cats can't work that edge up and peel it back so this will hold it good enough but also if I need to take the Shelf off to paint the wall which looks like it's coming soon I can still get this apart so the last shelf is on and done this part of the project is done so now I have I can get back far enough I have four shelves that let them get on top of the curio cabinet and then I also have an insert up there that's carpeted my plan is to eventually take shelves all the way up toward the peak come back down right along that window so that they can get down onto their tree stand right there between the two windows since these are the first ones I've made of this design I'm going to see how these hold up when I do the further up shelves I'm probably going to make the cleats out of oak so that I have a little bit camera doesn't want to focus so that I have a little bit stronger of a support since I sit right below that so if anybody wants to make one of these they're simple they really don't take a lot of time I think they look pretty decent feel free to enhance the design one thing I didn't mention during the construction is why I picked eight inches wide as you can see a cat's less than 8 inches wide I didn't want to go really wide because as they get toward the edge just the just that weight shift out toward the edge is going to put more stress on where the mount is along the wall Plus with these guys running around these I was worried that if I gave it too far out I was going to create too many forces and it was going to be harder to keep to the wall I just picked eight-inch because it looked aesthetically pleasing to me you can make that choice on your own if you build one well that's it for this project caps are already up and playing on it thanks for watching and if anybody has any questions you can leave a comment below or if you're in the Savannah group you can comment when I post this link thanks a lot bye

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey everybody's Courtney with friend from gray house studio and today we have a super simple but equally awesome looking project to share with you guys Brent is going to show you how we built these bookshelves for a nursery I'm pretty excited about the bookshelves but I think I'm most excited about reading books like the stinky cheese man so I've still cracked it open but I looks like it promises to be interesting to get started I began by cutting a 1 by 6 board for the shelves to 20 inches long then I cut the same 1 by 6 inch board for the two sides 4 inches long I clamped a board to the fence to make both cuts exactly the same length the mounting plate on the back of the shelf is a 1 by 2 inch board cut 10 inches long this will go in the center of the shelf and it will be covered up by books that's why it's shorter than the whole shelf the last piece to cut is a 1 by 1 inch board that's 20 inches long to match the width of the shelf and that will be the front rail I cut multiple of these at the same time since I built four shelves to assemble each shelf I started by drilling two pilot holes to attach the 1 by 2 inch mounting plate to the back of the shelf I used wood glue and two 1 and 5/8 inch wood screws to attach each mounting plate to attach each sideboard I use 1/2 inch finishing nails and wood glue to attach the front rail I used to scrap one by two to place under the rail to hold it level with the bottom and give me the same spacing on each shelf I attached the rail through the side boards with finishing nails once all the shelves were assembled I used wood filler to fill in the holes on the side and painted the shelves white using a nap roller for a smooth finish before hanging the shelves I've marked on the wall where the wall studs were with painters tape then after centering and leveling each shelf I screwed the Shelf into the wall over the wall studs using 3-inch screws if you found this project interesting and video helpful be sure to click the like button below to let us know you want to see more videos like this subscribe to our YouTube channel so you don't miss more videos like this and leave us a comment in the comment section if you have any questions be sure to check out studio gray house comm for all the details on this project and to find more projects like it

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: I just made this floating shelf here where I can store my wallet random things from my pocket can also store some keys under it wasn't too hard to make I'm going to show you how I did it the Shelf is made with just two pieces of wood the main shelf part is 3/4 inch thick 4 inches deep and I've cut mine to 12 inches long the other piece of wood sits up front acts as a little lip it's thinner it's 1/2 inch thick by one and a half inches and also it runs the whole length to mount the shelf onto the wall so that it appears to be floating with no visible hanger I'm going to use a keyhole bit on a router a keyhole bit has two cutting edges a larger diameter cutting edge on the bottom and then a smaller diameter cutting edge farther up so the bit makes a t-shaped hole that mimics the same shape as a screw I'm going to drill a hole first same diameter as the bottom of the bit put the bit in move it a little bit which will make this keyhole shaped hole I'll have a screw in the wall the Shelf will will rest down onto the screw and it will hold tight I've got six half-inch rare earth magnets then I'm going to recess into the bottom of the shelf using a Forstner bit so that the bottom of the hole is nice and flat now I'm going to glue the front lip on to the front of the shell I'm just going to use wood glue I'm not going to use any screws or nails I think the glue will hold it not going to be a lot of force put on that front lip it's just there to prevent things from sliding off the shelf let that dry overnight and we can start sanding the stain i want to use is a 50/50 mixture of sedona red and red oak both from in wax so i'm just going to mix up a bit of that okay now it's time to apply the stain let's start on this side I'll let that dry overnight before I put on the finish I'm going to apply a couple layers of spray-on polyurethane for a little bit of protection I'm going to read drill these holes a little bit so that there's some bare wood for the glue to stick to I'm going to attach the magnets with some jb weld quick-set epoxy now it's just a matter of putting a couple screws in the wall and then hanging the shelf where there you go I think the Shelf turned out pretty well if you liked the video or found it helpful give it a thumbs up you can also subscribe to keep up to date with my newest videos thanks for watching

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: today we're going to make a floating shelf let's build that start out by measuring and figuring out how big you need your shelf to be mine is going to hold these items here I started out by setting my width roughly the size I needed just so the plywood was manageable I ripped this down to about 7 inches I could then cut this in half to make the top and bottom of my shelf i'm making a four-foot shelf so the 8-foot sheet got cut in half to make my top and bottom I then set a 45 degree on my table saw and I ripped a 45-degree angled down one edge of the two top and bottom pieces once that 45 degree angle was cut I could then straighten my blade and cut the total width to six inches this will make the final width for my shelf this is the board I'm going to be used for my backing so I have about four inches to make the standoffs i'm going to set up a quick jig on my crosscut sled and i cut about nine standoffs four inches long out of this to buy one stock now I can minor each end of my top and bottom shelf to a 45 degree angle now we can use wood glue and Brad nails to anchor our standoffs in the corner of our top plate make sure that the piece is flush with the beveled edge and not the flat edge d left now i'm just going to tack it on with a couple brad nails while the glue dries i'm going to put one of these blocks on each end of my top plate it's very important that you line up these as close as you can to that minor because that will control how your edges will turn out on your final shell now that the front and back Ron I'm just going to anchor three more evenly spaced throughout the middle of my forefoot show now I'm going to put some glue on the standoffs and line up my top plate and bottom plate once these are all lined up I can clamp them in place and use Brad nails to tack everything together the final width of my shelf is two and a half inches I'm going to rip a three inch piece of plywood just to make it manageable now and can take the plywood and put a 45 degree bevel on one edge once the 45 degrees done I can mark my two and a half inch width and cut a 45 degree on the opposite side with the original cut facing the fence slowly nibble in and adjust your blade until you reach the width of two and a half inches this will make sure that your face of board will fit nicely in your shell once those 45s are cut we can then place it on our shelf and measure it should be at four feet but if you have a different shelf then you can make it whatever it is and cut to 45 bevels on each and making sure the front fascia lines up with the corners of these tops and bottoms now you can put the fascia and place apply some wood glue and tack it down with Brad nails with the leftover fascia scrap I'm just going to cut to end panels longer than six inches it's easier to cut them on the 45 and then measure the straight so I cut my 45 line it up and figure out where my backside which is a 90 degree cut will be now I can just cut those on the crosscut sled get using glue and Brad nails again we're going to anchor the end cap in place making sure you line up all your edges to get it as clean as possible to make your mounting bracket you're going to cut some stock four inches shorter than your overall shell plane I'm then going to attach the remaining stocks would cut earlier to each end and two equally spaced between the end I'm just using wood glue and one brad nail to tack these in place we can now pre drill two holes in each piece and anchor it with wood screws this will give it more strength than just the glue and the brad all together it'll make for a strong bracket now we can take some wood putty and fill in all our holes and all our seams make sure this putty is sandable and stainable if you plan on staining and not painting your shell once the fillers dry you can sand your shelf with an orbital sander or a handstand or whatever you have you just want to smooth out everything now i'm just applying a coat of stain to my shelf you could also paint it if you want it I just like to look a stained wood once it's dry it's time to hang it up to mount your shelf you're going to mount the bracket we built to the wall with a four-foot shelf you should be able to get three studs so I'm just measuring where my first stud is and anchoring it now I can use my level to find the other two studs and put those screws in with the Shelf being level this will anchor that bracket to the wall and make it very secure so it won't fall off a lot stronger than keyhole slots now you can take your shelf box and line up all the standoffs and smack your shelf lon mine was a pretty tight fit if yours isn't then you can easily just throw one screw up inside just to keep it from sliding off now you put all your decorations up on the shelf and stand back and admire your work so I hope you guys liked this project I hope it gave you some inspiration for something you can do in your house if you want a floating shelf this is a really nice way to do it gives you a good look without brackets and it's a lot stronger than just a standard off-the-shelf cat no pun intended off-the-shelf keyhole style mounting floating shelf you can put a lot more weight on these so if you like the project give it a thumbs up don't forget to share it with your friends and if you have any questions leave a comment if you want to see more videos like this feel free to subscribe to my channel you and I DIY I try and post here every Wednesday so thanks for watching thanks for coming out and I'll see you guys on the next project

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: well the folks over at remodel a holic comm contacted me about featuring and inside the door shelving unit that I've built for my laundry room now this was one of the very first projects that I did and before I started making videos so today I'm going to go ahead and build a second one on the inside of my shop door so that I can video the process now just because I'm putting it on a shop door keep in mind that you can very easily put this on whatever door you personally need it now this idea originally came from Anna White and I just adapted it to my needs and something to note is my doors are solid core doors meaning the inside is not hollow so imma be mounting my unit directly to the door however if you have more modern hollow core doors but be sure to check out anna's tutorial because she has a different method of mounting the unit to the door so I'm gonna get started I started this project by buying a piece of 3/4 inch plywood then using a temporary fence I cut it into seven inch strips now this does leave one board leftover that's not quite 7 inches however there's still we used for it later on I took two of the boards and cut them to length using the miter saw this will create the sides I took the cut offs from this as well as a whole nother board then use a stop block at the miter saw to cut up what will become all the shelves then using the same stop block setup I grab the board that was not quite seven inches and also cut it into pieces I took these to the tables all to rip down to one and a half inches with everything cut I started laying out marks for my pocket holes then stuck each piece of my jig and drill them out now before assembling I went ahead and gave everything a coat of primer let that dry and then came back and gave it a coat of paint with everything dry I started assembling it by putting on the bottom shelf first as you see I did not paint the inside because glue sticks better to an unpainted surface so to put on my shelves I would first measure where I wanted them clamp it down and then just screw them into place with the one side attached I went through and put glue on every end of the shelves then clamped on the second side then I stirred it up upside down to make attaching the shelves easier I would first make sure that the shelf was level then clamp it down and screw it in place then I went through and painted the inside when that was done drawing I flipped a unit right-side up and then started attaching those front bars since my color is our grand green I went ahead and came back with a green accent okay now I moved it into place using two by fours on the ground to act as spacers I made sure it was level then use the pocket holes that I drilled earlier to attach it to the door after loading it down I realized that screw boxes could actually fit on the side without interfering with the door shutting so I went ahead and added a few just to utilize some wasted space so this is a very easy project that will give you additional storage on whatever door you may need it for now something to note my door here has three hinges and since it's a shop there are actually commercial sized hinges but when I did this in my laundry room there were only two so I actually added a third one and also upgraded them to four inches because this is adding a considerable amount of weight to the door so keep that in mind if you tackle this project now I do have a set of downloadable plans on my website which is what conveys calm there's also a link in the description of the video for you and if you use the same dimensions that I use you can actually get two of these units from one sheet of plywood so if you wanted one for both doors then all you would need is one sheet of plywood so I hope that that's helpful and I would love to hear your comments of course below and I'll see you next time

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: welcome to DIY easy crafts calm how to make and easy do-it-yourself floating shelf gun safe now our design is kind of unique we hinge the front away from the shelf exposing the gun and this way all of the items that are on your shelf can remain in place when you're accessing this weapon this design is possible only because we're using cabinet hinges when I attempted several times to use piano hinges but just could not get an acceptable design that did not show the hinges or the secret compartment now I ended up using mortise full overlay cup hinges are available at your local hardware store there is a complete materials list as well as plans about available as a PDF downloadable file from WWD iy easy crafts calm once you have all of the pieces cut to the correct sizes the assembly is actually very easy we're going to use a little wood glue and some screws to attach each piece what we're watching here is the back wall which is going to attach to the wall in the home getting attached to the bottom of the shelf this is the first assembly but again a little bit of wood glue and some screws hold that together now assembling both sides of that wall assemble the only additional piece that's going to get attached to this is going to be the top of the shelf but that will get attached a little bit later once the sides are done we're going to move on to the second assembly that can assembly is basically the front wall of the shelf and two additional sides these sides will actually slide outside of these sides on the original back wall assembly and once again these are attached with wood glue and some screws now the size of this shelf was designed for this particular gun but you can modify the length and the width according to the particular firearm that you want to conceal when mounting the cabinet hinges you will have to buy a tool that attaches to your drill that's going to pour out a whole sort of hinge itself mounted plush the hinges are only seen on the inside of this floating shelf there's no exposed hinges are really anything that away the fact that that this shelf actually opens up and here you can see how the unit is going to fold open at this point we can attach the very top piece of the shelf and again that's used we're attaching it with wood glue in this case I'm not going to screw that top on to the existing wood I'm going to use some finishing nails we are going to see that entire entire top piece and it's a little easier to cover up those finishing nails if you had some clamps you could certainly attach that piece with wood glue and clamps rather than using finishing nails now the very bottom edge of the bottom of the shelf needs to be a sanded off a little bit you have to round that corner and you can do it with a file I'm just using a disc grinder with a sanding wheel the reason for this is that in order for it to fold out once the final molding in place it that final molding needs to clear that bottom edge the final molding actually drops down past that front wall so it conceals the entire front wall of the shelf and here you see that unit folding out even with the bottom molding in place once you know that everything functions that it folds as designed you can finish attaching the rest of the molding I actually sand it off the side edge of the molding just wear the one sidewall of both sidewalls meet the back wall sidewalls so that it slides together a little easier when you're opening and closing it now mounting this unit to the wall is very simple you find a stud with a stud finder and attach the unit at the desired height with about a three inch screw once that's holding it in place use a measure out 16 inches from that Center screw and I like to attach it permanently to the wall with some four inches four and a half inches long these will secure this shelf very very tightly to the wall and it will hold quite a bit of weight the finished product of course when you're looking at it you wouldn't even know that something was hidden inside please understand that this isn't true gun safe please do not ever leave the loaded gun inside this shelf you can see that our trigger lock is in place for additional information please check us out on the web at WWDC crafts calm be sure to check out our other how-to videos and please subscribe to this youtube channel you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: here's a set of shelves I designed that seemed to float against the wall with no visible means of support even though this project looks complicated to build it's really quite simple - oh why is you only need a table saw a bottle of glue a sharp chisel and a brad nailer the shelves are made from 36 inch hollow core bi-fold doors you can buy them at any Home Center for about $35 you can get four shelves out of one set of doors you can stain them paint em or add a decorative molding around the front and sides to match almost any decor take off the hinges and fill the screw holes with wood putty then paint or stain your door cut both panels down the middle using a table saw or an edge guiding a circular saw clean out the cardboard reinforcement strips with a sharp chisel work your way back to a bit over an inch and a half deep you're going to need to make a strip to fasten to the wall to hang the shelf to get this size correctly measure the gap this is how thick you'll cut the hanging strips from a two-by-four then cut the strips to length about a quarter of an inch shorter than the gap opening and then test the fit as you can see I drew a level line for the hanging strip mark the locations with masking tape then the Shelf ends with another strip of tape think this location out because once your shelf is installed let's just say you're committed hold the strip up then mark the stud locations onto the strip drill quarter inch holes where your stud locations are through the script hold the strip up to the wall and drill a pilot hole into the stud near the middle of the strip anchor that spot with the first leg screw repeat the step with the rest of the pre-drilled holes now that you've got the strip fastened to the wall with quarter inch by four inch lag screws it's time to glue the shelf in place apply some glue to the top of your strip and to the bottom of the door shelf flip the door on to your hanging strip then use your finish nailer to shoot one inch nails about every six inches through the door face and the bottom into the strip let the glue dry overnight and you're ready to load them up

content: what's up youtube this is LDS reliance does this look like your garage just stuff everywhere don't don't mind that but just there's none there's never enough room in a garage for building things and for organizational purposes so today I wanted to do a video and kind of show you a solution that I'm working on as you can see I've already started trying to paint the garage and make this a little bit nicer and more organized so what I did was I started with a French cleat system and basically what that consists of is these 45-degree angled cuts allow you to put the opposite piece the the opposite 45-degree cut attach it to the back of shelves or containers or whatever you've got and it creates a nice modular system for storing tools and supplies as you can see I've got all my screws and nails glue sealant so forth over here got a bunch of paint and stain and spray cans and so forth and then all my big gallon cans down there anyway it's a great way to get to get organizing and improve your storage so today what I'm going to do is I'm going to show you another piece that I'm building just just to kind of show you how easy this is is a do-it-yourself project but I've gone ahead and cut some some pieces too for the the side pieces for this for this next shelf and you can make it any dimension so it doesn't really matter what I cut it to or how I build this I just want to show you how easy it is to make this and how cool it is and how how flexible it is so I'm going to take these boards out and we'll get started making another shell so here we have the materials that we're going to need first up I have these two pieces of 2 feet by 4 feet OSB these are sold it's your big box Home Depot or Lowe's or whatever you've got as attic decking they're sold exactly as is their tongue and groove so one side will have a groove the other side will have a tongue and they slide together to lock in place which is really nice I just happen to have these left over front for something from something else if you've got plywood or something leftover that you want to use that's perfect I just happen to have these I wouldn't recommend using these going out and purchasing these for this type of project but I just happen to have them and they're going to work fine for the this this will provide the back so it's going to be 4 feet by 4 feet then these I cut these to 11 inches wide so again it doesn't matter I just wanted to be able to hang tools on this so my tool cases though the widest one was was about 11 inches so that's the the width I chose to cut them and so what I'm going to be doing is using my miter saw I'm going to cut these two lengths so obviously there's going to be a ring you know the outside edge is going to be boxed in and then in the middle I'm actually going to cut across this seam in the middle there's going to be two shelf so it'll be a total of three shelves where I can put things such as my my tool power tool boxes and chests that's what this is primarily going to be for so it needs to be it needs to be able to handle a lot of weight and and it needs to be big so that's why we have that now these these French cleats that I created and and attached to the wall they have they are each I've got them screwed in with heavy-duty screws in every stud I believe these were 16 inch on center so this is going to be able to hold a ton of weight and I'm going to make use of two of these I don't care emit like I haven't decided what which one I'm going to use but either this bottom one in the middle one or the middle one and the top row so I'll have they'll be clamped onto two of these cleats for extra support okay so I've got the bottom piece cut and once again with as with a lot of my projects I'm going to use a Kreg jig so that I can drill some holes on the bottom two pocket holes that will be hidden underneath and drill into the side boards on either side so I'm going to drill probably three pocket holes on each side all right got all the pieces glued and screwed together you'll notice the pocket holes on the bottom where they're screwed in at an angle so you won't be able to see that from the front or from the top and I'm going to let the glue dry for a couple hours and then we're going to glue it and screw it to the the back support or the back piece okay so now what I've done I've after this is try to carefully put this on top of the shelf and I'm going in with screws as you can see I've started here and screwing around the outside edges and then I'm going to measure where this the two shelves are in there and and put a row of screws as well just to hold give some extra support to the shelves okay now I've got the piece of French cleat that I've cut in the past as you can see it's got the 45 degree angle on the end there so what I need to do now is measure where I want the piece and then cut this to length so that it goes across the back and then so cut it to length and then screw and glue it to the back okay we got it screwed in there so obviously the cleat part points downward so this will be the bottom of the cabinet shelf whatever you want to call this so I put plenty of screws in it as you can see put glue on the other side so I'm going to let this dry for a couple hours and then I'm going to hang it up right over there and it should fit perfectly over there okay there we go we got it finished and hung up there sorry for the poor lighting but it's getting dark and it looks good I'll paint it white eventually to match everything else and it's going to hold all of my tool boxes tool carrying cases where we call him and then some so anyway this was a very easy project I use scraps that I had laying around and it took me probably continuously about an hour an hour and a half of labor a lot of the time was spent trying to capture this video and waiting for glue to dry so really really easy project just wanted to show off what you can do and when you want to move this stuff around you just lift it off of the wall and rearrange it that's the beauty of a French cleat system you don't you're not locked into some permanent thing where you've got it you know screwed or or anchored into the wall permanently so I really like these I encourage everyone to check them out and give them a try and thanks for watching guys

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hi I'm mark and today we're going to make this really large honeycomb floating ball shelf you can also make smaller versions of these and put them in any configuration you like I'm making the honeycomb out of five and a half inch pine or a hundred and forty millimeters the most important part is to get the angle cut at 30 degrees you can really make this whatever shape you like providing 50 total is 360 degrees and these are my six parts I used painters tape to tape the part up and gave it a quick test fit it was a little bit off but it was nothing to worry about there was no sound in this clip but I'm just adding some biscuits for a little bit of extra strength it also gives me a chance to explain my table saw which was meant to arrive but unfortunately there was a dispute with the supplier and I received my money back I am now making a table saw with this Bosch circular saw it's going to be a really fun build so stay tuned it's gonna be a really permanent table saw it's not going to be a quick mock-up so I really can't wait to get started on that so stay tuned and I'm gonna have heaps of build videos up for that I'm using type on to to glue it all up I really enjoy using this glue because it swells the joints and makes a really nice tight fit I'm using a Bessie band clamp to hold it all together while the glue dries for a couple hours for this part of the build you can be pretty creative I decided to add a center section and two sort of columns that will go up just to give it a bit of form and to add some dividers I gave it a quick sand with 120 grit around the outside and inside then I gave it a hand Sam's with 122 get rid of all the pencil marks and 240 grit on the outside and reduce swirl marks from the orbital sander I taped the inside we've just painters tape and use the sharp knife to trim it off so the stain doesn't get on the inside I'm really terrible at making a mess with stains so I decided to use some cling wrap over my MDF sheet was over my workbench but as you'll see I'm very messy with this though and this is just simple walnut stain and there's my mess I'm giving it two coats of fast-drying polyurethane Biman wax I learned this trick from Bob from I like to make stuff where you put a coat of spray lacquer in between the timber and the tape to seal the joins so you do not get any paint where you don't want for the color I chose this honey sort of yellow a good idea is to go to a hardware store and generally you can pick up samples very cheap or in this case a customer's spilt it so they gave me this one for free but there was only about half left after the paint dried I peeled off the tape I was happy with the results but I feel if I was to spray the paint on with a canned it would be a little bit better as you can see there there's a bead of paint from the foam brush any excess paint I just scraped off with a sharp knife then put a couple drops of stain the assembly was quite easy I just set it in place and used some bright nails to secure it I could then square up the dividers and bright nail them as well and it's complete I don't have a stud finder so I'm using some of these wall mates which you can pick up a box of them for about five dollars attaching them directly to the plaster and using a small Eldridge for secure the honeycomb to the wall and are using Craig screws because I feel they fit quite well in the wall mates I also attached a come from the bottom just for a bit of extra stability and it's now complete I was really happy with the results you can make this in a few hours providing your paint dries fast enough if you would like to see more hit that subscribe button and stay tuned for my next set of videos which is going to be the massive table-saw build thanks for watching

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey I'm Bob and I like to make stuff today we're going to make some inset floating shelves one thing Volusion for sponsoring this video Volusion has an all-in-one ecommerce solution if you want to start an online store they have all the tools you need to do it both they can help you build the site and they have a bunch of educational materials to help you get a business started Volusion is doing a really cool thing right now called stores and stripes it's for active US military spouses and veterans it's a way for you to get a business off the ground for $1 for a year you get an e-commerce store all the support all that stuff you give a $1 donation to Operation Homefront and they'll get you going be sure to check out Volusion thanks for sponsoring this video let's get to the shelves I had some friends who wanted some floating shelves that look like they were made out of a thick beam about two and a half inches I started with 1 by 12 pine for the top and the bottom but you could also use plywood for this for the faces I wanted to use pallet wood since it was going to be kind of a rustic look overall I trimmed off one end and then cut it to length and on the table saw I ran it through just to knock off one rough edge then I ripped down three pieces at two and a half inches to make the face of each one of the shelves to match the thickness of the face I needed to add some filler to the inside of the shelves I cut down some 3/4 inch pine down into strips of about 1 inch thick I cut down enough to be able to chop down sections so that I could put four sections inside of each one of the shelves then I just added some glue and laid them out they don't have to be placed very specifically here they just can't be on the ends I held them in place with Brad nails and then add a glue to the other side then I laid on the top panel to make sure that all the front faces were aligned I connected it all together with some Brad nails cover it all the front faces with glue and then added my actual shelf face I use lots of Brad nails to hold this in place this whole thing is going to look very rustic and it's going to be stained and so kind of the more damage you do at this point the more realistic it looks I used a rasp so just tear up this clean edge that I gotten from the table saw I made a lot of dents and scratches and just kind of mess it up on purpose and then I went back with an orbital sander and smoothed it out I left some of the dents and the imperfections there but I got rid of anything that would hurt you if you touched it and my friends wanted a really dark stain for this and I was hesitant at first but it ended up turning out really cool it blended the different types of wood together between the pine and whatever it was on the face from the pallet and I thought it worked out pretty well I'm not a big fan of staining usually but I like the way that these look the last thing to make were two more strips of pine for each one of the shelves then it was time for install we marked the center point for each one of the shelves I finally got to try out this new laser level from Leica I made my marks and lined up the laser with it and that made it super easy to transfer those marks to both sides of this inset normally an inset like this would be kind of a pain to get everything level but this device was really nice I'll put a link to it down in the description for each one of the brackets I transfer the marks on to a piece of pine and then I drilled a hole right through the center of it I made sure to transfer these so that I didn't accidentally drill through any grout lines I wanted to make sure I was drilling into brick I drilled the holes with a masonry bit and then I attached the bracket with some tapcon screws make sure you use the right size bit for the screws that you have the opposite side was drywall and I did basically the same process but I used the pine to drill some pilot holes then I used a bigger bit to make holes big enough for the anchors that I was going to use these anchors hold about a hundred pounds of piece so between two of them on one side and the brick on the other side these shelves will be plenty strong then I screwed the brackets right into the anchors each one of the shelves just slides right onto the brackets they were a little tight which is a good thing and I had to kind of jam them in place but that made it so that there were no gaps on the outsides if yours weren't so tight you could run a small screw down through the top of each shelf into the bracket to secure it so title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: I'm going to show you how to make some honeycomb wall shelves it'll not only add some style to this wall it'll give you a place to put those little knickknacks as well taking my white wall and making it a real showpiece these are the tools and materials we're going to need to create honeycomb wall shelves so let's get started our first step is to cut a 30 degree miter on one end of our piece of timber after that we're going to measure mark and cut the same angle on the other end we'll do this for all six sides do your first miter then measure and then catch a second miter it's as simple as placing two pieces together gluing and nailing and then working around the other sides need to make sure that each joint and all the angles are correct otherwise it won't complete the honeycomb shape when it comes to pinning it we're going to pin the top and bottom pins on opposing angles to give it more strength so it won't fall apart we're in a finish off with one pin straight in the middle [Music] putting any holes and gaps wait for it to dry then give the whole thing a good scene that's the sanding done you can paint this up however you like we're going to give it a coat of clear which will bring out the natural color of the timber to secure it to the wall I've simply drilled a hole into the frame and then used a short piece of threaded rod into the frame to secure it to the wall as you can see you can add shelves or dividers simply by cutting those angles again slotting them in with a bit of glue and fix them in the FIR nail they add a little bit of style to the room as well as providing you with places where you can put those little knickknacks and things to make it look like a you can have just one or you can have a whole wall of honeycomb auric and they look fantastic it's taken this wall from this to this

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: for a while now I've wanted to make a sunglasses holder so that I don't have to have these sunglasses on my bedside table which takes up a lot of space and I didn't really have any other place to put them now for a while i was thinking of all these different complicated ways to hold my sunglasses and recently I came along matt crowe Moniz video on his floating shelf that he made and I thought that would be a great way to store my sunglasses so I ended up making one of those myself and not with one piece of wood but with three different pieces I used walnut oak and cherry and it seemed turn out pretty good so let's go through the steps and show you how to make this I'm going to start by cutting this piece down so I can run it through the planer alright so now what i've done is i just trimmed down this piece of oak and this piece of walnut to fit better with this piece of cherry and then I glued and clamped everything up and I'm basically just going to wait for this to dry until we can move on to the next step all right and after cleaning up both of the sides i ended up cutting this to final length now it doesn't really matter the length just whatever or whatever length shelf you want and so next I'm going to write out the cavity in the back to hold this on a French cleat system now here would have done is I've set up the router table to cut this section out in the back of the shelf here so that I can put the French cleats now I would do this with the router out of the router table however I don't have an edge guide for my router so it's easier for me to do it in the table with a fence and a couple marks for where I start and stop alright so I've got this cavity here cut out and I clean this side up a little bit and still working on this side here but basically this is where the French cleat is going to go and it's going to be two small pieces of plywood in here and so basically I just need to finish cleaning this up and then we could put one of the sides of the French cleat in here right so what I've done here is cut out of French cleat and it's pretty simple this piece is just three quarter by three quarter and it's the depth of and three quarter is also the depth of this slot here and so this piece will fit in like this and then I cut this bottom piece right here and this will fit in like that to hold this against the wall now it sticks up just a tiny bit so I'm going to have to sand that down but it's enough so that i can just sand it down afterwards and it should be pretty good and it should fit nice and snug against the wall so i'll go ahead and glue this top piece in now alright so after i finished gluing that back piece in there or the back French cleat what I did is I ended up standing this down and I also put a little champ around the edges just with the hand plane and I didn't really want much of a profile but the little chamfer looks pretty good and now i'm just applying a coat of wipe on poly urethane all right so right here you can see I've put a French cleat on the wall and this is just a little bit over 16 inches so I was able to get two screws one in each of the studs so this is on here nice and secure and now what I can do is just simply slide the shelf on and I can also move this left to right so that I can Center it on the wall or in between two things on the wall and it seems to work pretty good alright and that wraps up the floating shelf project this looks really nice I am really happy with how it came out and I might also make another one of these for downstairs because it just looks so nice now also the French cleat in the back is kind of cool because you can move it back and forth as you please so you can make fine adjustments to it once you hang it and I'm again I'm really happy with it if you liked this project please click the like button below and also subscribe to my channel thanks for watching
