content: hey there guys welcome back today I'm going to be working on yet another pallet project but hopefully this one's going to be a little bit cooler than the rest what I want to do is build a picture show you know that looks nice to put pictures on but I want to have it have an added feature of a hidden compartment either off the bottom or one of the sides and what I want to do with the compartment is put like a whiskey or a wine bottle and make some glasses in kind of an homage to the speakeasies of the Prohibition days I've always found that era very interesting and the ingenuity of the people interesting to hide things and have little secret levers and different things like that so that's what I want to do so I finally acquired some nice really nice straight pallet pieces obviously they have the normal pallet holes and stuff but as far as straight and true they're about as good as I can get four pallets so basically let me take this to the saw I'm going to build a box kind of format and then I'm going to kind of see what my method to get to my secret compartments going to be so give me a few minutes and we'll see if we can get turned out you now that the pieces are cut out I'll kind of show you my my thinking behind this basically we're going to go for just a block mantle style shelf but basically I kept one piece just the the standard pallet piece and that's going to you know I just kept that just has a nice traditional pallet look a couple holes on the front so this is going to act as the front of the shelf right here is going to act as the back as you'll know that's I ripped that down just to compensate for the roof here and then I also use some pieces of the same width to make the sides so these are going to be the sides and all of this is going to get glued and nailed together and then this piece is going to be the top which is going to leave us that cavity underneath for our flip out shelf all of this once I get it sanded and glued is going to be stained to kind of give it more of a consistent look and then I still need to figure out some sort of fancy little mechanism to open the shelf but let me get this put together and then we'll get on to the mechanism Oh you so the sanding is done and you'll see it looks quite a bit different than what it did with that grade pallet wood this was actually a big surprise to me the the difference of it was just pretty much the same gray color when I sanded it it really brought out I guess the natural tones in the wood not a big deal I think once we put some stain on it it's going to blend it all in but you know hopefully give it that rustic look but so far I'm liking it and you know I'm just going to leave those nails in there because I think it adds a little character but for the bottom and basically this is where the prohibition thing portion is going to be I just did just cut out a simple little piece to fit in there I'm not sure if I'm going to use hinges but you'll notice one side I have angled a little bit and that's basically just to show that you know once I get some hinges or however I'm going to do this for pivoting that lead edge is not going to rub when it closes so again this is going to be on the bottom like this and then that door is going to open from the bottom so not sure if I'm going to do hinges or not hopefully if I do they're not going to really poke out too much but maybe I'll come up with something else so I'm going to take it and stain it right now and then we'll see how it looks after that you so I'm finally down to figuring out what I was going to do for my little bottom hatch door here off the bottom of this and I've decided to you to go with little hinges I was looking around into my tools and I found this old skill a drill bit Forster bit box and it had really really nice small slim low-profile hinges so basically what I've done is just chiseled out a little recessed edge and basically if you look underneath it you're gonna be able to see the hinges but once it's in there it should fit flush down to where you know unless you're three and a half feet tall you're probably not going to see it real easy so let me get these installed and and then I'll get to working on the hidden latch piece now we've got the hinges installed I'll let you see them on the bottom there I think they turned out all right you know they really don't poke out that much but for the most part I think they have a pretty decent finish for pallet wood so the next part of the equation is to figure out my latch mechanism and I already did that so if you look up here at the natural holes of the the pallet wood where they had it nailed I took advantage of one of those and I added kind of a fake nail and what basically what my plan is is to use a magnet embedded in a picture frame and then when I wave it dragging along there that magnet is going to pull out a nail and allow the trap door to drop so now that that's all finished I'm going to add some leather straps or something like that that kind of looks vintage or period to hold a whiskey bottle and some glasses so the next piece you see will be it in action alright guys well it's finally installed and my wife was I kind enough to put some pictures on it for me and get me pictures to modify for the latch so come in here I'll show you the backside of this I found a little bit stronger magnet and I will paint it black but I wanted you to be able to see it pretty easy so basically all I have to do to release the hatch is take a little pressure off the bottom door put it right there you'll see the nail gets attached to it and voila there's my stash so let me show you a couple different angles of this and you know a little more detail of this and hopefully it's something you guys liked so thanks for watching as always and we'll see you next time Oh you

just makes it easier to glue the panel's up and have them have them flush then I clamp them outside because I don't have enough room for the project I'm working on inside I use these little blocks to keep its luck I used a jack plane to kind of smooth it out and give it a little bit of a little bit of a rustic look and then this is a piece of 3/4 inch cabinet grade plywood I believe it's pine that I cut my length and then I put box joints I figured for the cantilever of the sides holding the whole box and you know the front and the bottom and top I figured that box joints would be the strongest I don't show it here but I ripped these pieces down in half them and then right here I'm gluing them up making sure to get glue on every surface in contact with another service I ripped and then I'm putting to length my top and bottom I attached it with glue and finish nails then I laid out the center points for the they're essentially cabinet hinges here I'm using a force in her bit to drill out pockets for these hinges I salvaged these from a job so I wish I would have gotten I wish I would have gotten self-closing hinges after much talk it was decided that the box was too big so I ripped it down and then I mitered my veneer and attached it to the sides figured a miter joint wasn't easier because it edges this here I'm ripping down the top and bottom panels that I put the splines in and something this they had at the big-box store it's a child child safety you know tell proofing thing and it's a magnetic key a magnetic lock and I figured it had a the least amount of play after it was title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: so this is a project about making some simple shelves for my office area and I wanted to use some scrap plywood and two-by-fours the plywood was roughly 5/16 of an inch and I used the circular saw blade dado trick that Matthias Wandel shows on his site in pretty complete detail and using that method with with properly measured shims you can get within a couple thousands pretty easily and all I had to do was kind of clear the kerf out after cutting those dedos and I could glue the brackets together right away it was a press fit it probably didn't need to be clamped although I did throw a clamp on them after in order to make them all flush and nice I crosscut them to 90 degrees on the crosscut sled and that worked out pretty nice they each ended up a little bit different shape but that's fine for what I'm using it for and then I round it over the bottom of the bracket so that you don't catch your knuckles on it it looks a little bit nicer but for the most part these were kind of ugly anyway so I wasn't too concerned I drilled my pilot holes using a pocket whole bit and that always works pretty nicely after some sanding I was ready to install I like to use some painters tape when I'm marking out my studs because it's very unobtrusive and quick and once I had the height set I can just put the level up and put them all into the same level and a little couple scrap boards up there and there's Marcel thanks for watching

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: you welcome to extreme how to wear today I'm going to show you how to make your own custom shelves like these that appear to float on the wall with no visible support floating shelves appear to hover on the wall without mounting hardware they not only look cool but they optimize space by eliminating the shelf brackets the shelves are essentially made of flat hollow boxes I made mine using wooden cleat that fits inside the rear of the box and supports it from within decide the size and shape of your shelf as determined by its location for my design the edges are made of two by material but the upper and lower panels are made of quarter inch plywood since this is such a thin material it's smart to keep the shelves fairly shallow might extend only six inches away from the wall to make the edges I ripped some 2x4 boards in half lengthwise I then ripped the rounded edges off the two by two strips I cut the rabbet 3/4 inch wide on both sides of the 2 by 2 strips the grooves were cut by adjusting the blade depth to make intersecting partial rip cuts on the table saw next I cut the ends of the Shelf to 6 inches square on one end but mitered at 45 degrees on the other the front rail should have matching miters on each end and cut to the width of your floating shelf next measure the corners of the rabbits and cut the plywood to fit I fastened the miters with wood glue and finish nails countersink the nail heads and fill with wood bunny the plywood panel should fit snugly into the grooves I fastened the panel's using wood glue and pin Mills to make the mounting cleat I ripped the short sides off the grooved boards so that the t-shaped profile became shaped like the letter I cut the cleat to fit snugly between the sides of the shelf box I located the cleat on the wall where I wanted the shelf I then marked the locations of two wall studs on the cleat avoid marking a stud within one inch of the end of the cleat pre-drill the cleat for your mounting screws at the stud location level the cleat and fasten it into the wall studs with 3-inch screws slide the hollow shelf over the cleat and flush with the wall finally screw the box into the cleat every six to eight inches repeat the procedure for any additional shelves you

content: this wall in our bathroom looks bad we're going to create a hanging hoop shelf that is not only going to be functional but it's going to give this wall a bit of spunk these are all the tools and equipment we need to make our hoop frame shelves so let's get started I'm going to use black form ply for my shelving unit we're going to cut out the backplate and the shelves out of this one piece it's a standard size from 1200 millimeters by 600 the challenge to this project is we have to create a perfect circle for our backplate use a hacksaw blade which has holes in both ends nail it down and using a pencil trace out our circle grab the jigsaw and cut it out now that I've got my backplate I'm going to measure and cut my shelves the drop saw is a great tool to have in the shed it gives you such a precise cut the material light form fly it gives you a beautiful raw edge I'm using flexible ply for the outer frame of my shelf I'm going to cut it to size now I have all the components of my shelf cut you can see this material actually wraps around the circle of my base plate we have to make sure that this center shelf is attached to the center of our circle it's really important because this is our fixing point for our hoop I'm gonna fix mine off with little black screws I think they're going to look great just remember to pre-drill all your holes that way when you're using dress screws you won't burn all the heads now it's time to put my final shelf in I've pre-drilled holes in my base plate to make more fixings really easy work your way around the hoop just fixing off the ply where doesn't look amazing I can't wait to see this in the bathroom I finished mine off with this acrylic just to protect the timber remember what this space looks like the bathroom shelving doesn't have to be boring what an amazing difference

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: tonight I'm showing you my rustic floating shelf at first glance these shelves kind of look like a board sat on a wall which they are however there's still a bit of preparation required I started out with the rough sawn piece of eight quarter or two inch thick white oak which I plane down just enough to smooth out some of the surface while leaving the deeper sawmill cuts still visible this was the look I was going for in order to make it look rustic and not to drop on one edge i find it down completely smooth employers since that high to be in contact with the wall [Music] after measuring out the location and distance of support from the wall I transfer that dimension to the Shelf in order to drill this hole you need to drill bit that's five and a half inches long this is one of the few instances when a floor drill press is really handy although you can drill it by hand my drill press didn't have five and a half inches of travel so I had to drill the hole in two stages [Music] what's the hole is drilled I had to mortise out of pocket for the mounting plate these can be slightly oversized as long as they covered the plate for the finish I use the same stain that I've used on all the other boys in this bathroom in addition to a polyurethane copco locating the brackets to the wall is critical because if the brackets are off then your show forfeit when you try to slide it onto the wall after the brackets reinstall and the studs are installed the shelves should slide right under the step now as long as I don't know more than 50 pounds on each shelf I should be good thanks for watching [Music] you [Music]

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey guys it's Angela today's tutorial is going to be a home decor episode I decided to finally go ahead and tackle my dining room wall I was kind of throwing around ideas between hanging art and doing tutorial on how to do a picture wall and I was going to go mirror but there's so many mirrors in my house I cannot possibly add another mirror so what I decided to do is go ahead and do a custom coffee bar if you do not drink coffee obviously you can use this as a dessert bar as an hors d'oeuvre bar if you host people it could be a tea bar it could be an alcoholic bar anyways I just want to go ahead and show you how to do it how to customize it it's really really easy so don't be intimidated let's go ahead and start it and I'll see you at the end of the video so here is my dining room wall as you can see we have a vaulted ceiling so I wanted to do something a little more special what you'll need to create your coffee bar is two floating shelves and then we will also be creating a chalkboard wall to go behind it I'm using this piece of masonite just because I want a really smooth surface and I don't want to have to paint back over the wall when I leave if you decide to use the base tonight start by drilling two holes and the top corners now using a leveler and my console to balance the masonite I'm marking two spots on to the wall where I drilled the holes now I'm going to drill the holes into the wall and add the inker obviously I don't suggest balancing on things I've just been doing this for a really long time and my balance is really good so I'm comfortable standing on furniture now I'm going to go ahead and put that back and then I'm going to drill the holes through the board and into the anchor now remember if you don't mind painting over the wall when you move out you don't need to do this part now I'm going to be moving on to the floating shelves you can follow the instructions I'm taking the measurement as to where the bar will go that is going to hold my floating shelves you always want to use your leveler when doing these parts of the project as you can see I drilled my holes through the masonite now we are ready to start painting I'm going to go ahead and wipe it down and you want to go ahead and tape it off now like I said if you weren't going to use the masonite this is exactly what you would do you would just tape off a large square above a piece of furniture or whatever you would like and then you can go ahead and start painting I'm using a primer and then chalkboard paint and a sand block the primer I had tinted a light grey just to make sure that the chalkboard was nice and black the way I wanted to look now that the primer is done I'm going to give it a little sand obviously it has dried for a few hours and now I'm going to start my first coat of paint this is where you would begin if you didn't use the masonite board you would paint your wall and hang your shelves our first coat is done so now we can move on now that we have all of our anchors in place we have our masonite on the wall and we applied the paint it needs two hours to dry so I'm going to go ahead and run to Ikea and get some things for the coffee bar I was going to go to the goodwill but IKEA actually has really cute coffee sets that are like a dollar fifty so I'm going to go there like thirty dollar budget and go ahead and see what I can get and then when I come back I will finish the last coat of paint and we'll go ahead and put everything together quick painters tip to preserve your brush wrap it in a plastic bag and throw some tape around the handle and then put it in your refrigerator you can leave it in there up to a week even and when you unwrap it it'll still be nice and fresh now this is what I got at IKEA like I said I got some coffee sets this creates foam and espresso cup a few glasses for when I like to add alcohol to my coffee drinks a jar for tea bags and then a croissant or a cake tray now that the second coat is dried I can remove the painters tape and we can add the shelves and then we can start decorating I'm screwing the brace into the wall and then you simply slide the floating shelf onto the two rods floating shelves come with two stabilizer screws so you want to attach those and now I'm attaching the final shelf and we can decorate now let's have some fun and start decorating if you decide to switch around the design a little bit and don't want the coffee pot you could always switch it out for some candlesticks or anything you desire now that I have everything up and in place I have all the glasses in place everything's done no coffee bar is complete without custom chalk art so these are your options obviously I went to my goals and they didn't have a few things there and Martha Stewart does have a like a chalk ink thing that makes it really easy to apply chalk it doesn't smear but this does alarm big enough and they weren't what I wanted them to be so I put an ad on Craigslist for $25 for a tattoo artist to come over and do some custom chopper and this is the final I hope you guys enjoyed today's tutorial on how to customize and design your own coffee bar

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: today I'm going to make a set of DIY clothing shelves for less than seven dollars a piece and before we get started here's your list of materials to make this show it does not require a ton of tools I'm using one 8 foot piece of lumber for each shelf I'm going to start by cutting away the large pieces first and you can use a handsaw or you can use power tools depending on if you have them or not if you're using a circular saw you can use a speed square as a guide while you make your cut and of course if you have a miter saw this should make quick work of all these cuts and after all the pieces are cut I'll end up with 4 pieces of lumber measuring 32 inches and 4 pieces of lumber measuring at 6 inches if you're a bit more experienced then consider using miter cuts for the corner now apply wood glue to the joint to hold this entire ship together I'm going to use a half inch dowel I'm going to mark the dowel so that it goes through both pieces of wood and have to add in the first value you want to add a second one on the opposite side so you'll end up with two dollars per corner apply wood glue to the dowel and also place glue down in the holes hammer the dowel down into the hole until they hit a stopping point then take a saw and cut off the excess [Music] you can apply wood filler to fill in all the imperfections or you can leave it as it is which is the way I'm leaving it I'm just going to stand it down with 80 grit sandpaper and then come back with 120 and then 220 to finalize it the choice is all up to you you can paint it or stain it for me I'm going to use an oil rubs brown paint to paint the shells and I really like the way this paint looks because when the light hit it it has this nice rich look to it the paint itself it's pretty thick and after the second coat you see hardly any brush streak after the first coat of paint it had to actually look to it but after applying a second coat of paint the color really started to come up and here's a quick tip for you if you ever want to mount something on a wall and you just wanted to transfer it to the wall easily then this should work just fine for you here I'm going to take a piece of scrap wood I'm going to mark two holes exactly where I want the mounted holes to be then I transfer those holes over to the wood then I take the same piece of wood and I love with that too the walls mark those holes and it should line up every time now trace out the keyhole hanger onto the wood before you drill and here I'm going to take a bit to drill out the opening if you want to keep it simple and easy just surface-mount the keyhole hanger to the back of the shelf however if you want it to look much nicer and flat to the wall you'd want to consider mortising the keyhole hanger into the wood and I'll show you how you can do that with a drill bit and a razor blade [Music] and now when it comes to mounting the chef I'm going to find the center of the wood that I previously used to mark the mounting holes and once I find the center I'm going to use that wood and find the center within the opening that I wish to mount the shelf while holding the wood level mark the mounting holes to mount the shelves I'm going to use these plastic screw drywall anchors and each one of these hold up to 50 pounds [Music] if you're new to woodworking and you'd want to get started consider checking out my limited tools video playlist down in the description I will be back to post on limited tools projects starting next week I'm Glen with DIY creators and don't forget to like comment and subscribe I'll catch you on the next one

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: I know there are a lot of shelving systems out there and sometimes it's hard to choose which one is right for you but I have to confess I have a particular favorite I like it because it's easy to put up can support a lot of weight and it looks like it's almost floating on the wall it's made up of two parts the bracket right here and the shelf let me show you how it works first drill the mounting holes in the wall if the shopping bracket can't be screwed directly to the wall studs bore a hole through the drywall or plaster and insert one of these hollow wall anchors sometimes called moly bolts tighten the center screw on the anchor until it's snug and then back the screw completely out hold the mounting bracket in position and pass the screw through one of the pre-drilled holes insert the screw back into the anchor and retighten it finally slip the rear edge of the shelf into the bracket Channel and the Shelf is complete you know what I really like about this shelving system it puts the emphasis on what's being displayed rather than on bulky braces and brackets you can put a shelf like this in any room and on just about any kind of wall thanks for watching now for more home improvement videos and articles check out Ron Hazleton com

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
Jason: I'm going to show you how to build
a shelf. Now, it doesn't matter where you are or what
room you're in, everyone needs a shelf, for an iron in the laundry, or your tea and coffee
in your kitchen. I'm going to show you how to put it all together. The tools I'm going to use are the drill and
impact driver. I've got my tape measure, brackets, spirit
level, pencil, drill, and some fixings, a stud finder, some white paint, and the safety
gear, as well. I'm going to use the stud finder to locate
the studs so I know where to put my screws. These two marks that I have on the wall, the
center of the stud should be located right in the middle of those, so I'm just gonna
measure center and that will give me the center of our stud. That should be my stud. I'm going to position my shelf bracket over
the stud that I've marked on the wall. I'm gonna mark those three circles for the
screws. Before I screw anything off, I'm going to
drop my spirit level down the outside of it to make sure it's nice and plumb. Now that I have the marks, I'm gonna pre-drill
those holes and put my timber screws in there, fix the bracket to the wall. I'm screwing in the timber so I have pilot
holes into the stud. My bracket will sit in position. I will drive my timber screw in three positions. I've painted the top of the blank so it matches
the bracket itself. The reason I put that top screw in before
the middle one, the middle one is right close to that middle bracket, and if I put it in
there before I put the top one in, it'll push the bracket over. So bottom one first to secure it, top one
to keep it in position, middle one last. Now that my first bracket is up, I'm now gonna
mark the position for my second bracket. My shelf is 700 mill long. I'm gonna come in 100 mill from each end of
my shelf. My second bracket will be 500 mill across,
and I'm gonna measure that now and put a level line in here. I've marked out my three new holes. Ideally, your bracket's going in your timber
studs. In this case, I know there's no timber stud
here. I'm going to be using a wall anchor. What it does is it flares open behind the
plaster, so it'll lock in and hold this stud in position. Now that I've got my hole in the wall, I'm
going to push my anchor in there. To get it to work, I need to tighten that
up. Once it's tight, I take it out, and then fit
my bracket over the top of that. Now that I've got both of my brackets on the
wall, I'm going to put my shelf up there. All I need to do now is mark and pilot hole
the four holes so I can put my screws in. That's how you build a shelf. Singers: Bunnings Warehouse!

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
Shelving is a great way to organize and declutter
a space especially a corner. I'm going to show you how easy it is to make
a nice, clean corner shelf at a cost effective price. Let's turn this wasted space into a functional
corner and free up that much needed floor space. These are the materials and tools required
to build a corner shelf. This particular piece has been pre-cut at
Bunnings but you can have yours cut to any length. All that will be required is to cut it on
a 45-degree angle when you get it home. Mark and measure out your 45-degree miter
joint and then cut it. Now the miter joint is being done, you need
to measure top, bottom and center so you know where to drill the holes for the dowels. Now drill the holes for the dowels to go into
the shelves. A handy little tip is to use half the measuring
length of the dowel against your actual drill bit and mark it with a bit of masking tape
so you don't go too deep. Repeat the same process on the other shelf
then use some PVA glue to secure the dowels. Put some glue in the holes on the other shelf
and run a little bit down the extra miter joint and join them together. Now push the two shelves together ensuring
that they're nice and flush with one another. Wait for the glue to dry and then sand off
any rough edges. Measure and mark the desired height of the
two shelves in the corner of your room making sure that they are nice and level. Find the studs, screw the flanges to the studs. Place shelves up onto the pipes in the corner. Screw the pipes onto the ends of the pipes
to give it a really nice finish. The corner shelving is now being finished
and turned into a functional space. We've painted our shelving but you can do
at any color you like or leave it natural. They are so easy to make. Not only this corner shelving a great storage
solution but it's also a fantastic feature for the style of the room.

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: today I will show you how to build this modern TV stand the lower portion of the stand will include square storage compartments for my electronic equipment the television will be in the central part and modern-style shelves will be added above it the necessary cable conduits and all the cabling have been installed beforehand first begin by tracing the outline of the TV stand onto the wall cut your metallic studs to the desired length here I'm using a tool called a nibbler it is easy to use and cuts with great precision now drill holes into the studs for the fixing screws the tips of the screws will allow you to mark the wall and help you know where you will need to drill drill into the wall for plasterboard walls I advise inserting a hollow wall anchor first now screw the metallic studs into the wall place a small candle block inside the stud it will come in handy later fix all the metallic studs to the wall the metallic structure is assembled much like a Meccano kit using key new blocks and metallic studs the structure is then connected to the studs on the wall with the small cube blocks we inserted earlier before fixing the MDF petals drill countersink holes to hide the screw heads I can easily adjust the structure by sliding the metallic studs into the cube blocks with key note I am certain that my construction is straight and properly positioned along the plasterboard clamp everything together before screwing the panel and please continue building the metallic structure with the key new blocks complete the structure with 6 millimeter MDF panels and insert polyester to reduce noise fix a metallic stud onto the wall and insert a small key nook block inside the horizontal stud notice that the structure is not fixed into the floor there is no need to damage your tiling as with this type of construction the TV stand will be sufficiently stable once finished continue building the structure one by one screw the MDF panels into place crimping small pieces of stud onto the horizontal track will create a support for the lower panels it is absolutely key that your MD of panels be carefully cut to the required dimensions this will ensure that everything fits well together now onto the lower central box with the help of two cube blocks I can easily fix a metallic stud onto the vertical panel continue building the structure and complete it with panels for the long horizontal shelf I'll be using an aluminum foot which will serve as a solid support the lower MDF panel is six millimeter thick plaster board moving on to the side of the stand start off by screwing a small piece of stud onto the existing horizontal panels this side panel will provide a solid base to work with for the upper long horizontal shelf once assembled the structure is extremely solid here's proof for you I can now start to work on the upper horizontal shelf in the same way as before build the last shelf by starting with a vertical part to guarantee a solid base for the horizontal shelves cutting your panels precisely will reduce the amount of finishing touches required voila all that is left to do is to band the edges apply acrylic sealant before screwing the edge panels in once Cruden remove the excess sealant for the edges I'm using six centimeter wide MDF slats cover up the screw holes with wood filler fill in the gaps between the slats with acrylic sealant sandé apply finishing compound sand lightly and here we are the TV sand is finished all that is left to do is to apply a couple of coats effect you log on to WKYT s and tips

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: what's happening guys is Glenn with DIY creators and today I'm going to be making a floating bookshelf a lot of angles a lot of cuts and a whole lot of patience so yeah let's do it this video is sponsored by video blogs before I started this project I wanted three things modern unique and bold this shelf was for a small area which I wanted it to be no longer than 48 inches it had to be functional beautiful and after making a rough sketch I was happy with what I saw this project calls for a lot of angles which could make it a bit difficult for a project to tackle with no real planning I guessed on the angle of 20 degrees and I started from there I made my first cut at 30 inches for the trim using 1 by 3 pine I lined up the to trim and made a mark then I set the miter gauge to 50 degrees for the second cut after every cut I set up the trim just to give me a visual that I was on the right path and the next Bend I need to make in the term has to be parallel to the first cut I used the aluminum tubing to carry out the line took a piece of wood place it on the line and marked above it and now I'm going to cut on the line which is the next bend in the trim and for the next cut I just measured from the bottom of the trim carry that out 18 inches wherever that land then that's where I cut then I cut off that piece of trim down on the miter saw and while I was at it I cut the two ends off for the shelf since the depth of the Shelf is 10 inches I make the trim nine point five inches and that's it behind the front trim I also cut the plywood down to nine and a half inches as well now making a frame can be tricky because it requires a lot of angles without a hanger finder I'd have a hard time making this happen the angle of this piece is 110 degrees and I need two pieces of plywood to meet up in the corner and for me to find the angle of that I divided the 110 in half which put me at 55 degrees I subtracted that from 90 which gave me the value of 35 degrees then I made my first cut the corner of a square is 90 degrees and that's where I got the 90 from now mark this piece of wood just past the bottom of the trim that's adjacent to it and I used the same method to find all the other angles so here's where it really starting to get tricky if you notice that this corner is very pointed and that's a 50 degree angle at the very top now my table saw does not go to 50 it stops at 45 and the only way for me to make this cut was making a jig I'm not sure what something like this is even called or if it even exists I do plan to study it and make some improvement to it and I'll share with you guys in a later video being that it is on hinges makes it extremely flexible to pretty much set whatever angle you need to cut on the table saw and I'm taking a piece of wood here and I'm attaching it to the bottom of it because this is how I'm going to support the swing of it and then I'll just install the screw in the side and lock it in place I also added another piece of wood on the opposite side so that I can clamp it onto the sled now using the angle finder I can set the angle that I need and now screw the jig in place so that it's fixed then using a test piece to make sure that the angle is correct the angle looks pretty good other than the freight edges I could take a sanding block and easy just clean that up and it should be good to go I did went on to make the final cut on the work piece now I was not perfect you know I wish I got a better cut out of it but the cut that I did get it was workable and I was able to work around it and make it work just fine and to get another visual of it before going to the nailing in the gluing process I wanted to make sure that it all fits together just fine and while I'm working on that in the background I'm going to take a few seconds to tell you guys about videoblocks who has the largest unlimited download library of stock video motion background and After Effects just like the one you seen in the beginning of the video with the video block membership you get access to over 10 million dollars worth of content and over 2 million stock videos after effects in motion background at your disposal and that 40% off per clip compared to video blocks competitors and over 100,000 free clips video block takes 0% on commission on its cells passing all the savings on to its members during a 7 day free trial you can download 140 pieces of content and if you like the test drive you can sign up for an annual plan which is 149 dollars a year to get unlimited access to their library all membership come with a hundred percent royalty free agreement even if you can't see your membership the agreement is still valid for your downloaded content for your personal and commercial use forever and to check them out just click the link in the video description or go to videoblocks comm /youtube and as shown in the video I'm using the wood glue and I'm using nail gun and for the nail gun I started in the corners and work my way out to the ends using one by three trim and 3/4 inch plywood that gave me a slim space for my wall bracket so I had to beef up the wall bracket the best I could so that I can believe in the strength of it I cut the bracket to a 1 inch thickness on the table saw set a stop block to 8 inches to make repetitive cuts for the arms on the bracket I want the location of the studs on the bracket then place two arms outside the stud and two arms inside the stud trace the arms about a half inch in on the back of the bracket now for this dado cut I'm going to use my table saw but you can use a few different method a circle saw a table saw a router a hand chisel or even a hand saw there's many ways to get this done when using a table saw it's best to get the out edge first and then work your way to the inside now apply glue and insert the arms and this should be pretty snug if it's not then insert some shim to make it tight and remember the plywood I'm using is 3/4 inch thick and that alone is pretty heavy so I added some l-bracket on the side to make the arms even that much stronger I only added he'll bracket on one side of the arm but if you're cautious then you can also add them on both sides and I use the same method for the remainder of the bracket and to finish up the bracket I added 1/3 inch screws from the back now one thing to point out I did find the studs in the wall before I made the bracket and to mount the bracket I'm going to use quarter inch screws three inches long now as you can see I marked all over the wall because the wall need painting I did not have to do all that it just made my life a little easier so I can get back and see the visual of what a shelf is going to be in your case you could have used tape or you can have somebody hold the shelf in place until you find the right spot for it and I also made a small bracket to support the weight of the suspended end of the shelf now this should help support the weight and one thing to notice that I can only fit this in one of the studs so the other hole have to go right into the drywall and of course you don't want to run a screw right into the drywall so in my case I'm going to use some Hilty toggles and they're pretty slick and they're extremely strong and now for my least favorite part of woodworking and that's sanding and I'm going to try something a little different because I am experimenting trying to find ways to get better finish and what I wanted to do this time was sand first and then come back in with the wood filler and then just did a light sand again to remove the excess now overall I did see a bit of an improvement but I think I can do better in my future projects now the story behind this bookshelf is this should be an accident piece for the desk that I do plan to build and I went a little Bowl with the color so it's just paint and if it doesn't look the way I expected once both pieces done then I can always repaint it this is a paint and primer I don't recall the color of it the exact color but it is a lime green and it's made by Valspar and it's a satin finish so I really like this project and I loved the way it came out you know I'm really excited I can't wait to start building a desk that actually goes with this bookshelf and you know I never actually made a project of this magnitude that had so many angles on it and so many cut it was pretty sophisticated and I managed to pull it off at one point I was wondering what did I even get myself into but actually you know you take your time I did get through it and I'm really excited the way this one came out so you guys let me know what you think about this project down in the comment to let me know if this is something you want to see more style like this so I'll be waiting on that and also don't forget to hit the like button the share button and you can also catch me on social media I'm on facebook I'm on Instagram you can catch up with my projects and see what I'm doing behind the scenes so my links are down in the video description and I also have them on the screen as well so you guys don't forget to catch me on those and that's it for this one guys I'll catch you guys on the next one peace

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: every one I always felt that one of the walls in my room was pretty bare and so finally I decided that I wanted to build some shelves for my cat meat gremlin I previously built a cat food for him so I figured a few shelves would be nothing and the reason I wanted to make shelves for him partly was to put his food up there because my dog loves cat food and currently I keep his food on my dresser which my dog is now big enough to reach up there and get to it so I needed a place that was higher up to put that cat and I also just wanted to give him some high places that he could hang out on so today I'm going to show you guys how to make some of your own let's get started you'll need a heavy duty stapler that can also use Brad's or finishing nails a drill a jigsaw wood glue stain or whatever you want to use to finish your wood carpet food and water bowls with a lip around the edges brackets two hanging shelves one piece of wood an inch by one inch by 8-foot cut into three pieces that are 32 inches long four pieces of wood two inch by 1/4 inch by four-foot take three of the pieces and cut into two pieces that are 32 inches and 10 inches long what's the fourth piece cut three pieces that are 10 inches long I wanted a nice clean look so I used miter joints I made a total of three shelves but I only made two types one being a friggin water shelf with recessed bowls and the other being a simple carpeted shelf first things first you need to cut all the wood to size I don't have a work bench so I just do this kind of stuff on my floor I got the big piece of wood cut at the store but for the smaller pieces I whipped out my miter box and pull saw and got to measuring and cutting when you're cutting wood for a miter joint you want the proper measurement to be the smaller face of the wood like so only one end of the ten inch pieces need to be cut at an angle the other just need to be cut flat because they're going to be resting against the wall for the food and water shelf take your bowls and figure out the placement you want I decided to put one on each end since we're making recessed bowls we'll need to drill a hole into the wood that's big enough to fit the body of the bowl but small enough so the lip can't go through I flipped the bowl over and traced around the bull's lip and from there since the lip of the bowls I used was about 1/4 inch high I balled a smaller circle that was shrunk about 1/4 inch all the way around first drill a pilot hole on the inside of the small circle then simply stick the jigsaw in and trace the circle I left the larger circle intact as a guide of where - absolutely not let the jigsaw pass just in case time to test fit the bowl perfect repeat on the other side now we get to assemble these things and yes back on my floor again I really need a workbench apply glue and use the heavy duty stapler to tack the wood in place with Brad's or finishing nails I don't have clamps but since these won't be stress points you could get away with just using the Brad's to hold the wood in place while the glue dries repeat for each side and each shelf you may have noticed I had a gap where the wood didn't quite meet perfectly it's unfortunate but thankfully it's fixable you just have to squirt some glue into the gap sprinkle some sawdust into it squish it in and then sand the excess glue away so if we have this problem hopefully you haven't cleaned that workspace just yet it's not the prettiest but hey it's better than having a gap right there and for me I stand them a dark color so you can't even tell anymore and here's what the assembled food and water stuff looks like with the bowls in place it's coming together now just assemble the shelves that will have carpet in the same way but we're going to add the carpet after we finish the wood so let the glue dry overnight and then it's time to finish finish the shelves however you like I chose a dark stain apply the finish and let dry or cure as long as the directions say once they're dry it's time to attach the carpet first cut the carpet to the exact size of the big board which was 32 by 10 inches this is the same carpet that I used to make the cat tree that I had mentioned earlier I just went to my local hardware store and got a roll a remnant carpet for pretty cheap I still have so much of that stuff that I'm trying to figure out what to do with I put some glue on the wood and laid the carpet down I don't even know if the glue did anything because ultimately I stapled the carpet in place anyway but it made me feel better so I did it after I laid the carpet over the glue I stapled it in place I made sure to staple the crap out of this thing so the carpet would stay put if Grimm decided to use it as a flat scratching post and here are the finished shelves now we just got to hang them up I wish we had splurged a little to get nicer brackets to hang these up but that's too late now oh well I could probably update them later in stereotypical cat fashion he was totally unimpressed and didn't want to have anything to do with them but a little catnip and some cat toy action later and he finally got up on them and besides coming down to cuddle with me while I sleep he's been up there ever since I hope you'll enjoy I'm glad that they came out the way that I was picturing them in my head and it seems like grandma loves them too which is the whole reason I made them so that's good if you liked this video and want to see more then please subscribe and if you have any questions or suggestions for new videos then please leave a comment down below as always you can follow me on twitter tumblr or Instagram see you next week

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
AHH...I need some shelving. I had to stop and think about what it was
that I wanted for a while. So I put together a list of pros and cons and settled on a low profile open faced off the
floor shelf system. I'm going to need some boards with angles cut in them and I've already gone over how I do that in
another video. So head over their if you wanna know a simple and easy way to cut boards to an exact length with
angled ends. The bracket design I'm using is a simple L
shape with a cross piece. This is the top piece that the shelf material
will sit on. This is the back and that is done for a reason. So that gravity can be my friend and not my enemy. I decided to use this style in order to keep the front of the shelves completely open from one end to the other. Since I'm close to the end of this board I
will predrill these holes. For a materials and a cut list. Head over to my website Simply Easy DIY dot com.  Check the description.  I'll have all the links. A 
couple of spacers keeps my cross peice centered
on the other two boards. After 9 of those it's time for some clean
up. I have a very specific heigth I am placing
this first shelf. I have a future project in mind that is going to force me to put it slightly higher than I initially wanted. I don't have a laser level so I'll do this
the hard way. I suppose I could have chalked a line but oh well, this works. The studs in my garage are 24 inches on center so every other one gets a shelf bracket attached to it. That looks good. Lets keep going. Now that all the brakets are up, it's time
to cut some shelves. Lay down a few pieces on a flat or flat ish surface. Plop some half inch OSB down on them. And get to cuttin. To stiffin up these planks I'm going to glue
and tack a strip of 2 by 2 to the underside of each one. I have a program on my computer that allows
me to input all the materials I am working with and it spits back at me the shelf span I can have before I run the
risk of sagging shelves. So there were a couple constents I was working
with. I wanted each shelf to hold about 300 pounds and I wanted a 48 inch span between the supports. So in order to
accamplish that I needed a strip of 2 by 2 And another piece attached to the front. If
you want the exact sizes of these pieces I'll have everything listed on my website. Simply easy diy dot com. Check the
description. Hey thanks for watching, subscribe if you
haven't. Don't forget to check me out on Facebook and Pinterest. If you like this video, here's a couple more
you'll like as well. Until Then.

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
Hey everybody today I'm going to be building
more shelves on this side of this wall. I've already told you about what's happening
on the other side with the plasterboard This side is going to be much more heavy duty. I need something on this side where I can
throw bikes or the wheelbarrow against it. So what I've got is heavy duty industrial ply. Flooring grade 7 ply. Normally it would laid on a floor. You can see the tongue an groove to join all
the sheets together. Today I'm doing something a bit different,
I'm going to be using it to line this wall. It will become part of the shelving. The shelves themselves will be suspended from
the ceiling not held off the floor. They will be floating (at the back). There will be two shelves, the bottom part
will be completely vacant so I can run bikes against it. There will timber from the top to support
the shelf. The first at 1200mm off the floor and another at the mid-point. Let's go through the process of how to put
this all together. Once again I'm using bugle batten screws as
part of the fixing process, in this case I've already pre-drilled the holes. Two drills. One to pre-drill, the other to fix the screws. That is not going anywhere. They will be all around the perimeter and
in the middle of the sheet. I'm using left over material, showing how
you can use whatever you might have lying around The shelf will sit directly on the wall lining
up against the stud wall. You can see how it will be attached to this
front support. This is the ceiling support, built into the
ceiling frame and attached with bugle batten screws It has been perfectly aligned with the shelf
points. Each end has identical supports. The shelf is already made up. I've already attached the front support in
90x35. I'll bring that over and sit it on the wall lining and sit it temporarily on the ladder while I screw it together. Now we can take away the ladder and screw
down the back. That's the shelf in place. Supported at each end. Next piece is the back wall sheet which will
also support the next shelf. Like the bottom lining it will be fixed with screws. There's the backing all in place. Now it's time to attach the shelf, fully supported
by the wall lining. But first I'll show you how to attach the
front support. In this case it's easier to attach this cleat
first and lower the shelf onto it. Now fix the shelf and install the last wall
lining to stop things falling to the other side The sheets are not long enough to go all the
way across so I make up these infill pieces. Once again we are going against the mud brick
wall so I had to scribe out the line of the irregular wall. Then the remainder is attached to the raked ceiling. To work out the rake simply measure the height
at both ends Measure the length of your level shelf The angle will then be self determined. I'll fit some 2x1 on the front of the shelves
to protect the edge. You can see how strong the shelves are. They will not go anywhere. No cleat shelves, supported by the wall lining
and suspended from the ceiling. Thanks for watching! More videos coming soon.

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey what's up everybody its Glen and today I'm building the eight-foot floating shelf with hidden storage and under mount LEDs the wood I end up using was wood left over from my office desk bill I had just enough left over for me to cut two 12-inch panels from that stash I bought a piece of oak that was about three inches longer than the panel itself and I cut off one of the end had a 45-degree angle ident to the other side mark that and then cut that to a 45-degree angle I cut two trims to cover the edge of the panel only miter in one side a sandwich the two panels together to find out the depth of the spaces I need then I ripped a piece of wood on the table saw I mark and cut spacers down to size with the biscuit joiner I cut the face trim and only one of the side trim add the glue insert the biscuit and join the two with my term router I notched out a track to insert the LED strip over on the router table I use a horse nose bit to taper off the bottom of the trim to use as a pull handle to secure the top panel to the trim a mark location for the pocket holes before screwing the panels together I move my focus over to the drawers which I started by cutting the track side I took that piece over to the table router to knock out a slot and I did that for both sides I then cut out a small strip of wood on the table saw which I used as the tracks for the drawers cut those down to size and then it's on to the front and back of the drawer I then cut out the tracks for the cabinet bottom in all four pieces give it a quick like sand now normally I wouldn't cut a track this close to the edge but I wanted to maintain the space for the remotes that I'm planning to put in this drawer so I glued the box together to make sure that nothing comes apart and now I can come up and let it sit to dry check the square and to make sure everything is good and on to the next piece this piece of wood here will hold one side of the track for the drawer and now I can start assembling the shelf I can also install the spaces now but one issue with these spacers is if you notice they're really close to the edge and that doesn't make a lot of room for my mounting piece so later on in the build I had to cut those down with my router I used some coins as a spacer but you can also use washers or whatever it takes to create a small space and that's what I needed to mount these tracks correctly the LEDs I'm using for this project was leftover from my office desk build which actually worked out great because I got a chance to save some money and reuse the leftover piece I cut out in addition to track and you will see why later on in the build I'm using biscuit joiner for the bottom and even though you're not going to see it I wanted to accomplish a super clean look add a ton of glue insert the biscuit and now I can anchor it down to attach the drawer front I had to trim up against the drawer use my pin nailer to temporarily hold it and screws to finalize seems to sit really well but I had to fine-tune it later to make it sit even better I ripped my cover two by fours on the table saw to make the mounting bracket I used the trim router to cut out some dado slot for the extended arms the extended arm should have been tightly snugged in the slot but for the ones that weren't I use shim to tighten that up and I also glued and screw them from the back side once the brackets done this should look something like this and to get that out of my way I took it to the wall and mounted it in place using a lever to get it straight now I can give all the pieces a quick sand and once I'm done with the sanding I'll take a rag and I wipe off by the excessive dust then I apply the priest and conditioner that is sit for three to five minutes and we can wipe it on and once it's dry I hit it with the sender once again before applying this thing I had two cans of stain that was very similar in color but I couldn't figure out which one I wanted so what I did took title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
4.5 billion years in the making. But it would have gone faster with Microjig Maker of the GRR-RIPPER. Work safer. Work smarter. I went through my scrap bin and pulled out a bunch of scrap pieces of half inch plywood for this project. And since this is a painted project, I don't have to worry about the grain direction or the color of the plywood matching. The main challenge to this project is that every piece is a different size. I'm going to start by making a bunch of rectangles. You can cut these out using any kind of saw
you happen to have. A circular saw... A jigsaw... A band saw... A table saw... Or you could even use a hand saw. Nah! Five of these pieces are squares. These are the shelves and I'm going to cut out the curves differently than I'm going to cut out the curves on the
rectangles. The curve on each of the square shelves is just a quarter of a circle. To draw the circle, I'll find the center of the square by connecting the diagonals. The distance from the center of the square to the edge is the radius of the circle I'm
going to draw. And I'm setting that using my beam compass. Cutting corners is easy with a jigsaw. Or a band saw. Or even a coping saw that I would hold like this if I had one. And there are all kinds of ways to sand these
curves smooth. But actually, when it comes down to it, most people just prefer using hand sandpaper and a little bit of elbow grease. Okay, I just totally made that up. One corner of each of the upright vertical
pieces gets a one inch radius. I'm going to join all of my shelves together using my pocket hole jig. I'm not really sure how to clamp this down while I put the screws in so I just put a board on top of the shelf so that I can push this up against it and hold it in place. I'll see if that works. I'm just trying to be super careful that I don't go so far that it comes through the other
side. Those pocket screws will be hidden because this side goes against the wall. It's turning out really handy to have my plans available while I'm trying to put this all
together so I can kind of visualize how it fits together. I really should have looked at those closer because this next shelf goes on like this and if I had really thought that through I would have drilled those holes at the same
time as these holes. But I guess it doesn;t really matter. It looks like I'm going to have to make up this clamping strategy as I go along but it looks like if I just lay this on its
side, I can clamp this together and put the screws
in. And really, that's the only tricky part about using pocket screws. You've got to clap your pieces together to hold them in place while you put the screws
in or they'll just slide around. And I'm only putting these in until I feel a little bit of resistance. because they will go all the way through if I'm not careful. Now I can start working my way up. That was kind of tricky. After letting that sit overnight, it's surprisingly strong. Of course, you could certainly make those
joints as complicated as you like. {Advertisement} I want to thank you all for watching this week's episode of Woodworking for Mere
Mortals. And I especially want to thank my Subbable subscribers who often get to see these video a day early and without ads. If you'd like to make your own corner shelves, check in the description for a free set of
plans. And if this is your first time here, please consider subscribing to my channel. It only takes one click and I have brand new woodworking videos every Friday. And if this is your first time here, you picked a really good time to find Woodworking for Mere Mortals: You absolutely don't want to miss next week's
video which will be one of my most requested projects.

content: hello and welcome to my workshop my name is Chris Pine today's project is going to be a fairly simple wall shelf for my son's room I'm going to put it above the head of his bed the wood that i will be using is some red oak that i salvaged from an old bunk bed that actually used to be in that very same room and my my two sons used to use that bunk bed a few years ago the thing had gotten to where it was just almost falling down so i took it apart we got him some different beds but I always kept that lumber because it was perfectly good but we're going to use it today make a wall shelf let's get started you can see just my really high-tech planning material here and I've made a basic drawing of the side of the shelf these shelves will be 11 inches here this is the side where the Shelf will go in so 11 inches deep 11 inches tall i should say another one at 11 inches tall and then this one approximately eight inches tall and they will also be approximately 11 inches in depth this way as well as this one see the cut that I make here makes this one about 6 inches so it's a fairly simple shelf project and I've traced out on the wood here if you can see the lines where those dedos are going to go this is one of the side pieces and I've got the down here at the bottom if you look this is going to be the part that tapers down at the bottom and we'll cut that out probably with the jigsaw but first I need to cut these dedos and to do that I'm going to go to my dado head cutter on the table saw okay I got the first dado cut on the side piece and here's one of the shelves just to see how that fits beautiful Leah would ended up being about 11 16 since thick so my dado is cut accordingly and the way that I cut the day though some may have a problem with that and that's fine we all have our way of doing things when we have to have personal responsibility I just use the fence when I cut this data just like this and it's a half inch deep and I just pushed it through up against the fence now as long as you hold on to this piece of wood and you're careful there should be no issue doing it that way however I say to you whatever you're not comfortable with do not do so if you have to make a sled to do this then do so but for me this is fine it worked out great so I'm going to cut the other day toes and we'll move on from there I Drive fit the pieces together that I have thus far I need to make some I need to glue up some pieces for the top otherwise this is a hundred percent of the recycled material that i got from the bunk bed here is the glue up for the top which i had to use some new lumber to do that with on the front edge of these shelves i wanted to round the corners over so i just traced a profile here around and then cut it with the bandsaw and I'm sanding it smooth so that ought to be nice just to keep from kid catching his head on it or something my favorite part we're ready for some assembly at this point ok I'm going to put this back piece on with the screws in the pocket holes and now the unit upside down with the bottom laying on the floor and I've got to get down here and install I've got it lined up I need to get down and installed the pocket hole screws into the top now and to do that I'm going to use a little smaller drill because I have a smaller area to work in with the square headed bit on the finish that I used for the bookshelf was polyurethane semi-gloss polyurethane and i dilute it down with some paint thinner I think it absorbs into the wood a lot better I put three coats and I just buff between with an abrasive pad between each coat and I even use a little paste wax at the end to give it a little more protection even after the finish has fully cured and it's time to go hang this on the wall so let's go see if we can get that done okay it's hung on the wall I just put a few things up there I'm sure it'll be full of junk relatively fast anyway neat little project I'm sure they'll get a lot of use out of it another project complete recycle the wood from a bunk bed it would get a lot of use in my son's room I'm pretty happy with how it turned out thanks so much for watching I'd appreciate a like on the video if you're not a subscriber I would invite you to subscribe so you don't miss any of my future videos for those of you who are loyal subscribers thank you very much I appreciate the support have a great week god bless we'll see you next time you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: it's time to do the shelves on the north wall of the kitchen and I'd like to have these shelves float on the wall so that they won't attach to the to the side wall or they won't have any brackets underneath I thought about making a box so that you sort of have the vertical piece to help hold the shelves up but but what I really wanted these to do was to float the method I wanted to use was to use steel pins that would go into the studs in the wall and then come out and go into the shelf and hold the Shelf up I needed to find the studs but even more than that I needed to find the center of each stud so that my pins would be centered on them and not near the side I didn't want to a pin that was sort of half in the stud or you know sort of mostly in the stud I wanted them really centered so I used several different methods to find the studs first by knocking on the wall and then a little bit of the stud finder and then measuring to kind of check to make sure they were there they're 16 inches on center before I had covered the wall up I had marked on a 2 by 4 where the studs were so so I used that as well to check to see whether I was close and things were making sense but in the end what I did to really make sure I was centered on each stud was to find the edge of the stud by drilling holes into the wall I figured that the Shelf would cover up the holes that I was drilling so it really wasn't that big steel that I was putting holes in the wall I could drill a hole about where I thought the edge was and find a spot where there wasn't a stud and then where there was a stud and then I would know that the edge was between those two holes and then from there I could measure over to the center of the stud so to do the pins and to get them in the same place on both the shelf and the I made a stick basically a story stick for the project so I cleaned up a 2x4 and got it nice and straight and nice and square then once I had that I could mark where to drill the holes in 2x4 based on where the Centers of the studs were I could then drill the holes into the 2x4 as straight and a square to the 2x4 as I could I got this long drill bit that's the same diameter as the steel that I got for the pins so that I could go through the 2x4 and then into the wall now I figured if I just held the 2x4 on the wall and tried to drill the holes it would move so what I did was mounted the 2x4 to the wall with screws so that it was in place and it wouldn't move between each hole as I drilled them I figured out the depth that I was going to need to do which for the studs was basically making sure that I didn't drill all the way through the wall so that to my for both spaces the holes but it also holds the drill square to the wall and I can pull the 2x4 down now I'll make the pins I got a 5/8 inch steel rod for this I found the sawzall with a miter box actually works really well for cutting steel and I cleaned up a little burr on the cut and then I could put the pins in the wall and it seemed fairly square and I tapped them in there fairly tight I'm not sure I can get these out at some point in the future I need to now for the actual shelves we've got a thicker piece of bamboo plywood it it's the 5-ply sheet so it's an inch and a half thick and it's heavy that's 8 feet by 26 inches I think so it's a little smaller than a full sheet the cutting was easy it was more that pushing the weight on the sled it was what was difficult I had to jerry-rig the clamp on the sled just a little bit and cut the shelves I first cut the length and then I cut the two widths that I needed and that's basically the woodworking on this project so then I took the same 2x4 story stick with the holes in it and clamp that to the edge of the shelf and I can then drill the holes into the shelf and I'll they'll both be spaced correctly and have the same angle hopefully if there's any tiny variation off of 90 it'll be part of the stick when doing this I started with my cordless drill which was working but it was slow so I tried the corded drill and not that worked a lot for this now something that was in the back of my mind up to this point was that if I if I was drilling holes in the wall and in the Shelf that were both tight to the pins my story stick wasn't going to be accurate enough for everything to slide together with the holes and the pins that type when I took the Shelf up to try and put it in there there was just no way it was going on like that so I went and got a little bit bigger drill bit I think it's 11 16 so sort of the next size up and I drilled out the holes in the shelf this gave me the little bit of wiggle room in the holes to allow the pins to slide onto the shelf on the wall but still kept it tight enough that the shelves weren't loose on them on the pins something I'd wanted to do all along was to put lights under the shelves so the idea was to cut a slot in the bottom of the shelf and put an LED strip light into that slot so with the router I cut a slot on the bottom of the shelf now it's turned out where the lighting in the kitchen is actually pretty bright and I really don't need the lights under the shelves but I figured this has been the idea all along so I'm going to go with it and then some finish I sanded just before this I think with 220 and then three 20 the same as the cabinets and with these I did all six sides so you can see how the shelves just slide onto the pins and held in place so those two wires that have been sticking out of the wall for the whole kitchen project are for the lights that go under the shelves so I stuck the lights into the slot and they seemed to work although that the next morning when we got up part of part of the light was starting to come down so I I'm thinking I'm going to have to figure out how to attach the lights better to the wood like some hot glue or something better better glue than than the sticky that's on the lights and the slot on the upper shelf casts a funny shadow on the wall that I don't really like so I made go back and cut that slot a little wider so that edge isn't in the way I'm testing his shadow so it worked it took a lot of fiddling to get the the pins to work and get the shelves to kind of sit right and and to get the lights to work but but they look good in the end when we were first envisioning these I was figuring the plates would go on these as well and the shelves would be 10 inches deep but when we started to really think about that it seemed it seemed really big and whether whether we really needed to do that so we ended up going with 6-inch shelves and just using them for cups and possibly small bowls so the shelves are sort of half storage half art on the wall away so so we need to make sure that what goes up there looks good I guess because it's totally open thanks for watching

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey guys I am really productive week this week although not a lot to show for it because taking mudding and skin coding not that exciting but what I did complete this week was a mini makeover in this here bathroom I built and installed these floating shelves and this cool Bluetooth speaker light fan if you want to see more about this fan check out my blog post ooh I will show you I will show you section why it's so quiet and then here's a little you know cotton thing check that out good section right okay so on to the floating shelves start it out by cutting a 1 by 6 into 3 1 and 1/2 inch crease then I used half inch plywood to cut my shelf tops bottom sides and front the back is open so the Shelf can mount on the pleats I started out by attaching the sides to the shelf top I used glue and one and a quarter inch nails I used my Dewalt 18 gauge finish nailer for this the battery power makes it very handy and convenient then I glued and nailed the front strip on I didn't try to glue a nil the sides and front all in one go because it's just too hard to keep everything in the right place and lined up while you get it attached I find it's easier just going to go in section once the sides and front piece were installed I went ahead and glued and nailed on the top piece the glue forms a strong bond the nails are just there to hold everything in place while the glue sets one down two more to go repeat the process and let everything dry and then there's lots of Sandy then I filled all of the nail holes and I used wood putty to cover the edges of the plywood on the sides and the front this is my favorite wood putty its czar wood putty and it's water-based cleans up easily works great I love it then I sanded everything lightly with 120 grit sandpaper focusing on the edges so they're not sharp and I wiped everything down then everything got a coat of primer luckily I could stick my hand right up in the cavity and paint all the sides at once and then lay it on its back to dry since I used a water-based primer after it was dry I gave everything a light sanding to knock down that raised grain then it was time to paint of course I have to dance wanna paint right that's a given time to install if I can get a handle on my tools all right I use a tape measure to find the center of my wall I transferred a line all the way down so I would know where the right side of my shelf would be then I kind of played around with a placement found the location for my top shelf and March that I made another mark 1/2 inch over to account for the side of my shelf and I marked the location of this studs onto my cleat I went ahead and started my three inch cabinet screws before I put the first row and here's the level I'm in then the shelf just went right over the top of the cleat and he is one and a half inch wood screws to secure the shell to the cleat I almost always use stack fasteners because I don't have to pre-drill and the countersink from school I installed the first two shelves and then measured the distance between those two so that I could transfer the location of the third shelf and make sure that they were spaced evenly I just repeated the installation process although on this one I secured the shelf to the cleat from the bottom up so it would have any visible scruple Magic Eraser gets all the pencil marks off the wall and we're good to go so that's how I built and installed these ponies and I will catch you next time
