title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey guys this week I built some floating shelves in my studio closet stick around and I'll show you how this project is sponsored by liquid nails fuse it I built the ribs for my floating shelves out of 2x2 lumber using liquid nails fuse it adhesive and 3-inch cabinet screws driven into the studs in the wall I applied the liquid nails fuse it to the wall or the board or both and then press the board to the wall and the instant grab acted as a third hand and held my 2x2 in place until I was able to secure the 2x2 with screws I set up my laser level for each shelf to give me a level line to reference as I was installing each shelf all the shelves will be secured to the wall on three sides on the side of the shelves that ran into the angled ceiling I use my table saw and cut those shelf supports at an angle to match the ceiling and then I wet both surfaces before I applied my liquid nails fuse it because it makes it bond faster I used some nails and one screw because that's the only stud that I could hit on that side which is an additional reason why I need the extra strength of the adhesive and I'm not bothering with drilling pocket holes I'm just driving myself drilling self tapping screws in at an angle and for the most part they work really well without splitting the wood although sometimes it happens and when that did occur I just bumped up the bracing with an extra block and then drove in an extra screw I'm using a big glob of adhesive and one screw in each joint and when you get the adhesive on the wall if you get it before it dries it wipes right off after attaching the front of the shelves I put in all of the dividers I used the adhesive and screws but I only attach the front screw until all of the dividers were in place because I was pulling forward on that front piece to allow me to slide the divider in without scraping off all of the adhesive while I slid it into play I used a clamp to keep both surfaces flush with each other while I drove a screw in at an angle through the divider and into the back cleat I built three 10 inch deep floating shelves on the main wall and then one deeper shelf against the back wall under the slanted ceiling after I built the 2x2 skeletons I put plywood on the top and bottom of each shelf I used quarter inch plywood for the bottoms and half inch plywood for the tops I applied a bead of liquid Mills fuse it along the perimeter and the dividers and then press the plywood into place the bond held really well so I just shot some 23 gauge pin nails in there to hold it in place and make sure it stayed until the adhesive set the bottom shelf is over 8 feet long so I had a seam I just made sure that I cut both pieces to end in the center of a divider so that I could shoot nails into the divider on both ends of the seam I used liquid nails fuse it and nails on all of my shelves and just repeated the process until it was finished I did bevel the ends of the angled shelves so that they fit nicely into place I used primed pine 1 by 3s for my friends and they put adhesive on the 2 by 2 and tried to squiggle it onto the top fly wood as well because I wanted to bond that face to both of those surfaces then I used my 16 gauge nail gun and shot some nails into the face to make sure that it stayed in place until the adhesive had time to cure the larger shelf in the back of the room was a little bit trickier I used half inch plywood on the top and the bottom to add a little extra strength but that extra weight on the bottom made it heavier and harder to hold in place without any extra clamps so it was a little tricky I had to take a little rest after that activity before finishing up the room I was thinking after I got the flooring installed I put a brace under this one I don't want it in the way while I'm trying to sell a flooring because this clause is small enough area already don't want to have to be working around a raisin that I can put step to Ben's high underneath here and over here I'm planning on having some I don't know honestly what I'm going to put in here right now I'm going to take all of the tools that I have laying all over the place in the rest of my studio and put them into your very nicely and then when I'm done building my studio put other stuff in here that's my plan so that's it for today thanks for watching about we'll see you next time

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
Hey Everybody we're back in the garage. I've already shown you how to do that suspended
overhead shelf and my workbench. You can see it's already getting filled up with stuff. Now the third stage of my shelving system
is going to be some corner shelves. We've got 600 mm or 2 ft apart. 3 of them, nothing on the concrete floor. What I'm going to do though is have an angled
front because I've got a door here and I want to be able to swing it right past with the
shelves in behind and on a similar angle to the open door. I don't want the shelves coming out on a square
angle because they will dig into the door. Your tools for today's job are all good quality
hand tools, square, hammer, tape measure, ear muffs, once again we're going to be using
bugle batten screws with an appropriate drill. We'll need a power saw and a good quality
level and also today we'll need a good quality saw to cut those angles. Let's get into it, first of all we're going
to do the cleats just like I've done the cleats up here with bugle batten screws. You can watch those videos to watch how I've
attached the cleats. I've already marked out the levels so I attach
the cleats and then it's just a matter of measuring the same style of chipboard for
the shelves, cut to 90 degrees in the corners and 45 degrees on the externals, with a 2
x 1 on the face to protect the front of the shelf. We measure the length from the internal corner
to the outside of both corners and cut our sheet accordingly with a right angle and two 45's. There is the finished product. Give it a test run. There you go. You can see how the door is going to fit nicely
across that instead of the shelf sticking out and hitting the door. So I'll apply some glue and fix the shelf down. Do the second and the third one as well. Then put the 2 x 1 on the front. This is the timber I'm using 42 x 19. It gives a bit of strength to that front of the shelf. It is already quite strong being supported
firmly on both sides. So the timber gives a bit more strength and
protects the chipboard edge. Glue and nailed on. Fitting a nail in to the support and into the shelf. This ensures the shelf is fully supported. Three extra strong shelves ready to take any
load and I can swing the door open quite freely and right out of the way with good access
for those who want to come in that way. Check out more of my building and construction videos. Thanks for watching guys and I'll see you
again very soon.

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
Every bedroom needs somewhere to store your
bits and bulbs up out of the way. These simple, lightweight floating shelves
will do just that. Let's take this bare bedroom wall and turn
it into a simple and useful storage space. These are the tools and materials I'll need
for my simple, lightweight floating shelves. To make this job even easier, I've got all
my timber precut at Bunnings. To attach my shelf support to my shelf, I
need to make sure it's centered and flush with the back of the shelf, and then pre-drill
three holes. I'm just gonna use a bit of glue to provide

content: hey guys I'm finishing up my pantry shelves when you last saw I had installed 3/4 inch plywood ribs now I'm going to be adding plywood to the top and bottom I'm using 1/2 inch plywood on the top and quarter inch on the bottom I use my track saw to rip down the 8-foot pieces of plywood and then used my table set to trim to fit I cut all of the plywood pieces down in my workshop and then brought them upstairs and trim to fit on the miter sod that I have in the house I had described several of the shelves because the walls just aren't straight and that's when that miter saw comes in handy it's a lot easier to trim it in my kitchen than to go all the way down to the workshop every time I need to make a little cut the first shelf I set in place and nailed down with my battery-powered nail gun but the consecutive shelves mine L couldn't didn't fit in all of the cavities so I used wood glue clamps weights my nail gun when it would fit I just didn't want to have to haul my air compressor down which I ended up having to do later anyway so I should have just made it easier on myself oh well I've got my quarter inch bottoms and primed and sanded them before installation it's easier to get as many steps done as possible before installation because painting wallets upside down is not the easiest thing and speaking of installation I used wood glue and a smaller nail gun which fit easily in between all of the cavities which I had to haul my air compressor down for so yeah I should have hauled it down to begin with and saved myself a little trouble on the first step after all of my tops and bottoms are installed I used my wood patch and filled all of the nail holes and patched my scenes I thought it would be a little bit easier to do now than after the faces are on because the faces will have a half inch overhang on the bottom of the shelves I faced my shelves with 1x3 poplar using wood glue and Brad nails to secure them they are flush on the top with a half inch overhang on the bottom and simple but joints no miter is necessary because they're going to be painted in the end yes of course they are once all my wood patch was dry i sanded and sanded and sanded I can't stress enough the importance of prepping your project for finish it's one of the most important steps that there is it can make your project look awesome or like a total fail so I sanded vacuumed wiped and then looked for anything else that I could see and filled again and then waited some more and then sand it again after that was dry I cleaned it all up and then I primed after priming I sanded everything again the power sander on the flat surfaces and a sanding sponge by hand to knock down any sharp edges then I wiped everything down and Kolb I made sure the caulk was dry and wipe down the shelves really well before I painted I used a high-gloss paint and painted it on with a brush and a microfiber roller I did two coats and I do not stand in between coats and I get a really smooth finish this way I think the key is light coats and don't overwork the surface I am so excited about how this turned out I love it and you have all kinds of paint or coal in my hair I guess I'll be wearing a hat for a while thanks for watching and I will see you next time

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hi everybody I'm Leo CJ trill and today I'm going to show you how to build one of these now what is this this is called a floating shop and I got to tell you there's nothing better if you want to showcase a collection of islands you may have so let's get in the workshop let's get started okay so this is what we need to get started so what is it well it's a hollow-core door and it's 30 inches wide now we're going to have to take the door and we're going to cut it down the middle well maybe not exactly down the middle because we want to cut a shelf that's going to be appropriately sized so let's get started we're going to go over to the table saw before you get started just make certain that you have an outfeed table set up behind the table saw okay so that's our cut that's a nice clean cut gonna turn it on its side so you can see what we've got here now remember I said was a hollow core door so these pieces here you say they're just cardboard that's what I'm gonna have to do is gonna have to cut away some of the cardboard to make room for the cleat okay so I've got a utility knife here this is just cardboard what we're going to do is we're just kind of cut away some of the cardboard what it's gonna do is it gonna it's going to give us room for the crease okay okay so there's a little bit of remnants of the cardboard what I'm going to do is I'm just going to take up a razor blade a safety blade and just spread that off and smooth it and you're going to want to repeat that process wherever you find remnants of the cardboard now keep in mind we're going to insert the cleat into the cavity of the door and you want to give yourself about an inch to two inches worth of clearance here from the top of that door for where the cardboard is so just cut away about two inches okay so now it's time to cut our cleat so we need to measure the distance between okay it's about an inch in 1/16 but we're going to cut it so it's an inch and 1/8 because we want a snug fit so you're probably saying wait wait you're cutting the cleat a little thicker than the cavity in the door hey that's fine because the the skin of the door is flexible what that cleat could be as snug as possible okay so this is the clean and we want to make certain that we drive fit to clean inside the cavity of the the shelf and because you don't want to get this thing secured to the wall and then find out your cleat doesn't fit so that's what I'm doing right now I'm just doing a dry fit okay so I've got my cleat inserted I know that it fits I don't want to push it all the way down because then I'll have a hard time removing it and we need to remove it so we can secure it to the wall okay now I've determined where I want the shelf to be placed on the wall now what we have to do is our next step is we have to determine where the studs are and we're going to use a stud finder to do that okay so I'm going to put the stud finder on the wall turn it on allow it to calibrate it's calibrated now now I'm going to start moving it across until I locate my stud well there's one stud there so I'm going to mark it so they keep going down don't find my next stud someone else stood right there I'll mark that okay as you can see I've located the studs of beneath the surface of the drywall now I know where I need to attach the cleat okay so what I've done here is I've got to clean I'm holding it up against our reference line it's gonna let me know where I need to pre-drill holes in the cleat so I'll tap directly into my stud and I won't split the pine because I'm pre drilling now I'm going to use a structural screw you can use a lag screw if you like but this is a good alternative I like because it tends not to split the wood okay so when you drill a pilot hole just make certain that the drill bit that you're using is smaller in diameter than the diameter of the screw that you're going to use to attach the cleat just make certain that you clamp the wood down before you start to drill okay so now it comes time to attach the cleat to the wall we're just going to line up our pilot holes with stud Center remember stud Center is the center of the stud can you see why now I love these structural screws they're just an easy install and they secure whatever you're attaching to the studs and this is what it should look like now what you want to do is you want to apply wood glue to the inside of the end bead you don't be generous with it mixing you get the top as well here okay I want to give you like three different fastener choices and the reason for that is I you know you never know what a homeowner has in terms of equipment ideally you would want to use a pneumatic nailer with a compressor but not most homeowners have something like that around the house so what we're going to be using today is we're going to be using a cabinet screw and it looks like that looks a little bit like a drywall screw the other thing you could do is you could use a wire Brad that's what this is that might be a little challenging nailing it in but it's a good choice it can be a good choice if a hammer is all you have next up this is more like a finishing screw what makes it different is it has a smaller head now it's time to put the shelf in place so we're going to slide now remember we did a dry fit so we know that it fits but it may not be effortless we could have to you know fool around a little bit here's the thing it's important to get a nice snug fit you don't want to have a gap between the shelf in the wall so you might have to wrap it with a hammer but you don't want to damage the shelf itself so just make something to use a piece of scrap wood make your taps that way you're not worried about you know damaging the shelf itself now I'm going to just use a cordless screwdriver to drive the screw into the cleat now make certain you repeat the process down the length of the shelf all about every 12 inches and don't forget to get the underside so we're all finished I got to tell you I'm pretty happy with the results there's no better place display a collection like my tribal mask here than on a floating shelf now I stay in my shelf you may want to paint yours or you may just want to leave it natural the choice is yours this is Leah saying you can do this see you next time you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey everyone my name is Matt welcome to my son's nursery today I'm going to show you how I made these really simple floating wall shelves out of a reclaimed right ok to buy for now a few years ago my wife and I went to pick up some reclaimed lumber for a project that she was working on and I picked up a lot of extra stuff just because it was so cheap and I figured I have a use for it in the future sometime so I've had this stuff sitting around for a while now and I figured this would be the perfect project for a few of those pieces so I got a couple of these boards that I thought would work for this project but I ended up only using one of them anyway I started by standing a face and an edge of the board and those are going to become the bottom and the front edge of the shelf if my wife wants needs to be about three feet long each and she wants two of them so this one here is going to be pretty good for that this is 70 inches to the bottom of this notch cut that was here for whatever this used to be proud of like a roof Raptor or something structural in the in a barn or whatever so I think that work out pretty well can cut this down to 35 inch pieces and like give me my two shelves it's also going to include those nail holes and one of them which I think are really cool they have a nice look to them so now British Argyle of nails out but we shall find out for sure so I'm just going to cut these real quick with the jigsaw just to cut them down to rough size and then later on I'll come back and clean up these cut edges so if the joint or I'm going to clean up one faced in one edge and not get too much I'm squirted to each other and those are going to be the top and the back side of the piece so I on the wall you'll still have this cool rustic look on the top and bottom but the pieces you have on the shelf will have a nice flat place to sit so now that I have my reference corner I'll use that on my crosscut sled to not only square them up but also cut them to length so my wife would also like a small lip on the front edge of the shelf so at the table saw I'm gonna use my ripping blade and it's like reficul fences to create a really tall rabbit but not that deep the blade is protruding past the fence about a sixteenth of an inch maybe a little more than that shelves we going to mount to the wall on a French cleat so rip the cleats of a scrap with my blade tip to 30 degrees so since i'm going to mounting this on the wall with a French cleat this one I get glued into the shelf and this one will go on to the wall and they'll lock together like that now to make this happen i first need to create a recess in the back of the shelf so i can mount the shelf cleat into it and then you won't see any any of this clade system when the shelf is actually on the wall so I've laid out the basically this giant mortise here it's going to be stopped about an inch and a half from both ends it's going to go down the thickness of the French cleat which is a three-quarters of an inch and it's about maybe an inch and a quarter wide yeah so I mentioned a quarter wide and I'd love to go 316 from the top and the bottom now notice as I'm using my router here i'm using my reference face that i made off the joint ER so now it's straight and square to this one here then we're actually working on and as you'll see since this isn't a consistent thickness the remainder on the bottom is actually going to be variable compared to the top and I was kind of clean this up a little bit with the chisel this is not going to be seen but I figure might as well make it look a little better than his little hump to in the middle there now there's a little better and then I can glue the cleat into the shelf clamps then the last thing I'll do is just break these edges with the block plane and then to get to the inside of slip here I'll use some sandpaper ok I'm finished I'm gonna give it one coat of this really light shellac I don't want a really thick film finish on this just looking to kind of you know seal things up make it look a little nicer and kind of bring out that rough sawn look the finish will also helps seal in and either remain dirt and grime and stuff that will be left on here so I'm really happy with the way the shelves turned out overall it took me about an hour to make and that includes filming so it's a really quick project and really quick to hang as well so that's great and more importantly my wife really likes them and she's happy that I finally made these because I've been saying that I would do this for a long time if you like to see more of my simple projects I have a bunch of them listed in this playlist here check those out and if you want to see something a little more complicated check out one of my build videos perhaps this small dresser that I'm standing next to and as always thank you for watching really appreciate it if you have any questions or comments both these shelves or anything else I've done in the past please feel free to leave me a comment as always I appreciate those and I'd be happy to answer any questions you might have until next time happy we're working

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: I went to Home Depot where I bought a pre laminated 12 by 4 ply sheet and a 10 foot one inch galvanized steel pipe both of these cost me $40 my son wanted a corner desk but he is limited by a window on one of the walls he wants the desk in I drew out a quick draft that will ensure I clear the window this has plantation shutters and extends four inches when perfectly open the desk will be two feet from the wall and five feet six inches in length once you know what shape you want simply draw out your table on the surface of the board I am positive the pipe can hold a larger desk but I think that two feet is the perfect size for a corner desk instead of a corner I am going to make a slight arch to give it a more professional look I simply measure out a foot on both sides and with a nail placed at the point of the intersection I draw out my arch I drilled a small hole at the end of my ruler so my pencil tip can fit through it with a compass I round out my corners anything will work a paint can will do just fine you just want the bends to be long and round so when you apply the edging it will have no problems adhering to it once your desk is drawn out you may begin cutting first I clamp down a straight board as a guide to keep my cuts straight you will have time to prove you can cut a straight line when you get to the bends for pre laminated boards you need to use a very thin and fine finishing blade to minimize the chipping at the particle board beneath the laminate to really cut down on chipping you can use a straight blade and cut along your line if you do this then when you are sawing do not cut on the line but to the outside of it finish the rest of your cuts in the same manner until the desktop is completely cut out now to cut your pipes simply use whatever metal blade you possess and cut your pipes I have decided that I want the death slightly higher than two feet so each pipe was cut to three feet six inches this will include the bend dividing the length of your pipes in half clearly mark them so you can ensure your bends will all be centered take your pipes to a workshop or if you have a pipe bender bend your pieces to 90 degrees each I have a piece that will take multiple bends to avoid the window I anticipate you will not have this problem if you are making the bends yourself ensure they are 90 degrees by using a square this is the double Bend piece that I will be using to avoid the window now lay your pipe on a flat surface and drill out the holes these holes will be used to secure the desktop to the pipes you probably won't need more than three a hand drill works fine but here I will be using my drill press to ensure that the holes are ninety degrees just ensure you are using a titanium drill bit where this process will take a long time taking a piece of scrap that was cut from the desktop I clamp it down to ensure that when the pipes are drilled the holes remain perpendicular to the wall just make sure you clamp the pipe to the scrap piece so it's straight up and down once all the pipes are bent and drilled you can paint them I had some leftover glossy white from another project so I use that use whatever is closest to the wall color of the room the desk is going in the desk edging is actually sold as shelfing edging it is three dollars a roll and one roll will easily cover the desk and some using scotch tape I taped the edging into position I cover the iron with aluminum foil so I do not get any adhesive on the iron or burn the edges while applying take your time and melt the edging onto your desk in past experiences I have learned that screws are easily pulled from particle boards so I've decided to cut a couple of braces that I can tack down and with wood glue mount to the bottom of the desk this will be stronger and allow me to screw in the mounts with regular screws your only limitations to the width of these boards is to ensure that they are wider than your pipe but not small enough to allow tacks to penetrate through the top of your desk top take a small scrap piece cut from the desktop and test your nail depth before you fasten the real ones to the desktop the worst thing you could do is penetrate the desktop with a nail on the last step of this project simply use a level when installing your pipes to the wall you can set them at any height you desire a good rule of thumb is to ensure that the armrests of your desk chair can easily pass under the desk now place the desktop on the pipe mounts and slide snugly into place the last step will be to secure the desk top to the pipe mounts with a bead of glue lace one side of your cut board tack on with a nail gun and allow an hour or so to dry before screwing the pipes to the bracket once again check the length of your screws to ensure they will not penetrate all the way through both the pipe and the other board if you know where all the objects on your desktop will be placed the last part is easy use a hole saw to cut your hole to run your wires place this hole in an inconspicuous location and that's all there is to it now you have a nice looking modern floating corner desk that gives you ample space above as well as below thanks for watching

of the doors dictates the width the boxes that support them since the doors are 14 inches and that's wider than standard boards you need to cut down some plywood to build the boxes and whether you're building the box that lays on its side the box that stands up or the basic square the process is essentially the same so let's start with some cutting tips blue styrofoam insulation makes a great surface to cut on you'll get cleaner cuts with less splintering and it's an easier safer solution than trying to cut big unwieldy sheet goods on sawhorses to get a good straight cut use a 1 by 4 or 1 by 6 as a guide board always cut your pieces to width first and remember when you're using a circular saw the overall measurement needs to account for the distance from the edge of the foot to the blade so in this case the distance from the blade of the foot is an inch and a half add that to the width the piece you're cutting and that's where you mark and clamp your guide board once your pieces are cut to width then cut to length now you can prep your pieces to build the boxes each box has a bottom two sides a top and a back the joints in the boxes just butt up against each other and that's a lot easier than miter joints because you'll use glue they need to mask off the joints and spacers are a fast way to find your masking point then Prime and paint your pieces for those surprising pops of color on the interior of the boxes once the piece is dry you can assemble your boxes each box needs an offset so that the face frame is flush and the box sits flat use a couple of pieces of scrap that are the correct thickness and place the bottom piece of the box on those to create the offset now you'll glue and nail the pieces in this order a side the top the other side and then the back perfect fit flip the box on its back to add the face frame don't pre-cut these pieces cutting them to fit will give you a much better result sandé prime and paint the exterior of the boxes don't forget to fill the nail holes first one thing to pay attention to make sure to mask this bit on the interiors of the boxes it's the point where the face frame sits evenly with the floor of the box and you wouldn't want to paint over your color let them dry and stack them up you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey I'm Bob and I like to make stuff today I'm going to show you how to make a really simple floating desk first I made the frame and it had to fit between three walls I did this with just regular old two by fours I cut down two long pieces for the front and back three pieces to act as cross braces I pre drilled some holes in the ends of the long ones and countersunk them so that the screws could fit flush add drove in screws and just made a simple box the last piece of the frame was just to fit in the center piece and screw it in the exact same way to make the actual surface of the desk I figured out how many pieces of 1x4 I would need and then I just cut those in half on the chop saw to make sure that I had enough I laid them out and then rearrange the grain pattern to what I thought would look good these were going to be connected with biscuits using a biscuit joiner so I had to make a mark between two pieces anywhere that I wanted to biscuit to sit on these marks on each piece I use the biscuit joiner to cut a slot and I had to do this on both sides of most of the pieces other than the front in the back once I got all the slots cut which was a whole lot I added some glue to the surfaces and down in the slots that were cut then I just pushed a biscuit down into each one of the slots some of them were tighter than other because the biscuits are often a little bit different in size so some of them had to be knocked in with a mallet some one end very easily then it was a matter of just lining up the slots between the two pieces using the lines that I've drawn earlier I clamped these two pieces together alternating the clamps from the top and the bottom this helps the board's not to buckle in one direction if they have even pressure at first I just started with two boards at a time I wasn't entirely positive that my long clamps would be long enough to do the whole tabletop at once on each of the rest of the boards I added the slots to both sides of it then I added glue to all the surfaces and down in the slots before dropping in the biscuits I had to glue to the top of these biscuits so when they went in their mating slot there would be glue on all the different surfaces it took a little bit to line all these up but once I got everything lined up I used some really long clamps to clamp the whole thing together again I use clamps on the top and the bottom to make sure that there was even pressure and this would stay as flat as possible the last step before I did the final glue up was to clamp on that two board section that I had done previously it turned out my clamps were plenty long enough and like I always say you can never have too many clamps today's video sponsored by dove men plus care and their personal care brand but there's a very specific reason that I wanted to work with them I spend a lot of time in the shop without air conditioning and I spent a lot of time outside running training for marathons between all of that and living in the deep south I'm sweaty a lot of the time and being sweaty a lot at least for me causes a lot of armpit irritation and chafing they've done a whole bunch of research and I found that over 50% of men deal with some sort of an armpit irritation if we don't have to deal with that stuff we're going to be more comfortable more confident we're just going to do a better job at whatever it is we're doing I know for me if I'm comfortable I will work longer and train harder for sure so they made a whole line of ana purse prints made specifically to fight irritation and if you deal with this at all you want to visit the link below and you can see all their research and the line of products they have to help you be more comfortable so be sure to go check them out thanks dove men plus care after that panel was dry and out of the clamps I had to clean off the glue squeeze-out it comes up in droplets so I just used a scraper and slid it along the lines all those droplets popped off pretty easily a biscuit joiner does a pretty good job of lining up the surfaces but it's not perfect because the biscuits are a little bit different size so to smooth it out I used a hand plane and just ran over all the joints until I couldn't feel them very much it didn't need to be perfectly smooth and this wasn't something I had a lot of experience with I got it pretty far and then finished up with an orbital sander the last real step of construction was to add the front pin it needed to be deep enough to cover the 2x4 frame and the 1 by 4 top so I used a 1 by 6 and just stripped off just a little bit I set it up against the front of the top panel and added biscuits just like I had done to create the top panel itself i clamped a piece into the vise and added the biscuit slots from the backside then it was a matter of just attaching it like I had done previously glue biscuits knocking it together with a mallet and adding clamps but I wanted this piece to be a little bit stronger just because it wasn't in to end I used some clamps to pull this piece snug to the tabletop and make sure it lined up well I split the width of the desk into 6 equal parts and then made a mark 3/8 of an inch down from the top this is right in the middle of the board that's behind it I counter cycle hole and drove in a screw and this really forces those pieces together then I added a dowel with some glue into that hole and sawed it off so it was flush originally I wanted this desk top to be removable so you would lift it up using the front panel that's why it needed to be attached in a really strong sturdy way well turn out in the end that wasn't going to work out but I went ahead and did this because I like the detail of having those dowel ends from the front panel i planed down that edge just to get it smooth with the top again and then ran over it quickly with the sander but it didn't need very much the sander was really handy to get those dowels completely flush on the front panel the glue and the sawdust around those holes fills in any gaps which is really nice then I needed to trim it to the correct width I used my speed square and clamped on a straight edge so that I could get a nice even cut along one side of this table I had to do the same for the front face but there wasn't enough room for the circular saw so I used the flush cut saw instead after getting one side completely flush I measured over the actual distance that I needed and cut off the opposite side the client wanted the desk to be a classic gray stain so it covered the whole thing with a really thick coat and then went back and wiped it off with some paper towels I left it on for probably about five minutes before I started wiping things off after that was dry I did two coats of satin polycrylic with a light sanding in between I wanted the tabletop to be very smooth I laid the frame over a piece of eighth inch plywood and cut it to size and this is going to be the bottom once it's I measured up the height where I wanted the frame to stop and then used a laser level to mark that point on all three of the walls that this would be attached to I went around on that laser and made several marks because I would cover up the laser while I was in there installing it I dropped some screws into each one of the two by fours into where I knew studs were then into the corners I filled in the rest of the spaces with some anchoring screws that I had that I knew worked pretty well I wanted to test it out and it's plenty strong then I just sat on the top I had to do some adjusting and slamming and knocking in but once I got it fit in then I drove some screws in through the two by fours into the frame of the front I ran at a time to stain the bottom panel before I put it in so I'm gonna have to go back and stain that later this was a little bit different that I had stalled that desk but then I had to actually do some last-minute travel you can tell I'm actually on the road right now and I wasn't able to get back in there to get the final shots of the desk so all I have to show you is a photograph but this is what it ended up looking with I was really happy with how it turned out and it was a super simple build I did mention before that the top of this desk was originally supposed to be removable that was the idea and I was going to put some magnets in the bottom of the top piece and in the 2x4 frame so it would stick together unless you actively pulled it out I was hoping I could add some hidden storage to it that way just to make it a little bit more interesting and when I was installing it I found a problem the opening that the desk went into was actually a little bit larger on the back than it was on the front so to make it fit I had to trim off a little bit of the front to make it nice and snug but that made it so I couldn't actually pull the desk out I was running out of time and didn't have any other options at that point so I just made it fixed which is what they wanted in the first place so it's a super simple project something you can add to any little look in your house very easily you can add some storage underneath it you can do a lot of different things to customize it to fit whatever space you have to put it in I hope you like this one if you did I'd love to hear about let me know down in the comments or my website I like to make Steph calm I've got all my social links down there and lots of other videos and stuff for you to check out thanks for watching guys see you next time [Music]

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: this is the homemade modern DIY kitchen series where we will show you how we built an entire kitchen from scratch this episode will focus on how we made the open shelf and some of the storage accessories for this kitchen I'm going to make the upper shelves for the kitchen out of oak stair treads that I had left over for the staircase in this apartment the treads come with a rounded nose that I want to trim off for aesthetic reasons I cut the shelves to length using my compound miter saw the edges that we cut with the table saw were a little bit rough we sanded those down with the orbital sander I want to make sure that these open shelves are connected firmly to the structure of the wall so I'm going to use a stud finder to locate the two by fours behind the drywall I'm going to use L brackets to connect the Shelf to the wall so I'm laying out the shelf and then marking the locations of the studs in the wall to the shelf now that I know where I want the L brackets located I can cut recesses into the shelves so the L back brackets fit flush the inside corners of the L brackets are slightly curved so I'm gonna use my knife to round over one of the edges after painting the brackets with two coats of white paint I screwed them to the underside of the Shelf I used to melt crate and some scrap pieces of wood to build up some scaffolding that would hold the shelf in place while I screwed it to the wall it did the same thing for the second shelf I use the level just to make sure everything was going in straight for the pantry shelves around the refrigerator we're use a combination of cleats that are made from balusters and two by six two by eight and two by four lumber all painted white since we have all open shelving I wanted to have some cool containers to hide cleaning supplies and other things that aren't yet aesthetically pleasing we bought some ammo cans online spray painted them and then dip dyed them with high gloss interior house paint in the interest of saving paint I modified a cardboard box it was just a few inches bigger than the ammo can itself I lined the cardboard box with a trash bag duct taped it into place pour it into paint and then dip the ammo cans I really like how the ammo cans came out and I actually think I'm going to get a bunch more of them for storage elsewhere in the loft no one's going to mistake these shelves for fine woodworking but dicket my sort of rough simple aesthetic and they're really durable and I can always adjust them if I want to change the way they're located keep your eyes open for other videos in this series where we will show you how to make the base cabinets and the concrete countertops check out our website for more detailed information and don't forget to subscribe to this channel

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: welcome to specific love look what my dad made me it's a cool Lego shell for all my Lego murder when I first saw this I thought that wow that is a cool thing for all my Legos to go on too and I also thought well it's a really good thing for little kids so they don't get to my Legos and just start chewing on them so I also thought a little later on that when people come over they always say hey can I see all your Lego men and stuff so this is even better for when they want to see all my Lego men just show them this they get the same and be way easier than just getting the bucket and taking about one by one and showing them well my dad's gonna show you how to make this thank you son for the intro these Lego shelves are a little different than I've ever seen because they're double layered so you can store twice as many characters in the same amount of space we chose a wall near the door because it's easy to see in the room and fast to grab when heading out and with this shelving design a small wall works great too we started with three shelves to hold most of his favorite characters but this design can be expanded easily for future growth the shelves are 15 inches wide and constructed from six pieces cut from a 1 inch by 2 inch by 8 foot board pick the two pieces and putting them into an L shape allow for securing with screws in the bottom drilling pilot holes is a great idea for this design and it prevents cracks my wife did painted each one white to match the wall for the Lego strips I had to cut up a 10 by 10 base plate into two peg wide sections and since the shelves are 15 inches wide I only needed one and a half strips per level I had to use an exacto knife for this task when going in is wise to hold the separate pieces together with a Lego block to get the correct spacing I then found the studs in a wall drilled some more pilot holes and attached each shelf or two screws adding a touch of paint to each screw head will help hide them and now my son can display and enjoy his Lego characters with everyone if you like this project you may want to check out some of these videos you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey I'm Baba Dali to make stuff today I'm going to show you how to make a really simple floating shelf I started out by cutting one of my many many extra pallet runners down to about 24 inches and then just used a punch to knock the nails in flat I measured in four inches from each end and made a mark which puts them 16 inches from each other which would ideally line up with studs we're going to measure out the piece that you're going to use for the front to the length you want and then make sure to measure a couple of pieces to go on the sides out of the same material the width of the side pieces needs to be the same as the thickness of the top and bottom pieces everything is going to sit behind the front panel I wanted to make sure this thing was pretty smooth but not lose the kind of rough rustic look on it so I ran everything over the belt sander just to knock off anything loose anything rough but not to completely plane it down to like nice lumber start with the top or the bottom doesn't really matter and attach the size of some Brad's then you want to put on the front this helps lock it all together and it's a lot easier to line it this way one of the really fun things about doing rustic type stuff like this is that you don't have to be exact when lining edges up I used the same natural stain that I used for the headboard I did recently I really love it because it brings out the contrast in the wood but doesn't change the color then I hit it with a couple of coats of spray lacquer just a satin finish this isn't going to be handled so it really doesn't even need it but it just kind of brings out a little bit more contrast put the ledger on the wall and level it and then make a mark for where the holes are going to be drill those holes out and if you're going to use anchors put them in now in my case I had to deepen the holes in the wood a little bit because these anchors weren't going to be long enough to go through the 2x4 and through the drywall there are lots of different methods for securing these to the wall this is just what I happen to use now you want to pre-drill some holes on top of the shelf to secure it to the ledger you want to make sure that they're in far enough so that no matter where the shelf sets on the ledger it can connect to the wood set it in place run the screws down in and you're good now if you didn't want a rustic shelf you could finish it in any way that you wanted to you could use any type of wood that you wanted to it's really just a box pretty easy the big thing to remember is that the ledger that's on the wall needs to be really really secure because that's going to carry any kind of weight that you put on the Shelf the shelf itself doesn't really carry much weight big thanks to my good friend Chuck who shot this episode Chuck is in town visiting he normally works on the drunken woodworker if you've never seen the drunken woodworkers channel be sure to check it out David over there does some really great woodworking projects and every week he does a wrap-up show that show shows the best woodworking videos and talks about podcasts and just kind of the events that are going on in woodworking community and it's a really funny show David's a funny guy and does a really great job so be sure to check that out thanks so much for watching I really appreciate it and I hope you guys in this one if you want to get in touch with me let me know on Facebook be sure to check me out over there and on Instagram be sure to go to I like to make stuff calm and check out all the other projects and free plans that I have available and if you'd like to support this show please check out patreon there's video that explains how it works and how the support helps me and I really appreciate it hope you guys have a good week see you next time

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: so remodeling the dining room is going great and as you can see the buffet is finished but the room is still huge and makes the buffet look tiny my wife and I think that some open shelves will really help balance it out for me this project is more of a layout challenge than anything else and I'll start by locating the studs with a small nail and marking it with a piece of masking tape then I'll use a level to get a general idea of where the Shelf will go once marks have been made for the bottom shelf I'll next make marks for the top shelf I want 32 inches in between the top and bottom because that is a number I can easily cut in half meaning the middle shelf will be at 16 inches this is the hardware I will use to attach the shelves to the wall it matches up to a 7/16 inch drill bit and you can get both of these at Rockland com I'm going to show you a very effective way to install this hardware using a piece of scrap wood so my studs are supposed to be 16 inches on center and three studs that would make 32 inches and so I'm going to make mine about four inches oversized so about 36 I even started out measuring everything even laid out the lines for the center but this is why this story stick is so great because as you can see here it doesn't match up at all so I'm going to just make a mark where the stud actually is it's time to use that 7/16 drill bit to make our holes on the story stick but because I now know my holes are off-center I have to mark which side is left and which is right next I'll insert the hardware and use a level to attach the story stick to the wall now I can trace the hardware and remove the stick so with the hardware attached to the wall I can now get rid of that tape and focus on the shelves out in the shop I start by so I'm using a cheap dowel jig I got a long time ago if you don't have one of these just be careful to drill as straight as possible to make sure the shelf sits flush on the wall I will cut these content: hi I'm Dave today I'm making a floating display shelf it's very simple design that you could make it one day these are the boards that I'm going to use to make the shelf they're going to be sandwiched together they're reclaimed pine from an old stage riser the first thing to be done is to cut the boards to size [Music] after they're ripped I cut one end each square and then measure for the length [Music] now that the boards are cut to size I'm going to cut grooves across them on by here and here roughly five inches in from the ends that'll be to accommodate the bracket which is made of a three quarter inch dowel set into a base the base is going to need to be accommodated too so I'm going to cut another groove lengthwise here and when we're all done with that we'll sandwich them together to make the Shelf because I'm using a 3/4 inch dowel I set the dado stack to 3/8 of an inch at the width of the dowel [Music] [Applause] once the boards are sandwiched together you have a 3/4 inch hole for the dowel I put on a sacrificial fence raise the dado stack up to about half an inch and run both boards through to make a pocket for the base of the bracket [Music] [Applause] now the grooves are cut now it's time to glue the board's together [Music] Oh [Music] now I nail the pieces together I'm just putting in three Brad nails this is to keep the pieces aligned while I clamp it up after the glues dried remove the clamps then I measure the pocket in order to cut blocks to fill in at the ends [Music] piece of oak is what I'm using for the base of the bracket I'm cutting it to size to fit into the pocket in the back of the shelf [Music] with the base of the bracket in place I use a technique I learned from watching Jimmy direst ax marking with spray paint now I know where to drill holes for the dowels [Music] now I cut the dowels to length and install them in the base of the bracket [Music] you [Music] here I'm cutting some of the remaining stock to strips about 1/4 inch thick I'm going to use this to trim the edges of the shelf [Music] [Applause] [Music] now that the shelf is painted it's just a question of finding the studs in the wall screwing the bracket into the wall making sure to level it and sliding the shelf on then using a couple of small screws secure the shelf to the bracket and here's the completed shelf it's light duty I wouldn't keep my kettlebell collection on it but it's just perfect for the CD player thanks for watching

content: hey guys my name is aaron massey and today i'm going to show you how I built this DIY industrial black pipe bookshelf that's a mouthful to get started let's take a look at some of the pieces we're going to need to tackle this build I'm using 3/4 inch black pipe pieces which I picked up from Home Depot and all this stuff cost about 75 bucks for our shelves I found a piece of laminated pine at a local lumber store which I really like the look of for about 20 bucks here's how each leg goes together once it's fully assembled the overall height of the bookshelf will be about 36 inches tall so the first thing I did was rip my piece of wood to the width that I wanted then I crosscut the lengths of the shelf the overall dimensions of each shelf are 12 inches deep by 24 inches wide next I'm clamping to three shelves together so that I can measure and mark where I'm going to be drilling the holes for each piece of pipe to pass through I want the holes exactly lined up so that when I go to put the thing together later it doesn't move on me and the shelves don't match up exactly and the thing come out of whack the overall diameter of the pipe is about an inch in 16 and I chose to drill the holes with a pinch in 1/8 force in a bit if I were to do this again I think I would use the 1 inch Forstner bit and then ream out the hole a little bit with some sandpaper so that the pipe was title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey there welcome to DIY projects with Pete today we're going to build some floating shelves let's get started the first step is to frame out the shelf support we'll start by ripping a 2x4 down to two and a half inches wide on the table saw and if you'd like a thinner shelf you can rip the board even narrower or use a standard two by two next use a miter saw or a circular saw to cut the length for each board cut the ledger board to the approximate width of the shelf and then the shorter boards which will be the depth of the shelf I cut the shorter boards to eight and a half inches which will make the final overall shelf dimensions roughly 33 inches wide by 11 inches deep then lay out the five boards that are part of the shelf support we'll attach each shorter board to the ledger using two 3-inch long screws and some wood glue use clamps to help hold the boards in place if needed then pre-drill and put the screws in through the back of the ledger into the shorter board use a square to ensure everything is lined up correctly and once the two outer boards are attached evenly spaced the two inside boards or spaced them as needed to make it easiest to mount to your wall attach the inside boards using the same method or if you prefer use pocket holes simply drill each pocket hole using a jig and then attach with glue and two and a half inch screws then do a quick sanding to remove rough edges and to smooth things out next we'll build the box that will slide onto the shelf support I used cedar fence pickets to keep costs down and because I like the gray weather finish you can get with the steel wool and vinegar stain but feel free to use any type of wood you like because I use pickets I needed to use two boards on the top and bottom to be able to have a deeper shelf the measurements I used can be found in the free plans at DIY Pete comm forward slash floating shelves cut the length of each board down to size next put the boards in place to simulate how the Shelf will look I like to use the frame support to hold everything in place during assembly and then butter up the ends of the boards with wood glue and attach the sides using an 8 move onto the other side and repeat the process use clamps if needed to hold boards together during assembly then pull out the shelf support and attach the front piece of the shelf box with wood glue and nails sand the entire shelf box using a sander and 220 grit sandpaper this is going to give the board's a smooth finish and it's also going to remove excess dried glue next go ahead and add a finish for the shelf I patina the wood to give it a gray weathered look using a steel wool and a vinegar solution and if you'd like to do the same you can check out the video tutorial on how to make it by clicking on the link in the description below feel free to stain or paint the Shelf to best fit your space and simply brush on the solution let it react with the tannins in the wood and dry for at least an hour then seal the wood I used a water-based spray sealer that dries clear and keeps the wood the gray color and here's a look at how the wood darkens to a brown color when sealed using an oil-based stain allow the sealer to dry and then get ready to mount your new shelves to the wall use a stud finder to determine where you'll attach the shelf support the studs are typically 16 inches on center use drywall anchors if needed for your particular situation then pre-drill through the wood and attach to the wall using 3-inch long wood screws I used 2 for each stud and the shelf support was rock-solid then grab the shelf and simply push it into place it should have a nice snug fit I installed one additional shelf below and here's an up close shot of how the box slides over the shelf support you can see it's pretty slick how it slides into place and you can use a few screws to secure the box to the shelf support from the top if needed and that's all there is to it load up the shelves and enjoy the free plans can be downloaded at DIY P comm forward slash floating shelves thanks so much for watching please subscribe and give this video a thumbs up if you found it helpful and Cheers from Montana and for free DIY inspiration and updates on the latest projects make sure to head over to the website to join the email list it only takes a minute cheers guys

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hi I'm Matt and I'm Jackie and we're the husband-and-wife team that make up the DIY village we're here today on behalf of homes.com to bring you a tutorial on how to build your own custom built-in bookshelves today we're working in my craft room we're going to be using the space around the window that is often wasted between the wall and the window casing we're going to be going from the floor to the ceiling so that we can get the most out of this space going vertical is probably the best way you can go so that you can get lots of storage plus built in is going to give us a really upgraded professional look in the house and going to return some value in what we spend on the materials too so now we're going to be making the base for the bookshelf we're using 1 by 3 stock we've cut them down to the measurements based on the area we're working in and we're going to put these together using the Kreg jig jr. and that's a product that allows you to easily join pieces of wood together make really really strong joints to give you a little idea how it works these gray areas here are sliders they have measurements on each side and those measurements are correspond with the width of the wood you're working with so these boards are 3/4 inch thick and what we'll do is we'll slide these over to where they are on the 3/4 inch marks that leaves a little bit of a lip right there so that as we are ready to drill the pocket holes will put the jig in place by pushing it flush up against the end of the wood and we'll take this clamp and we'll go ahead and clamp them in place and then Jackie is going to drill the pocket hole we'll clamp off check out the dust and we have pocket holes very very strong joints that will flip it to the opposite side and we'll do the exact same thing the way this is going to work is when we have all the pocket holes drill will take longer pieces here and will join them together with the shorter pieces using screws that are made for pocket holes the inside pieces will clamp in place and then screw them in okay we're ready to start building the bookcase it's a very simple process we're going to be using our 1 by 12 we've already cut them length to length and we've cut the top to length but what you're looking at here are two sides and the top we're going to connect these using the same system we used for the base the Kreg jig Junior we're going to get pocket holes in the side pieces and those screws will attach through the side piece into the top piece pulling this joint tight we'll do the same thing on this side about halfway down we're going to cut a shelf that will be a fixed shelf we're going to measure it to fit inside between the the two sides and in the pocket holes will actually be drilled on the sides of the fixed shelf and go into the sides here of these then we'll do the bottom piece exactly the same way we did this one like I said a very simple process so we'll go ahead and get that going and we'll move on to getting the adjustable shelf side okay so we've gone ahead and we've attached the side to the bottom and top and we've added a fixed shelf in the center what we're going to do now is we're going to make the pin holes for the adjustable shelves we're going to use the Kreg shelf pin jig we've got two of them and makes it really easy to use so what we're going to do is we're going to measure up we've measured about halfway from the bottom to where the edge of the Shelf pin jig meets we've clamped it in place and now we're going place the other one here we're going to clamp it in place as well and now Jackie's going to go ahead and using the bit that comes with the Shelf pin jig she's going to go ahead and drill the holes for the adjustable shelving nice thing about using the Shelf pin jig instead of using something like pegboard is the Shelf pin jig has a steel collar in the inside and so your drill bits not going to walk you're going to get a pretty precise drill bit hole for your shelter now we're we're all done with the construction of the frame of the bookcase we need to prep a few things in the craft room before we can actually do a drive fit we need to remove the baseboard in the area that we're going to put in the the platform base so I'm going to use an oscillating cutting tool to do that it's got a shaking blade it's kind of loud so definitely what I have hearing protection on and eye protection to so we're going to go ahead and do that one thing to keep in mind when you're removing the baseboards is you will have to come back in and use a utility knife and where it's been cocked in place before you'll need to score that area all right now we've got the baseboard out of the way we can go ahead and take our platform base and put it in place now I'm going to take the bookcase and we're going to dry fit it to make sure that we don't need to make any adjustments all right that's not bad it's pretty tight you might have to cut off a little bit more base over here just to get that flush up against the wall while I'm doing that though I might go ahead mark what I need to mark and have Jacquie go ahead and start painting well as you might be able to see we've done a few things to add some bulk to the bookcase we went ahead and installed it in place and secured it against a stud over here in this wall definitely want to make sure it's secure in place we have a little one running around and we definitely do not want this falling anywhere we've also added some one by two trim here on the sides and also on this fixed shelf here we added the adjustable shelves here and one on the bottom and the nice thing about how many chef's pin holes we drilled when we were outside is we have the flexibility of adding a couple more shelves we definitely have more room here and on the bottom four shelves if we want to add any more in the future so up here you can see we've added the crown molding to the top that kind of adds a built-in look about it and then down here at the bottom we matched the the base molding that was already existing in the room and we continued it around the bookcase so it has a true built in feel one nice thing that Jackie did when it came to decorating this is she combined organization and storage with the core so she took some of the stuff she might normally not have out showcasing and put sort of on display on the bookcase but she also has all the stores she needs for all her materials on behalf of homes comm thanks for joining us be sure to subscribe to homes comm youtube channel and be on the lookout for our next video tutorial you

content: okay so the brothers coming along pretty well you can see behind me here I've got my my hot water tank and and pump hooked up for the in-floor heating got my ski rack and the canoes hung and what I really want to focus on today is that there are these shelves that I put up along the ceiling here suspended shelf system that I came up with really cheap and easy way to do it you know to go online on Amazon or to go to Home Depot and you know buy a section of shelving from here to here like four feet you're looking at like 200 dollars and I figured out a way to do this for I don't know that probably that section right there probably cost me like five bucks maybe you know a little bit of time and effort but you know I think it's worth it now that it's done and it's I've got my spare tire summer tires and everything up there so it can hold quite a bit of weight so yeah I'll take a second and show you how I how I did this so basically all you'll need for this project is some three-eighths inch plywood some two by twos or two by fours that that you that you rip I've just taken this 2x4 this ripped it and has some three inch screws maybe one and three-quarter inch screws using an 8 screws four for the shelves and and that should that should be about that all you need if you're going to use 3/8 inch plywood make sure you cut your strips along the totally and don't do them across the board because they're not it's not as strong that way so make sure you cut them sort of up and down that way okay so basically the first thing I did was I cut two two inch strips full eight feet in length and those are the bottom strips for the shell after cutting those I then cut a four inch wide strip in the four inch wide strip is the upright support for the shelf this is basically what keeps the shelf from falling falling to the floor once those strips are cut the four inch strips I cut to the height of the shelf plus two inches for the before the scrips at the bottom in my case it was 34 inches now the shelf with itself I cut with a full sheet of 3/8 inch plywood in this case I do the shelf with was 26 inches using my skill saw which I felt easier to do than using my table saw I just cut the machine to the appropriate width as far as building the shelf goes so you've got your two two inch strips that are eight feet long and then your appropriative sized four inch strips first four inch strip you're going to put it half on half off the two inch strip going to move over to the four feet or the middle of your of your run on the two inch strip put your your next up right there take a square and make sure that it's that everything is square on and then your second two inch strip simply just goes over top of it like that now the pattern of the screws is important don't just drive screws three screws across like this it's not going to be as strong drive two screws one here one here flip the whole assembly over and then put your next screw here and here that'll make it very very strong you might be wondering why is this this board half on half off so when you get to your next shelf as you can see right here the upright strip the next lower piece two inch strip going across meeting on that same upright all right now that assembly is built you're going to want to mount it to the wall what I did was into a level line so that I have the back support perfectly level and then took my square and through the depth of the Shelf off the upper wall using the back support which is just as simply a two by two that screwed directly into each one of the joists make sure you screwed into the joists otherwise it won't stay up same thing on the ceiling screw it into each one of the rafters I just used number a three inch screws if you want to make it stronger you can use lag bolts okay so then using the assembly we just put together line it up with the previous shelf clamp it into place and then screw I appropriately the uprights what I used was a square of three-eighths inch plywood that I cut from from the four inch strip and I screwed into that into the plywood and any into the two by two making it really strong now you also have to notch out where the uprights meet the bottom support in order for the shelf to simply just drop into place as it does here you can see where I've knocked it around the upright support then using one and a half inch screws you can screw into the back bunch supports to secure the shelf support is ready for the next shelf to come on the end there it is I'm going to take a section of the 2x2 and where the two sheets of plywood meet in the middle I'm just going to put that as a support the bottom of the shelf right here up at the top of the support there cut you know scraps of plywood and screw that in instead of screwing like directly into into the plywood so one of the questions you might ask speaking of speaking of that is why not just build this at a two by fours well I mean one it's this is this is a little bit cheaper and two plywood is actually really good in tension it has a really good tensile strength two by fours do as well but when you screw into a 2x4 especially up at the ends like that you run the risk of splitting the 2x4 whereas with plywood because of its it's biaxial you don't have that don't have that issue if you wanted to make the system even stronger use some lag screws same thing with the screws down here and then to make this shelf stiffer you just make these pieces the the bottom strips there you make them thicker and and that'll make the shelf title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hi everybody welcome back and I'm so happy we hit a hundred subscribers thank you guys so much so for this video I'm going to be showing you guys how to make these awesome hexagons floating shelves without any further ado let's get into the video so all you're going to need to make this is popsicle sticks spray paint and how cool soap alright the first thing we did was arrange my popsicle sticks in a hexagon pattern because I wanted hexagons shells after arranging them I glued them all down when the base of your shelf is finished it's time to actually make your shelf for this you want to glue your popsicle stick on top of two overlapping popsicle sticks you I made three shelves and each of them were 15 layers after I was satisfied with the design I counted each of the sides to make sure they were even you then I attached my three shelves together using hot glue I then took the shelves outside and spray-painted them after letting them dry completely I hung them onto the wall using pushpins thank you guys so much for watching if you enjoyed this video please make sure to hit the like button and subscribe to my channel if you haven't already I'll see you guys next time bye

to build your own shelves and make them fit snugly without any gaps so in order to save time on this video we've gone ahead and what we've done is installed 5/8 inch furring strips and basically I got them for 89 cents per foot at my local lumber warehouse and I went ahead and primed and painted them white and then where we could find studs in the walls we went ahead and drilled holes pre-drilled and attached these furring strips to the walls and these furring strips will be the will hold our shelf and I liked using furring strips they're they're more sturdy than your brackets and they're also less obtrusive than your triangular brackets that you see now after we installed these furring strips here to hold the shelf it's time to actually cut the shelf to fit and this is the tricky part and we actually have a tip for you on how to do this so I'm going to bring my dad back in our master carpenter and he's gonna he's going to explain the concept of scribing okay Susan what we've done here we selected the piece you want to make for your shelf you want to cut it to fit this is a piece of normal Rock run-of-the-mill particle board with a melamine covering on it that we bought down at Lowe's or wherever and we're going to scribe this to v as well now I've added some blue painters tape on this edge for a couple of reasons we can mark that tape and put the tape on it keeps the chipping and the spoiling whenever you make the cut to a minimum and it lets your saver so right on the tape instead of scratching the surface so the way you do the scribe is you have to get this in there where you can get to it and what I do is turn the piece up when it's this way set it in the closet on an angle now this piece is two inches bigger than the hole that we're fitting it in so put it on an angle this way we're going to scribe this side push it back tight against the back wall and then if you don't have one you need to get a common set of scribes carpenters call it subscribe some people call it a compass for drawing several but you want one that has a little locking wing that it locks the the adjustment on it pretty snug now we know this is two inches too big so I'm going to set these for one inch approximately one inch down here from point to point we're going to make a mark on this board that rides this wall that changes transfers the profile of this wall out of square to this board and it's done this way we've set this compass for one inch approximately one inch width because the piece is two inches too big for the holes we want to take half that distance off one inch so because we have to cut the other side in like manner later and we'll show you that after bet now what we do is take this compass set it for one inch or approximately and let it ride the back this this wall the pin side of your compass rides the wall and the pencil makes the mark on your piece on your tape and you just pull that towards you and let the compass ride the wall clear out and then it is transferred a mark unto this board coinciding with the profile of this one okay so now what some people don't cut the tape on the board as I said to minimize the small and the scratch from the saw some folks like to take a regular single knife like this and on your pencil mark you have in here kind of scratch or scratch that with the shingle knife and that little bit of a scouring helps to keep from this melamine surface from spoiling to some degree and keep it to a minimum now we're going to use a saber saw because if your wall has the profile you're gonna have to move that saw little bit to transfer that angle when it cutter that or to ride that curve of that at mark so this is a time for the safety glasses as we all know follow that mark that you put on there title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: today we built some hexagon shelves also known as honeycomb shelves after we cut the pieces the first step was to sand then we laid out a tarp and applied a couple coats of stain after the stain had dried we fit the pieces together with glue before screen the pieces together we had to pre-drill the holes it was time to take the project outside for painting we taped off the outside and applied two coats of gold paint this project is really fun because it's so diverse I'm thinking about hanging it on a wall but it would also look great on an existing shelf with a succulent or some books in it if you don't want to miss out on any of our upcoming projects make sure to subscribe to our YouTube channel and if you have any ideas of projects you want us to build leave a comment below
