title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: what's going on buddy I'm Johnny Brook welcome back into the crafting workshop video in today's video I'm going to be showing you how to build these simple DIY floating shelves so I built these out of some fancier hardwoods I used bubinga on this bottom shelf and soft maple on the top shelf but if you don't have the machinery required to mill rough lumber you could build this out of something like a 2 by 8 from your local home center and build these with nothing but a circular saw to cut the board's the length a drill to cut the holes in the back for the floating shelf hardware as well as cut the holes for the dowels and in the doweling jig itself which is only about 20 bucks so this is a great beginners woodworking project and if you build that of a 2 by 8 you can paint it or stain it to match the look to your hero 4 so let's go ahead and get started with the build so as I said in the intro if you don't have access to the tools required to mill rough lumber you can either buy s4s lumber from your local lumber dealer which means it's already surfaced on all sides or you could use something like a 2 by 8 from your local home center so the first step since I was using rough lumber was squaring up the wood using my jointer planer and table saw so I started by joining one edge on the jointer then cut the shelf pieces to rough linked on the miter saw so the dimensions of the shelf pieces are 18 inches long by 6 inches wide for the top and bottom pieces and 5 and a half inches long by 6 inches wide for the side pieces so I left the two side pieces of the shelves as 1 11 inch piece since they would have been too short to pass through my planer otherwise so next I flatten one face and one edge on the jointer and this gives me a reference surface for the next steps in squaring up the boards so with one face flat I could put that base downwards on the planer and bring the opposing face parallel and this is one of my favorite parts of woodworking it's almost like unwrapping the piece of wood since you really don't know what's below the rough surface until this point and this was my first time working with bubinga and it is just absolutely gorgeous so I also brought all the boards down to roughly an inch and 1/8 thick while at the planer next I squared up the other edge of the boards on the table saw also ripping the boards to their final width of six inches and finally I cut the boards to their final length at the miter saw squaring up one end before cutting the other end to length so what the boards cut to size I could start laying out the joinery for this build I used the Rockler half inch dowel drilling jig kit and so the first step was to mark lines where I wanted to put my dowels and placement here wasn't super critical since the shelves won't be supporting a ton of weight mostly just knick knacks and that kind of thing and half inch dowels will provide a ton of strength next I set the depth on the drill bit that's included with the kit since I definitely didn't want to drill through the face of the shelves and with the depth set I started drilling my dowel holes so one key when using these jigs is to make sure to clamp the jig tightly so that it doesn't move and I didn't clamp the jig tightly enough when drilling a few of these holes and this caused my shelf pieces to be slightly misaligned a little later on so with the top and bottom boards done I moved on to drilling holes in the sides so first I reset my depths again using a dowel for reference and the process was basically the same as the top and bottom boards except on the sides I was drilling into the ends of the board and once again just make sure to clamp the jig down tightly so it doesn't move so once all the holes were drilled it was time for assembly I added glue to the half inch dowels and then pounded them into the corresponding holes and make sure not to add too much glue since it'll create too much pressure for the dowel to seat fully and you can see that I had some trouble with this when I went to put the shelf together since I had added a bunch of glue to the dowel holes but luckily a little clamping pressure got rid of the gaps so while I assembled the maple shelf let's talk about one of the sponsors of this week's video Rockler so I used a ton of rock lip products during this build including their dowel drilling jig blind shelf supports and their ever trusting glue brush and I'll have links to all the items I used in the video description below so Rockler has got tons of great tools and accessories for your next build and they're always coming up with new and innovative ideas to help make your woodworking more efficient and more enjoyable so thanks again to Rockler for sponsoring this build after the glue dried I cleaned up any mints and linemen and the shelves with a hand playing off camera and since hopefully you won't run into this problem and then added a chamfer to all the edges with a router so this is obviously an optional step but it really gives the shelves a nice look also having my wagon bites on my new workbench makes workholding during routing a breeze man I love that thing so after routing I squared up the inside corners with a chisel since the router leaves a rounded edge there next I laid out the hole locations for the blind shelf supports and these supports need to be mounted to studs so I space the hole 16 inches on center and I also centered the holes along the thickness of the shelves and then used a center punch to mark the location so to drill the holes I used my drill press which is highly recommended if you have access to one but if not just make sure to use a square or a drilling guide to keep the hole as square as possible next I saying that both shelves up to 180 grit making sure to remove any burn marks from the router and also hand sanded all the chambers to really smooth them out for finish I used water locks another one of this week's sponsors and water locks is a blend of tung oil and resins and creates a really tough water resistant finish that is also absolutely beautiful the tung oil penetrates into the wood while the resins remain elastic and this combination holds up to we're extremely well to learn more about water locks check out the link in the video description below and in total I applied three coats of water locks letting the finish dry for 24 hours between coats and finally it was time to hang the shelves so I used a stud finder to mark the locations of my studs and then I mounted one of the blind shelf supports to the stud using two and a half inch screws so to mark the location of the other shelf support I put the shelf post itself into the hole in the back of the shelf with the set screw that's included with the shelf hardware installed then I leveled the Shelf and then put pressure on the Shelf to mark the exact location on the wall so I installed the other shelf support and then did a test fit of the Shelf and it looks great so with the first shelf done I could mark the location for the top shelf I made sure my marks were plumbed to the first shelf using a level so the shelves would line up and I spaced the upper shelf 10 inches above the lower shelf so they were arranged in a square so I solved the shelf hardware for the upper shelf the same way I did for the lower shelf and with both shelves in place the project was done man did I say shelf enough times there alright hopefully you guys enjoyed this one this is a nice simple project but I'm really happy with the look I actually got inspired to build these from my local eye doctor believe it or not they had a whole wall full of shelves that look like this and so I'm hoping to kind of expand this shelving over time this is great if you have like one single board of a certain type of wood that you couldn't really build a whole project out of this really doesn't require a ton of wood and the result is beautiful so if you guys enjoyed this one go ahead and get subscribed I put out new project videos like this every week also I have a list of all the materials and tools I use down in the description below also a big shout-out to all my supporters over on patreon of a list of my $10 patrons here on the screen you guys want to join up I'll also have a link to patreon alright guys thanks again for watching and until next time happy building

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: okay this week I'm going to be working in this corner I'm not a huge fan of this corner thing and both me my husband have been wanting a bookcase or bookshelves somewhere around the house but I don't have too many other places to put it other than here so looking at this corner I think that I want to make some floating shelves corner shelves some corner shelves floating shelves some corner floating shelves that will hold books let's get going I'll be making all of my shelves from 2x4 and quarter-inch plywood and I do have a free plan available on my website the first thing I did was take all the two by fours and cut them to the width needed at the table saw then I set up a stop block at the miter saw and cut all of my pieces to length next I repeated the process using the quarter inch plywood this will be used to make up the top and bottoms of the shelves after cutting them to width then I moved over to the miter saw and set up a stop block and cut them to length now to actually start making the inside of the shelves I grabbed the two by fours and used a countersink bit first before joining them together now I make sure to put the cut edge of the 2x4 pieces always facing the outside edge that way that it'll either butt up against the wall or be the exposed edge later on also I used a spacer to just make installing these inside pieces easier then I would grab one of the quarter inch plywood surfaces and attach it using my nailer now for the time being I only attached one surface so that I wouldn't have a tight spot for my drill whenever installing these I was mostly done building the shelves when I decided to make the two bottom shelves a little bit deeper and I didn't have enough quarters material to cut two new surfaces so I ended up just using a patch piece to make sure that all of the ends were as flush as possible I grabbed my belt sander and attached it to my workbench which is a really awesome feature by the way and then just grab each shelf individually and ran each side over the sandpaper to make sure that it was nice and smooth then I laid out all of the shelves and used joint compound to fill in any of the imperfections or those patched lines that I created and while that compound was drawing I decided to go ahead and make some molding this is really exciting for me because it's my first time really getting to use my router table I made the molding from some scrap two-by-fours that I had and I was just so pleased with the results I made two or three passes to get the profile completely cut in I found out with this bit I was able to get two profiles cut on one side of a 2x4 after getting all four cut in I took it over to the table saw and resold it in half then I laid it down flat and cut it in half to get the four separate pieces next size I apply two coats of paint to the shelves and while that was dry and cut all the different molding pieces to the links needed using a miter on all of the ends then spent a little bit of time cleaning them up with a chisel and sandpaper then I also gave them a few coats of paint as well when I came to actually installing the shows I cut a few spacers to make life easier and I would first set the shelf in place making sure it was level to pre-drill the location of the studs and also mark where I was going to need a drywall anchor then I was able to set the Shelf back into place and attach it permanently with the screws with the long shelf attached I came back and repeated the steps with the shorter shelf using a clamp to help hold it in place when it came time to attach those front surfaces again I used a countersink bit first and I just repeated the same exact steps for all of the other shelves so you can see they do I mean these things are sturdy they're going to be perfect for holding books I can't be more queasy after they were all installed I went through and nailed on all the bottoms then it was time to - the molding and that's when I found a mistake so big mistakes silly mistake whenever I was making this molding the height of it I did not take into consideration the bottom that I was gonna be adding so now this molding is under flush I went ahead and installed the pieces and what I'll do is come back later and make a kind of filling moulding part that will fill up that gap I came through and just attach these with the brad nailer now since my walls are a little bit curved I did come through on the back ends and apply a line of caulking then with everything dry it was just a matter of applying one last coat of touch-up paint yeah I didn't realize how big this corner was with that small little corner milk in here I think that these shells just really open it up and I can't believe we're pleased with the way that it looks I mean it's definitely give us a lot more function to this corner but aesthetically I'm just way more in love with this look but I'm really happy with how sturdy they are as well those wall anchors are no joke it was a very simple project I did mess up the molding but other than that it went really smooth so if you would like to go in your own I do have a very simple set of plans for these shelves on my website of walk reduce calm so check that out and that's it for this one um I will see you the next time I'm working on something guys I'll have to climb into the attic to get the rest of our books real quick I want to say a big thank you to lynda.com for sponsoring this video and supporting what I do now if you don't know lynda.com is a website that has online video tutorials available for one flat monthly fee they have a ton of topics that range from education to animation to music to design and all classes are taught by professionals that are passionate about teaching so the information that you're getting is not only clearly given but it's also very accurate if there's something that you've been wanting to learn let's just say designing a website then you can go to London comm and take an entire course on that subject and it'll walk you through from the very beginning all the way to the very end and what I really like is there's an index given to you to where if you already know about a subject you can very easily skip to the next chapter and of course with it being online you can learn at your own pace it's a pretty cool website that I've been able to get plenty of use out of so again if you would like a free 7-day trial then go to lynda.com slash April

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: you hello I'm Matt welcome back to workshop my workshop space a country pub that also does bed and breakfasts there always asked me to do things around the place and the most recent thing is to do something for our hotel rooms is a little small so that wants me to do a nightstand corner shelf so let's get started as you can see the room is a bit tight for space the first thing to do is get the old bedside table out of the way I'm checking see if the corner is actually square but of course that'd be too easy and it's not I'm using a sliding bevel to determine the actual angle of the corner with the angle determined I've made a template for the bedside table out of a bit of cardboard that I can just trace it on some plywood ready to be cut out I'm ripping down a sheet of plywood to the correct size and dropping it down on the miter saw using the bandsaw to cut the curve out cutting out two pieces so the nightstand can have a shelf I clamp both pieces in the vise and then using the random orbital sander sand down to the pencil line just cutting the back pieces and the side pieces for the shelf to attach the size the base I'm just gluing and then Brad nailing them on then I can touch the top which again I'm just gluing and Brad nailing the excess wood on the side on the back I'm just cutting off with a handsaw then sanding it to a nice curve I'm using a roundover bit in the router to give the front a nice curved edge drilling a hole in the back corner so that a cord for a bedside lamp can be run for it put it some marks on the back on the side then putting some holes on the marks later these holes are what I'm going to put screws through to attach it to the wall that's all the construction done so now a code funder code then two coats of gloss I also gave it two coats of varnish to make it extra hard wearing for a hotel room I'm holding it up at the same level as what the other table was at making sure it's level and then just making marks where the holes need to go it's a bit tricky to work in such a tight space then I could put holes in the wall where I've made my marks and put some plugs in to attach it to then he could just be screwed onto the wall that's it all done the client was pleased with how it turned out and it made the room look a lot bigger thanks for watching and please subscribe for more

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: welcome to DIY crafts com how to make a secret compartment floating shelf available on DIY easy crafts com you can download free plans you will have to purchase cabinet hinges these are full overlay cabinet hinges available at home depot or any other hardware store there are basically two assemblies to this floating shelf the wall assembly and the hinged front assembly we're working on the wall assembly first and bottom of that unit attaches to the back just with wood glue and some screws the sides also attach in the same manner with wood glue and screws but please be sure to insert these sides about an eighth of an inch in from the absolute end of that wall unit the reason for this is that when the hinged front is sliding over it you don't want it to have to rub in those signs and you could even put those in a half inches the only reason for the sides is to give support to the top which will be screwed on at a later time alright we're now moving on to the front hinged assembly and this is basically just three pieces of wood the front and two sides again they are assembled with wood glue and screws and once this is assembled you'll see that that the front folding assembly is actually slightly longer than the wall assembly so it just slides right into place we're just going to lay the top in place right now it's actually easier to work on this unit without the top screwed in place and that's how the front folds away now I tried to do this with a couple of different 2 inches piano hinges with standard hinges there's just no way of doing it without an exposed portion of the hinge which would give away the secret compartment so really the best thing to do is to use the cabinet hinges as as explained earlier you will have to purchase a tool that can be inserted into any drill it's just a small router and it comes with its own Jake for Logan to them you just mark the location from the edge of the wood and then that you router a whole basically just the death of the rabbit and the hinge just it's inserted into that once the hole is aboard the hinges just screw into place with small screws which are included the size of this floating shelf can be varied you can make it longer you could make it a little bit shorter this one's about 24 inches long you do want to be able to grab two studs so the minimum that you'd want to make it width wise would probably be in the 18 inch range but you could certainly make it longer we're going to encase the entire outside with molding and in this case I've taken small molding and I'm going to attach it with wood glue and some finishing nails to the very top edge of the box I'm then going to cut some additional strips of pine to fill in the void on the bottom but first I'll put all the molding along the top this is the the side molding which I've kind when us when attaching this molding be sure that you don't drive finishing nails all the way through because you basically just mean the hinged front assembly to the inner box and you prevent it from opening you can use finishing nails at the very end where it's going through the edge of the pine or you can hammer a finishing nail you know about halfway through just attack it into position while that wood glue dries very important before you attach the bottom piece of pine to cover the bottom of the box you have to break the edge on the very front bottom edge of the wall assembly the reason for that is when you attach that final piece of pine it would actually bind preventing that front assembly from folding outward and you can do this with a file you could do it with a sander using a disc sander any way that you want to break that edge and this is the piece of pine I just cut it to the right height cut 45s in both sides and I'll attach that also with wood glue and a couple of finishing nails again i'm going to use those finishing nails just on the ends I'm not going to nail through the you know through the front folding assembly and we're almost done this is the ends or the sides of the finish pine which will finish the molding and then once we paint sand and paint this unit and fill in all the little creases with some corking it will look as if it's just solid molding encasing the entire box and again the finishing nails not all the way I learned that the hard way and the floating shelf is basically almost done we're just going to attach the top which in this case is a half inch piece of plywood finished on one side a little bit of wood glue and some finishing nails is it very easy to make project and there are a downloadable PDF plans and a complete cut sheet available on WWD I why easy crafts com we're going to attach this unit to the wall with some large flat-head actually torque head screws I like these they're available at home depot or any other hardware store there about four and a half inches long and they're very very much again each of these floating shelves should be attached to a minimum of two studs and the finished product the neat thing about it is you can leave whatever's on that upper shelf in place they can access whatever it is that you want to hide please check us out on the web at DIY easy crafts com be sure to check out our other how-to videos and please subscribe to this YouTube channel you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: Hey guys, Again Mr ATC and welcome back to MyATCtv!!! Today we are going to create a nice DIY floating shelf for the bathroom and for less than 15 euros… For this project, I have been invited to work on a new bathroom design in Paris and the goal was adding a simple DIY floating shelf in this corner as you can see just right here which is measuring  23 cm large… The owner of this apartment couldn’t find the right furniture for this spot so ask me to design it... And as you already know as soon when it’s about making, I am all IN!!! That’s the reason why, I’ve decided to share this project with you in case you find yourself experiencing the same problem at home… Alright!!!! So enough talking let’s make it happen!!! To make this shelf you don’t really require a lot of tools, here I am making it with 2 pieces of lumber from 1 meter long, 20 cm large and 1.9 cm thick Here Each of the 3 shelves will be cut at 20 cm large and 21 cm long in order to be inserted into the main back piece I gonna  start by cutting the different shelves pieces first and note that for this I am using a minor saw but you could also use a handsaw or jigsaw depending of what you have available. To insert the different shelves, i am here taking some marks in order to cut using my router and making a deep cut at 0.7cm… then I decided to place the shelves to have a first testing look and also trace a line giving me their exact thickness to follow with my router Yeah, looks like I like it already… Alright time to use the router! Here if you decide to use a router, remember to be very precise in order to cut just on the line. Here to make sure the shelves are staying in place and with an angle of 90 degrees I decided to drill some holes in order to insert screws from the back (so when looking in front of the shelves, they should be invisible) and keeping this all creation strong and stable Then I am sanding a little bit to avoid having any side particles while trying to slide the 3 shelves to the holes… For the finish, I’ve decided to use some invisible lacquer to keep the real wood texture and spirit as I really liked it.. Even if the color in the bathroom was mainly gray, i thought that adding a wood spirit with this DIY shelf could create a very nice additional design And here we are with a cool DIY bathroom shelf. Guys as usual, remember that you will be able to find below in the video description links a free plan to this creation if you want to make it yourself And don’t forget to share with us your own creations via the ATC App, you will have a link showing up just above this video Feel free to check it out!!! I really hope that you liked this project, and as usual, Mr ATC for another idea of housing!!!! See you next time and don’t forget to share, subscribe and comment below the video… Bye….

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: welcome to extreme how to in this video we'll learn how to build a simple shelf that mounts to the wall in this particular case I needed a shelf at least 14 inches deep to hold this satellite receiver beneath the wall-mounted television set now when I went to the hardware store the deepest shelf I could find was only 12 inches that meant I had to build my own and here's how I did it this satellite receiver was resting on the dresser we wanted to mount it to the wall to keep clutter off the dresser and also conceal the cables behind the drywall first step is to determine your shelf size and cut the shelf to shape I cut the Shelf from plywood that had an oak finish I then added solid oak edging to give the appearance of a solid wood shelf while saving money on materials my shelf measured 14 by 21 inches but you can make yours virtually any size I used a table saw to rip the 3/4 inch oak boards into quarter-inch thick strips I then made 45-degree cuts in the edging using a miter saw with each strip measured to fit over the exposed edges of the Shelf test fit your edging and then attach the strips with finish nails and a high-quality wood glue brush the glue onto the joints for even coverage and be sure to apply glue to the miters for a tight connection pre-drill all of the nail holes to avoid splitting the wood countersink the nails with a nail set fill the holes with a stainable wood putty allow it to dry and then sand the putty smooth the wood putty can also be used to fill any joint lines in the edging with the shelf assembled I sanded it smooth added some wood stain and two coats of polyurethane once it was dry I screwed on my two shelf brackets which I centered on the underside of the shelf and spaced 16 inches apart to mount into the wall studs if you're building a large shelf you should mount your brackets on the wall first then add your shelf next I used a stud finder to locate the wall studs I marked their locations and screwed in the shelf brackets using 3-inch panhead screws I used a torpedo level to check my positioning before placing the satellite receiver I used a hole saw to drill two holes in the wall one at the shelf and one at the floor I ran some fish tape through the wall I attached the TV and receiver wires then rounded them behind the wall board to conceal them from view I added computer grommets over the holes for a finished look once the job was done the TV and dresser were much more organized and free of clutter

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hi I'm Chris of mandate mondays today we're going to be showing you how to make iron pipe shelfing iron pipe shopping is a fantastic industrial feel you can add to almost any room for the materials are going to need wood for the shelf and iron piping for the supports holding the shelf up from the wall now for the shelves we're using 10 inch by 2 inch planks of wood depending on the length depends on how many shelves you want to make 4 iron piping each shelf will need four half-inch flanges two half-inch two and a half inch nipples two half-inch four and a half inch nipples and two half-inch ninety degree elbows now you can pick up all these materials at your local hardware store but the iron piping was so expensive we decided to buy it on Amazon because it was half the price so click on one of the links around here to get to the list on Amazon to buy the iron pipes and save yourself some money first measure and cut the plank to the desired size of your shelves then give the planks of good sanding with an 80 grit sandpaper now that we're done sanding it's time to start staining we're going to go with the dark walnut because it gives out a nice brown tone of the wood without going too dark like an espresso finish you of course can choose any style stain you'd like to use now that we finish standing we're going to let this sit for a couple of hours to dry we're also going to want to add at least two coats of polyurethane after this is dried to help protect the wood and make it a lot easier to clean in the long run so now that the shelves have been Polident it dry it's time to start creating the piping supports we're going to use to mount them to the wall take the flange put the longer nipple into that one tighten it up a bit take our 90 degree connector tighten that on we'll add our smaller nipple into the top of that finish it off with the other flange come on now we've got our supports now that the arms are assembled we're going to start mounting them to the shelves where you place these is really up to you but for our shelves we're going to go seven inches in from each side once you're happy with their placement mark all the holes so you can pilot them with a drill to mount the arms to the shelves we are using 3/4 inch wood screws find a spot you want to install the shelf on the wall make sure your level and mark your pylons if you're drilling into drywall you will need drywall anchors once you're done install your other shelves and you've just created and install your own iron pipe shelving

first measure and cut the plank to the
desired size of your shelves then give
the planks of good sanding with an 80
grit sandpaper now that we're done
sanding it's time to start staining
we're going to go with the dark walnut
because it gives out a nice brown tone
of the wood without going too dark like
an espresso finish you of course can
choose any style stain you'd like to use
now that we finish standing we're going
to let this sit for a couple of hours to
dry we're also going to want to add at
least two coats of polyurethane after
this is dried to help protect the wood
and make it a lot easier to clean in the
long run so now that the shelves have
been Polident it dry it's time to start
creating the piping supports we're going
to use to mount them to the wall take
the flange put the longer nipple into
that one tighten it up a bit
take our 90 degree connector tighten
that on we'll add our smaller nipple
into the top of that finish it off with
the other flange come on now we've got
our supports now that the arms are
assembled we're going to start mounting
them to the shelves where you place
these is really up to you but for our
shelves we're going to go seven inches
in from each side once you're happy with
their placement mark all the holes so
you can pilot them with a drill
to mount the arms to the shelves we are
using 3/4 inch wood screws find a spot
you want to install the shelf on the
wall make sure your level and mark your
pylons if you're drilling into drywall
you will need drywall anchors once
you're done
install your other shelves and you've
just created and install your own iron
pipe shelving

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: today I'm going to build a few shelves from my daughter's pottery and the design for the shelving is inspired by the artist Donald Judd who is a minimalist sculptor and I made this small model to get an example of what one of the sculptures kind of looks like you'd have to imagine this bigger and these cubes made in a different material they were often made in aluminum and plexiglass I'll start by making four boxes the top and the bottom of the boxes will be made out of half-inch birch plywood the tops of the bottoms are on the same measurement so I've set up a stop block and that way I only need to measure once I've got the tops and the bottoms of the box cut and now ready to move on to the walls and that's this part right here and for that I'm using 3/4 inch birch plywood and these are just some odds and ends that have been hanging around the shop it's a good way to use them up and also the 3/4 inch birch plywood will be more stable than using solid wood I've got all of my parts cut and I'm ready to start assembling the boxes I'm going to attach the front to the sides first and then I'll attach the bottoms and the tops I'll use a little wood glue and inch and 3/4 nails in the nail gun and now to attach the tops and the bottoms and just make sure you're flush with the front as you work your way around the box it's always a good idea to use a damp rag to remove any excess glue before it has a chance to set up I finished making all the boxes and the next step is to band the edges to hide the end grain and the plywood up and the two sides in the front now I'm painting the boxes so MDF will work fine but if you wanted to you could also make these boxes out of cherry or I think they look good in walnut just make them out of walnut plywood then band the edges with walnut or you could even laminate a veneer on the boxes even though I know the walls of the box are 2 inches and I've used half inch plywood on the top and the bottom it's still a good idea to take a measurement because sometimes happens plywood can be a little bit light this looks pretty good though so I'll rip the edge banding at 3 inches you Motz new day I've got a few coats of paint on all the boxes and now getting ready to install them I'll install the shelving by the Kachin cleats to the wall and then the shelving will fit over the cleats now I make these cleats out of 3/4 inch birch plywood simply laminating two pieces of plywood together I made them a little bit heavy and then I trim them on the table saw so it's just a nice snug fit in the back of the box the way I like to install a shelving system like this is to first install the bottom cleat now I've only got a stud in the center here so I've pre-drilled encounter some two holes in the cleat and these two screws will catch the stud and at the ends here I'll put a dab of glue and I'll put a screw in to these holes it's only going to hit sheetrock but between the glue and the two screws in the stud that should be more than enough to support shelving this small I've attached a cleat with one screw and made sure that the cleat is level and now I'm ready for the second screw I'm using 3-inch cabinet screws to attach the cleats to make the installation a little easier I've ripped a piece of quarter-inch plywood to 13 inches and this way I'll have the same spacing between each shelf and since the bottom cleat is level all I need to do is attach the second cleat at the line I'm attaching the shelving to the cleats with inch-and-a-quarter drywall screws and I took a minute to spray-paint the screws first and that just looks a little bit nicer Hey well I had a lot of fun with this project and if you think you want to make these shelves I'll put this cut list up on my website just search Donald Judd inspired shelving system now if you have any questions I'm going to answer them and I'm gonna start doing the follow-up video I guess maybe on Wednesdays Tuesday's on Wednesdays and so if you have any questions just leave them in the comments please subscribe also I'm going to start doing a lot more with Facebook so if you've made a project a lot of people have made the projects that I've made here in the shop I'm going to start posting them up on my Facebook and some of the paintings that people make in my painting class now as far as inspiration I like to talk about different artists because I think it's really good to look at a lot of different art and furniture design sculptures because you really never know where your inspiration is going to come from and what I decided to do a video on this project I took a look around on the web and I found a pretty cool interview hour piece that 60 minutes did on Marfa Texas now Donald Judd had bought an abandoned military base in Marfa and that's where most of his sculptures are housed today and it's become kind of a mecca for art and artsy type people and so on one hand you have these ranches that have been around forever and now you have all these kind of artsy people and it's created this sort of nice little coexisting community that it actually looks like a fun place to go visit but if you want to know more about that I'll put a link to the 60 minutes piece in the description of this video thanks for tuning in and I'll see you soon thanks dad one two three go

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
This bathroom is ready to go. We've already had the trade's man in and they've
done the electrics and the plumbing. I want to put something of my own in here,
so I'm going to build a beautiful hardwood floating vanity. It's going to be a real centerpiece for the
bathroom. Here all the tools materials I'm going to
need to make my floating vanity. The first thing we're going to do is join
our two pieces of timber together. I want to make sure I get the nicest faces
up right. Now stands your timber boards up, glue the
edges, lay them back down and clamp them together. As we don't want to damage our timber, we're
just going to use some chalks in between the clamp and the timber. To ensure that the boards don't bark in the
middle when clamping, we're going to put two additional clamps on top. We're now going to remove all the glue from
this side of the board using a chisel and a rag. We use a chisel as this avoids spreading the
glue around. To get these two boards level and remove the
step, we're going to put one block off cut timber underneath, the other on top. And we're going to hammer them level. Now, the timbers all level, we just need to
clean off the excess glue and then leave it to dry. Make sure you follow the drying times in the
back of the glue you've used. Now it's fully dried. I've taken off the clamps and we need to remove
any excess glue that has oozed down, and then flip it and do the other side as well. We're going to sand back our timber. We're going to be using a belt sander here
as it will give us a nice smooth finish, and we want to make sure we have a nice level
finish as well. It's looking great, so we'll send it back. We need to make two of these, so we can repeat
exactly the same process for a second board. You should now have two of these pieces of
timber. They've all been sanded back. You're not going to pick out the best piece
for your top, and you need to mark that and the frontage. The next thing we're going to do is cut the
45 degree miter at one end and then we're going to measure back to give us the length
of our vanity top. Now we've got our top done and miter it out
the way, we're going to follow a similar process on this second board. The three pieces were going to get are the
side panels, the basin and then the miter. Now we need to join the pieces together and
miter them. Before doing this is a really good idea to
mark those pieces are going to join together, so you don't get confused later on. I've now rebated all my mitered corners for
my brackets to fit into. We now need to glue and nail them together. When you apply the glue to your corners, you
just want to make sure you get a really good coating. We're going to continue on mailing and gluing
our mitered corners making sure that they're flushed. This is already starting to take shape. Let's glue and pin this final piece in. Now we just need to put some brackets in to
provide some additional strength. We're going to drill and screw them in, really
simple. We now need to measure the top of our vanity
unit and cut it to length. To preserve the natural look of the wood,
I'm going to give it a clear stain. This will go and looking kind of milky but
it will dry clear. You can do what you want, but I think that
the clear stain here will really make the wood look good. To fit our vanity, we're going to bring it
up and make sure the holes are in line with our rear bar. It is quite heavy so you will need an extra
set of hands. Once the vanity is back up and in place, you
can just put some glue along the back of the rear bar. There you have it, completed floating vanity
unit. [Inaudible 0:03:48] vanity which would cost
a fortune in the shops, we've done it in a fraction of the price, plus it's something
we've made ourselves. The timber brings a beautiful natural elegance
to the room, and a simple design is understated but really stylish. I absolutely love it.

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: putting up a shelf is the classic DIY project and there are loads of different types available we put up a floating shelf which as the name suggests looks like it's floating in mid-air that's really sleek and stylish the important thing to remember is to make sure you pick the right fixing for the wall that you're popping it on - if it's plasterboard use special possible fixings we fix this one onto a brick wall is how you do it first check that there are no hidden pipes or cables using an electronic detector never drill directly above or below a light fitting or power socket because that's where its supply cables are most likely to be if using a stepladder ensure it's correctly set up on a level surface and all work items are clear from the bottom of the ladder then following the manufacturer's instructions hold a metal strip on the wall at the height you want ensure that the hole found along each prong is facing downwards make sure it's horizontal with a spirit level then mark the fixing hole positions with a pencil the instructions will say how many you need to use mark the length of your wall plugs on the drill bit using a piece of tape put your goggles on and then drill the holes of the marked positions you may need to switch to hammer action to get through a brick or a stone wall gently tap in the wall plugs with a hammer to ensure they're flush with the wall now screw the bracket in place then slide the Shelf onto the bars secure the Shelf in place with the under side screws finally cover up the screw heads with the supplied stickers for a seamless finish floating elves do look great on your wall but they're not really suitable for very heavy objects and make sure you don't overload if you want something stronger use a shelf with brackets

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: have you ever wanted something more from your IKEA magazine holders today we're hacking IKEA these IKEA hack shelves you'll need Knuth magazine holders a dark stain paintbrush drywall anchors screws level measuring tape a drill and a pencil start by standing the outside of the magazine holders and when dry stain the inside place the dry holder horizontally in a corner in the position that you'd like it level it out and trace a straight line along the wall to mark its location mark a point five inches along one side of the corner and ten inches along the other side from these points measure a point that is one point eight inches straight down and Mark it with a pencil this was half the width of the magazine holder drill in basic drywall anchors of heat points on the magazine holder itself measure a point that's five inches along the bottom and one that's ten inches along the backside Center these points about one point eight inches and mark with a pencil pre-drill a hole at each point and insert a screw into each of these holes line them up with the anchors and drill the screws in repeat this process for as many shelves as you want there you have it we've turned these boring magazine holders into these cool IKEA hack shelves what projects do you want us to do in future videos let us know in the comments and if you haven't already don't forget to subscribe thanks for watching so next step is to switch this off we're gonna put in the grilles turn it to breakfast bar and get cooking let's get this bacon off she's getting crispy I am impressed prosciutto melon and basil

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: I gave my lack wall shelf a makeover and it looks so good so here are the things I use to go about it so obviously I started with my lack wall shelf and I have mine here in the black brown shade which is alright but I kind of wanted to lighten it up a little bit so I have to be in the kitchen storage department at Canadian Tire and I found this really nice lining and it only cost six dollars and the veneer looks very similar to an actual wood veneer and you can also find this at Walmart or Home Depot you'll need scissors to make cuts and an exacto knife to finish the edges this little subway pass came in really handy when I was applying the lining okay so I'm really working on the floor because I don't want to just my dining table dented from the low wall shelf it looks pretty pretty heavy enough sharp corners on your spoon to lay out this old tablecloth bow from the dollar store and I'm going to work on it so here's the last wall shelf it is about 43 inches long 2 inches deep and 10 inches wide here and so I'm going to be laying down this adhesive in four pieces so I'm going to have one piece covering this side one piece covering the other side one piece that's going to go over on the top and throughout the side and another piece that's going to cover this side so I'll show you how I do it so I cut a piece that was wide enough to cover the one side and what's nice about this lining is that it's backing has grid lines so you can easily cut on a straight line separating the backing from the lining was a bit of a struggle so you really need to use your fingernails once I got that taken care of I put the lining on the side of the shelves so I flattened up with my hands at first but then I ran over it again with my subway card to ensure that there are no air bubbles left and the car is really affected especially when you're going over the corners when dealing with the part of the liner that's supposed to cover over the front end of the shelf you kind of fold it up the same way you would a Christmas present you don't want that part to be too bulky so just fold and cut the way you see me doing it here and use your exacto knife to make the edges look a bit more precise make sure you have some cleaner close by throughout the project because inevitably you'll get oil from your fingertips onto the shelf and you don't want that because you want the the lining to adhere well so towel the cleaner off with a regular towel not a paper one because the paper one will leave fibers behind take off the backing of the liner and line it up with the shelf taking off the back end can be a bit of a struggle it took me a little while to figure out what not to do ripping the backing off piece by piece is not the best idea because the tearing of the paper makes it very difficult to remove so it's best to cut the backing straight across and then remove it all in one piece so now that I have that squared away I can smooth out the liner with my hand and with my subway card I continue the process over the front side I cut off the excess in the back since that part is where the Shelf meets Bracken so now I'm doing the other side and at this point I have mastered my lining skills here's what the Shelf looks like in the back the last step before putting the shelf on the wall is to expose the holes where the screws will go in so with my exacto knife I made a cut in the shape of an X to make sure that the bracket and shelf were aligned properly I insert the center screw partially through and if you have any questions about how to install the lack shelf I have a whole other video and I'll be showing a preview of it at the end or you can click the link in the description box and here's my new lack shelf I'm really happy with the results the seam on the right hand side is a bit more pronounced than I would like but all-in-all I think I did a pretty good job now it's ready for me to put some of my things on it and you can see the bottom is free and clear of any screw heads giving it a nice clean appearance so if you have a lack shelf or you're thinking of getting one you should try this DIY out I say it's $6 well-spent thanks for watching I see Melanie

raise the shelf up until it gets level
once it's in a nice level position pop a
nail in you can use regular nails to it
work just as well

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content:
This bathroom is ready to go. We've already had the trade's man in and they've
done the electrics and the plumbing. I want to put something of my own in here,
so I'm going to build a beautiful hardwood floating vanity. It's going to be a real centerpiece for the
bathroom. Here all the tools materials I'm going to
need to make my floating vanity. The first thing we're going to do is join
our two pieces of timber together. I want to make sure I get the nicest faces
up right. Now stands your timber boards up, glue the
edges, lay them back down and clamp them together. As we don't want to damage our timber, we're
just going to use some chalks in between the clamp and the timber. To ensure that the boards don't bark in the
middle when clamping, we're going to put two additional clamps on top. We're now going to remove all the glue from
this side of the board using a chisel and a rag. We use a chisel as this avoids spreading the
glue around. To get these two boards level and remove the
step, we're going to put one block off cut timber underneath, the other on top. And we're going to hammer them level. Now, the timbers all level, we just need to
clean off the excess glue and then leave it to dry. Make sure you follow the drying times in the
back of the glue you've used. Now it's fully dried. I've taken off the clamps and we need to remove
any excess glue that has oozed down, and then flip it and do the other side as well. We're going to sand back our timber. We're going to be using a belt sander here
as it will give us a nice smooth finish, and we want to make sure we have a nice level
finish as well. It's looking great, so we'll send it back. We need to make two of these, so we can repeat
exactly the same process for a second board. You should now have two of these pieces of
timber. They've all been sanded back. You're not going to pick out the best piece
for your top, and you need to mark that and the frontage. The next thing we're going to do is cut the
45 degree miter at one end and then we're going to measure back to give us the length
of our vanity top. Now we've got our top done and miter it out
the way, we're going to follow a similar process on this second board. The three pieces were going to get are the
side panels, the basin and then the miter. Now we need to join the pieces together and
miter them. Before doing this is a really good idea to
mark those pieces are going to join together, so you don't get confused later on. I've now rebated all my mitered corners for
my brackets to fit into. We now need to glue and nail them together. When you apply the glue to your corners, you
just want to make sure you get a really good coating. We're going to continue on mailing and gluing
our mitered corners making sure that they're flushed. This is already starting to take shape. Let's glue and pin this final piece in. Now we just need to put some brackets in to
provide some additional strength. We're going to drill and screw them in, really
simple. We now need to measure the top of our vanity
unit and cut it to length. To preserve the natural look of the wood,
I'm going to give it a clear stain. This will go and looking kind of milky but
it will dry clear. You can do what you want, but I think that
the clear stain here will really make the wood look good. To fit our vanity, we're going to bring it
up and make sure the holes are in line with our rear bar. It is quite heavy so you will need an extra
set of hands. Once the vanity is back up and in place, you
can just put some glue along the back of the rear bar. There you have it, completed floating vanity
unit. [Inaudible 0:03:48] vanity which would cost
a fortune in the shops, we've done it in a fraction of the price, plus it's something
we've made ourselves. The timber brings a beautiful natural elegance
to the room, and a simple design is understated but really stylish. I absolutely love it.

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hi I'm Matt and I'm Jackie and we're the husband-and-wife team that make up the DIY village we're here today on behalf of homes.com to bring you a tutorial on how to build your own custom built-in bookshelves today we're working in my craft room we're going to be using the space around the window that is often wasted between the wall and the window casing we're going to be going from the floor to the ceiling so that we can get the most out of this space going vertical is probably the best way you can go so that you can get lots of storage plus built in is going to give us a really upgraded professional look in the house and going to return some value in what we spend on the materials too so now we're going to be making the base for the bookshelf we're using 1 by 3 stock we've cut them down to the measurements based on the area we're working in and we're going to put these together using the Kreg jig jr. and that's a product that allows you to easily join pieces of wood together make really really strong joints to give you a little idea how it works these gray areas here are sliders they have measurements on each side and those measurements are correspond with the width of the wood you're working with so these boards are 3/4 inch thick and what we'll do is we'll slide these over to where they are on the 3/4 inch marks that leaves a little bit of a lip right there so that as we are ready to drill the pocket holes will put the jig in place by pushing it flush up against the end of the wood and we'll take this clamp and we'll go ahead and clamp them in place and then Jackie is going to drill the pocket hole we'll clamp off check out the dust and we have pocket holes very very strong joints that will flip it to the opposite side and we'll do the exact same thing the way this is going to work is when we have all the pocket holes drill will take longer pieces here and will join them together with the shorter pieces using screws that are made for pocket holes the inside pieces will clamp in place and then screw them in okay we're ready to start building the bookcase it's a very simple process we're going to be using our 1 by 12 we've already cut them length to length and we've cut the top to length but what you're looking at here are two sides and the top we're going to connect these using the same system we used for the base the Kreg jig Junior we're going to get pocket holes in the side pieces and those screws will attach through the side piece into the top piece pulling this joint tight we'll do the same thing on this side about halfway down we're going to cut a shelf that will be a fixed shelf we're going to measure it to fit inside between the the two sides and in the pocket holes will actually be drilled on the sides of the fixed shelf and go into the sides here of these then we'll do the bottom piece exactly the same way we did this one like I said a very simple process so we'll go ahead and get that going and we'll move on to getting the adjustable shelf side okay so we've gone ahead and we've attached the side to the bottom and top and we've added a fixed shelf in the center what we're going to do now is we're going to make the pin holes for the adjustable shelves we're going to use the Kreg shelf pin jig we've got two of them and makes it really easy to use so what we're going to do is we're going to measure up we've measured about halfway from the bottom to where the edge of the Shelf pin jig meets we've clamped it in place and now we're going place the other one here we're going to clamp it in place as well and now Jackie's going to go ahead and using the bit that comes with the Shelf pin jig she's going to go ahead and drill the holes for the adjustable shelving nice thing about using the Shelf pin jig instead of using something like pegboard is the Shelf pin jig has a steel collar in the inside and so your drill bits not going to walk you're going to get a pretty precise drill bit hole for your shelter now we're we're all done with the construction of the frame of the bookcase we need to prep a few things in the craft room before we can actually do a drive fit we need to remove the baseboard in the area that we're going to put in the the platform base so I'm going to use an oscillating cutting tool to do that it's got a shaking blade it's kind of loud so definitely what I have hearing protection on and eye protection to so we're going to go ahead and do that one thing to keep in mind when you're removing the baseboards is you will have to come back in and use a utility knife and where it's been cocked in place before you'll need to score that area all right now we've got the baseboard out of the way we can go ahead and take our platform base and put it in place now I'm going to take the bookcase and we're going to dry fit it to make sure that we don't need to make any adjustments all right that's not bad it's pretty tight you might have to cut off a little bit more base over here just to get that flush up against the wall while I'm doing that though I might go ahead mark what I need to mark and have Jacquie go ahead and start painting well as you might be able to see we've done a few things to add some bulk to the bookcase we went ahead and installed it in place and secured it against a stud over here in this wall definitely want to make sure it's secure in place we have a little one running around and we definitely do not want this falling anywhere we've also added some one by two trim here on the sides and also on this fixed shelf here we added the adjustable shelves here and one on the bottom and the nice thing about how many chef's pin holes we drilled when we were outside is we have the flexibility of adding a couple more shelves we definitely have more room here and on the bottom four shelves if we want to add any more in the future so up here you can see we've added the crown molding to the top that kind of adds a built-in look about it and then down here at the bottom we matched the the base molding that was already existing in the room and we continued it around the bookcase so it has a true built in feel one nice thing that Jackie did when it came to decorating this is she combined organization and storage with the core so she took some of the stuff she might normally not have out showcasing and put sort of on display on the bookcase but she also has all the stores she needs for all her materials on behalf of homes comm thanks for joining us be sure to subscribe to homes comm youtube channel and be on the lookout for our next video tutorial you

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: today I'm going to build a few shelves from my daughter's pottery and the design for the shelving is inspired by the artist Donald Judd who is a minimalist sculptor and I made this small model to get an example of what one of the sculptures kind of looks like you'd have to imagine this bigger and these cubes made in a different material they were often made in aluminum and plexiglass I'll start by making four boxes the top and the bottom of the boxes will be made out of half-inch birch plywood the tops of the bottoms are on the same measurement so I've set up a stop block and that way I only need to measure once I've got the tops and the bottoms of the box cut and now ready to move on to the walls and that's this part right here and for that I'm using 3/4 inch birch plywood and these are just some odds and ends that have been hanging around the shop it's a good way to use them up and also the 3/4 inch birch plywood will be more stable than using solid wood I've got all of my parts cut and I'm ready to start assembling the boxes I'm going to attach the front to the sides first and then I'll attach the bottoms and the tops I'll use a little wood glue and inch and 3/4 nails in the nail gun and now to attach the tops and the bottoms and just make sure you're flush with the front as you work your way around the box it's always a good idea to use a damp rag to remove any excess glue before it has a chance to set up I finished making all the boxes and the next step is to band the edges to hide the end grain and the plywood up and the two sides in the front now I'm painting the boxes so MDF will work fine but if you wanted to you could also make these boxes out of cherry or I think they look good in walnut just make them out of walnut plywood then band the edges with walnut or you could even laminate a veneer on the boxes even though I know the walls of the box are 2 inches and I've used half inch plywood on the top and the bottom it's still a good idea to take a measurement because sometimes happens plywood can be a little bit light this looks pretty good though so I'll rip the edge banding at 3 inches you Motz new day I've got a few coats of paint on all the boxes and now getting ready to install them I'll install the shelving by the Kachin cleats to the wall and then the shelving will fit over the cleats now I make these cleats out of 3/4 inch birch plywood simply laminating two pieces of plywood together I made them a little bit heavy and then I trim them on the table saw so it's just a nice snug fit in the back of the box the way I like to install a shelving system like this is to first install the bottom cleat now I've only got a stud in the center here so I've pre-drilled encounter some two holes in the cleat and these two screws will catch the stud and at the ends here I'll put a dab of glue and I'll put a screw in to these holes it's only going to hit sheetrock but between the glue and the two screws in the stud that should be more than enough to support shelving this small I've attached a cleat with one screw and made sure that the cleat is level and now I'm ready for the second screw I'm using 3-inch cabinet screws to attach the cleats to make the installation a little easier I've ripped a piece of quarter-inch plywood to 13 inches and this way I'll have the same spacing between each shelf and since the bottom cleat is level all I need to do is attach the second cleat at the line I'm attaching the shelving to the cleats with inch-and-a-quarter drywall screws and I took a minute to spray-paint the screws first and that just looks a little bit nicer Hey well I had a lot of fun with this project and if you think you want to make these shelves I'll put this cut list up on my website just search Donald Judd inspired shelving system now if you have any questions I'm going to answer them and I'm gonna start doing the follow-up video I guess maybe on Wednesdays Tuesday's on Wednesdays and so if you have any questions just leave them in the comments please subscribe also I'm going to start doing a lot more with Facebook so if you've made a project a lot of people have made the projects that I've made here in the shop I'm going to start posting them up on my Facebook and some of the paintings that people make in my painting class now as far as inspiration I like to talk about different artists because I think it's really good to look at a lot of different art and furniture design sculptures because you really never know where your inspiration is going to come from and what I decided to do a video on this project I took a look around on the web and I found a pretty cool interview hour piece that 60 minutes did on Marfa Texas now Donald Judd had bought an abandoned military base in Marfa and that's where most of his sculptures are housed today and it's become kind of a mecca for art and artsy type people and so on one hand you have these ranches that have been around forever and now you have all these kind of artsy people and it's created this sort of nice little coexisting community that it actually looks like a fun place to go visit but if you want to know more about that I'll put a link to the 60 minutes piece in the description of this video thanks for tuning in and I'll see you soon thanks dad one two three go

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: hey everybody's Courtney with friend from gray house studio and today we have a super simple but equally awesome looking project to share with you guys Brent is going to show you how we built these bookshelves for a nursery I'm pretty excited about the bookshelves but I think I'm most excited about reading books like the stinky cheese man so I've still cracked it open but I looks like it promises to be interesting to get started I began by cutting a 1 by 6 board for the shelves to 20 inches long then I cut the same 1 by 6 inch board for the two sides 4 inches long I clamped a board to the fence to make both cuts exactly the same length the mounting plate on the back of the shelf is a 1 by 2 inch board cut 10 inches long this will go in the center of the shelf and it will be covered up by books that's why it's shorter than the whole shelf the last piece to cut is a 1 by 1 inch board that's 20 inches long to match the width of the shelf and that will be the front rail I cut multiple of these at the same time since I built four shelves to assemble each shelf I started by drilling two pilot holes to attach the 1 by 2 inch mounting plate to the back of the shelf I used wood glue and two 1 and 5/8 inch wood screws to attach each mounting plate to attach each sideboard I use 1/2 inch finishing nails and wood glue to attach the front rail I used to scrap one by two to place under the rail to hold it level with the bottom and give me the same spacing on each shelf I attached the rail through the side boards with finishing nails once all the shelves were assembled I used wood filler to fill in the holes on the side and painted the shelves white using a nap roller for a smooth finish before hanging the shelves I've marked on the wall where the wall studs were with painters tape then after centering and leveling each shelf I screwed the Shelf into the wall over the wall studs using 3-inch screws if you found this project interesting and video helpful be sure to click the like button below to let us know you want to see more videos like this subscribe to our YouTube channel so you don't miss more videos like this and leave us a comment in the comment section if you have any questions be sure to check out studio gray house comm for all the details on this project and to find more projects like it

title: Build Simple Floating Shelves
content: Hey guys, Again Mr ATC and welcome back to MyATCtv!!! Today we are going to create a nice DIY floating shelf for the bathroom and for less than 15 euros… For this project, I have been invited to work on a new bathroom design in Paris and the goal was adding a simple DIY floating shelf in this corner as you can see just right here which is measuring  23 cm large… The owner of this apartment couldn’t find the right furniture for this spot so ask me to design it... And as you already know as soon when it’s about making, I am all IN!!! That’s the reason why, I’ve decided to share this project with you in case you find yourself experiencing the same problem at home… Alright!!!! So enough talking let’s make it happen!!! To make this shelf you don’t really require a lot of tools, here I am making it with 2 pieces of lumber from 1 meter long, 20 cm large and 1.9 cm thick Here Each of the 3 shelves will be cut at 20 cm large and 21 cm long in order to be inserted into the main back piece I gonna  start by cutting the different shelves pieces first and note that for this I am using a minor saw but you could also use a handsaw or jigsaw depending of what you have available. To insert the different shelves, i am here taking some marks in order to cut using my router and making a deep cut at 0.7cm… then I decided to place the shelves to have a first testing look and also trace a line giving me their exact thickness to follow with my router Yeah, looks like I like it already… Alright time to use the router! Here if you decide to use a router, remember to be very precise in order to cut just on the line. Here to make sure the shelves are staying in place and with an angle of 90 degrees I decided to drill some holes in order to insert screws from the back (so when looking in front of the shelves, they should be invisible) and keeping this all creation strong and stable Then I am sanding a little bit to avoid having any side particles while trying to slide the 3 shelves to the holes… For the finish, I’ve decided to use some invisible lacquer to keep the real wood texture and spirit as I really liked it.. Even if the color in the bathroom was mainly gray, i thought that adding a wood spirit with this DIY shelf could create a very nice additional design And here we are with a cool DIY bathroom shelf. Guys as usual, remember that you will be able to find below in the video description links a free plan to this creation if you want to make it yourself And don’t forget to share with us your own creations via the ATC App, you will have a link showing up just above this video Feel free to check it out!!! I really hope that you liked this project, and as usual, Mr ATC for another idea of housing!!!! See you next time and don’t forget to share, subscribe and comment below the video… Bye….

For this project, I have been invited to work on a new bathroom design in Paris
and the goal was adding a simple DIY floating shelf in this corner
as you can see just right here which is measuring  23 cm large…
The owner of this apartment couldn’t find the right furniture for this spot so ask me to design it...
And as you already know as soon when it’s about making, I am all IN!!!
That’s the reason why, I’ve decided to share this project with you in case you find yourself experiencing the same problem at home…
Alright!!!! So enough talking let’s make it happen!!!
To make this shelf you don’t really require a lot of tools, here I am making it with 2 pieces of lumber from 1 meter long, 20 cm large and 1.9 cm thick
Here Each of the 3 shelves will be cut at 20 cm large and 21 cm long in order to be inserted into the main back piece
I gonna  start by cutting the different shelves pieces first
and note that for this I am using a minor saw but you could also use a handsaw or jigsaw depending of what you have available.
To insert the different shelves, i am here taking some marks in order to cut using my router
and making a deep cut at 0.7cm…
then I decided to place the shelves to have a first testing look and also trace a line giving me their exact thickness to follow with my router
Yeah, looks like I like it already…
Alright time to use the router! Here if you decide to use a router, remember to be very precise in order to cut just on the line.
Here to make sure the shelves are staying in place and with an angle of 90 degrees
I decided to drill some holes in order to insert screws from the back (so when looking in front of the shelves, they should be invisible)
and keeping this all creation strong and stable
Then I am sanding a little bit to avoid having any side particles while trying to slide the 3 shelves to the holes…
For the finish, I’ve decided to use some invisible lacquer to keep the real wood texture and spirit as I really liked it..
Even if the color in the bathroom was mainly gray, i thought that adding a wood spirit with this DIY shelf could create a very nice additional design
And here we are with a cool DIY bathroom shelf.
Guys as usual, remember that you will be able to find below in the video description links a free plan to this creation if you want to make it yourself

I really hope that you liked this project, and as usual, Mr ATC for another idea of housing!!!!

Bye….

while back I actually did a video on how I completely redid our like dining room table it was just a classic wood table and I kind of flipped it and made it farmhouse style I painted it in stained it so I thought I would just kind of continue this little series here on my channel as I you know work on my house and fix it up a little bit I'm basically just trying to do everything on a small budget and do a lot of it myself do a lot of DIY project so today's video I'm going to be showing you how I made these really awesome DIY floating shelves they kind of have a rustic farmhouse feel and they were very inexpensive and actually surprisingly really easy to put together so I'm going to show you step-by-step everything I did to create these beautiful shelves you can kind of see a little bit of a sneak peak of one of the shelves behind me I am still working on decorating them but they are just totally transforming in this room which is our main living room and I'm so in love with them so I'm going to show you guys everything that I did the very first thing that we did is we went to Lowe's our local Lowe's and picked up the materials that I needed so first I just picked out four of like the pre-cut like wood plank fours we used pine and they were super easy to find you just go to like the wood section of the store and they have like all different cuts and lengths and widths of just different wood planks four foot planks were perfect for the wall space you're working with so I picked up four of those and then I also grabbed some Elle hooks I believe they're called and that's what we actually used to like fasten the shelves to the wall and then lastly I picked up some black spray-paint which is what I used on the l-looks to turn them from boring ugly metal into like a matte black some of the supplies that I needed for this project I already had at home like one stain and screws and you know things like that so once we got all that stuff we headed home and neck I started working on actually the shells themselves turning them from boy blanks to really gorgeous stained shelves so the very first thing I did was just give each of the wood planks a good sanding and then brush all of the sanding dust off so then it was time to stain the wood if you can see the Roses tale just ignore it considering were you guys doing on the couch right now but I used a stain from mini wax it's actually the same stain I used on my dining room table the top of it and I believe it's in the shade espresso and basically I just painted that on with a paint brush going with the grain I just did one coat because the what I like the way that that color payoff turned out it's kind of a rich deep cool tone brown I really like it so I went ahead and I stayed all four of the shells or the wood planks and then I let that sit overnight and just completely dry and the next day I went back and I actually put like a top coat or a finish on it like a wood finish which is just clear these aren't really going to be touched or handled ever so I probably could have just skip this but I figured I would just put one coat on the directions actually said to put like two to three coats on and let them dry and then sand in between but since no one's ever going to be touching these I just throw in one coat and called it a day not sure if that that we were supposed to do it seems to be okay thus far I am so not Pro when it comes to sup I'm just like totally winging it so who knows the next thing I did was I spray-painted all of the L hooks so they would be like a nice matte black I just took them off my backyard throw down a plastic-like drop cloth and just sprayed them on all sides that was super easy and then the next thing to do was actually install them on the wall so for this part I actually had Matt come and help me because he's a little bit better with this kind of stuff I did help out but he definitely just the rains as far as the installation of my DIY shelves so the first step to actually hang them on the wall was choosing where we were going to put them so we just kind of measured on the wall and figured out where they would fit best you know on the wall space that we had and then we just went ahead and marked those areas for where we kind of wanted the shelves to sit then we went ahead and used a handy stud finder to go ahead and just find like the drywall like the not the drywall but the wood planks and I don't even know what the term for those are but you guys find out what I'm talking about so we use the stud finder to locate these studs and then we would actually hammer the L hooks into those studs so I just put it into the drywall as well and just need to make sure to get those like special hooks like the plastic with the nail inside it's like a two-for-one type screw and those hold a lot of weight and you can just put it directly in the drywall and you don't need a stud but our stud we're conveniently located to where we kind of wanted to put the L books on the wall so it worked out fine so once we figure out where the studs were and do where we were going to be hammering in we went ahead and just made like a small line on the wall where like the bottom of each shelf would go and that way we knew exactly where the L hooks should kind of like land on the wall because the L hook was gonna be holding the bottom of the shelf so once we had that done he actually went ahead and started putting the L hook on the wall and as he was going along he kept using the level over and over just to make sure that everything was obviously level but more so that so that each hook was completely level with each other so we wouldn't have like crooked shelves because that would not be good then once we had our L hooks on the wall we went ahead
